Text: Ethics will be the base of how I practice.  Delivering the best possible care while being ethical at the same time is how I intend to practice. on which I base my practice.

For the next four years, I want to grow as an individual.  I want to become a professional.  I have been around the dental field for the past few years, working in a dental office as a dental assistant.  I want to transition from being a dental assistant to a dentist.  I hope once I finish my four years at NYU I will be a confident and ethical doctor.  I find it so important to establish trusting relationship with patients, and the first thing is to do everything in the best interest of the patient.

Becoming a professional I believe takes time.  You need to be exposed to situations where you need to interact with other professionals and learn from them.  I believe you never stop learning to become a professional, it is a lifelong process.

Becoming a professional I believe takes time.  You need to be exposed to situations where you need to interact with other professionals and learn from them.  I believe you never stop learning to become a professional, it is a lifelong process.

Beginning of my dental career two years ago, I have come a long way so far. I have gained so many skills, interpersonally, socially, and most importantly with manual dexterity. I am looking forward in applying all those skills and I am eager to learn more in my next two years in NYUCD.

For the next four years, I want to grow as an individual.  I want to become a professional.  I have been around the dental field for the past few years, working in a dental office as a dental assistant.  I want to transition from being a dental assistant to a dentist.  I hope once I finish my four years at NYU I will be a confident and ethical doctor.  I find it so important to establish trusting relationship with patients, and the first thing is to do everything in the best interest of the patient.

As a health care professional, it is my duty to be ethical in all my actions and interactions. In treating patients, I will learn about the community around me so that I can be culturally sensitive and empathetic. I will also stick to a code of ethics that I will hold myself to. These will include putting my patient's desires, and health and oral health above my own personal desires. I will always provide my patients with all their options so that they may be able to make the best decision for their oral health based on their limitations and their understanding. I will always document my procedures and any important events that occur during my patient's visit, so that I can legally protect myself and themselves, and so that the work is documented for future review. I will  never discriminate and will serve all equally, regardless of ethnicity, gender, faith, sexual orientation, etc.

As a dental student, I will strive to learn about various oral health diseases and their symptoms, as well as different methods to improve oral hygiene. I will also learn the processes behind these diseases, and how to treat them. In the clinic, I will learn about the characteristics of each teeth, how to restore them via crowns, fillings, or root canals, how to remove caries, how to make complete and partial dentures and how to create models and impressions for studying a patient's mouth or for preparing crowns or retainers. I will also learn how to interact with patients in terms of explaining procedures to them in words they can understand, in a manner that is respectful, and in a empathetic and ethical way (putting the patient's health and wants above my own personal desires). Finally, I hope to learn from my colleagues and practice communicating and working together with them. I believe that an environment in which everyone is honest and working together as a team ends up benefitting both those working as well as the patients being treated.

Personally, as a professional I hope that I can possibly specialize in an area such as orthodontics, pediatrics, periodontics, or endodontics. However I will not limit myself to these specialties and I will explore other areas of specialty. I will also be satisfied with being a general dentist as well. Ultimately though, it depends on what I find I enjoy the most. I would also like to open my own clinic or at least have a clinic with another associate, especially because of the ease of accessibility to another dentist's opinion. Finally, I will strive to treat all my patients with respect, and all my colleagues with gratification and respect. I will try to be patient with patients that can be difficult to communicate with or patients who may have different ideologies than myself. I will  never discriminate and will serve all equally, regardless of ethnicity, gender, faith, sexual orientation, etc.

In becoming a health professional, I hope to provide my patients with the best care I can possibly give. That includes continuing my education by going to conventions and conferences to learn about the most up to date technologies for oral hygiene. I will also constantly challenge myself to better my work, by self-assessing myself often and checking on past work to see if anything should be redone. As a professional, I will strive for clear and concise communication with the patient and with my colleagues. I will also attempt to ensure that all my patients understand the importance of oral hygiene to overall health and the various ways they can take care of their teeth and health. Even if my patients have difficulty practicing this, I want to make sure I give them all the information and knowledge so that they can make their own autonomous decision about their dental health.

After my second year of dental school and entering my third year, I've learned much more about how the oral cavity can reflect diseases in the body or how the oral cavity can be affected because of other changes occurring in the patient's body. I've learned how to work with another student as a dental assistant and vice versa, learning more about team effort. I've learned the steps and processes needed in creating a complete and a removable partial denture. I've also learned how to prepare crowns and bridges as well as make temporary crowns and bridges. I've learned more about how to interact with patients and now that I am in clinic, I am starting to understand how to communicate with my patients in a way that shows professionalism and competence while still being a student at the school. I also learned how to give local anesthesia to my patients in the form of nerve blocks and infiltrations, how to perform a comprehensive exam and x-rays, prophylaxis, scaling and root planing, and simple restorations. I still have yet to perform endodontics or prosthodontics yet but I aim to soon.

As a dental student, I will strive to learn how to best serve my patients, the community around me, and various communities around the country and the world. Specifically, I will become knowledgeable on the causes and symptoms of dental diseases as well as full body diseases, especially those that can become evident in the oral cavity. I will learn to treat patients both in the short-term and long-term capacity. I will also strive to treat all my patients with respect, sympathy, and ethically. I will always put the patient's health and desires above any personal gain, and I will be sure to refer my patient's to other doctors or dentists if I do not feel able to complete a procedure. I will practice my communication skills and being honest with my patients. I will practice my own skills so that I am competent and able to serve others well. I strive to continue learning new methods, techniques, and technologies when appropriate, to be better able to treat my patients.

So far my time in clinic as a D3 has been a tremendous learning experience as well as a lot of fun.  I finally get to apply the knowledge that i've gained in my D1 and D2 years, as well as gain new knowledge and tips/tricks from the D4s and various faculties.  When I first started in clinic I was very nervous and unsure of how I would be able to deal with treating my patients.  Now that I have been in clinic for just over 2 months, I feel more comfortable and competent in my abilities.  The majority of my treatments to date have been SRPs, and I feel like I know how to efficiently and properly complete these procedures.  I have also already completed 1 of my SRP competencies and successfully passed.  I have also got more confident and steady in terms of delivering LA to my patients vs. when I first started in clinic.  I have also completed my NBDE part 1 in August and am currently awaiting the results that should arise in the next week or two, with the hopes that I passed the exam.

Growing up, my dentist was the most influential on my definition of dentistry. My interactions with her and her comforting approach to treatment defined what I thought of dentistry and how I still describe it to this very day. I loved how she would talk to me about school, sports, and tv shows before ever asking me to open my mouth. I knew I was more than a set of teeth and more than a name on a chart. I look forward to providing my future patients with a similar experience. I am looking forward to developing the knowledge and skills necessary to assure my patients that they are receiving the best quality of care.  
                        Throughout these next few years, I envision myself being molded into a competent healthcare provider. I hope to build professional relationships with my colleagues and faculty. My time at NYUCD is an opportunity for me to best prepare for the demands of dentistry and the needs of my patients. Dentistry is an evolving field and I am excited to be a part of what it will have to offer in the near coming future.

The term "professional" is thrown around a lot in everyday conversation. We may declare someone as a 'professional hockey player' or a 'professional stone carver.' The word professional carries value and a sense of higher standard. What we expect from a professional is expertise and reassurance that the work or role being fulfilled will be of the highest quality. When I hear the word "dental professional," I imagine someone that is looked upon by the general public as a trusted figure to provide the utmost quality of care and treatment. A professional is a person that has received a structured education and/or discipline that pertains specifically to that profession. The individual is accepted as one that has proven his/her competence in the demands of that field. 
      While a student at NYUCD, I would like to imagine myself approach these definitions of a professional as I progress through the tiers of dental school. I am excited to be an important and dynamic influence on my patient's lives and serve as a vital component in their path to a healthy lifestyle. It is a great privilege to be a trusted individual in society and looked upon as a symbol of wellbeing.

      While a student at NYUCD, I would like to imagine myself approach these definitions of a professional as I progress through the tiers of dental school. I am excited to be an important and dynamic influence on my patient's lives and serve as a vital component in their path to a healthy lifestyle.

My interactions with her and her comforting approach to treatment defined what I thought of dentistry and how I still describe it until this very day. I loved how she would talk to me about school, sports, and tv shows before ever asking me to open my mouth. I knew I was more than a set of teeth and more than a name on a chart. I look forward to providing my future patients with a similar experience. I am looking forward to developing the knowledge and skills necessary to assure my patients that they are receiving the best quality of care.

I hope to build professional relationships with my colleagues and faculty. My time at NYUCD is an opportunity for me to best prepare for the demands of dentistry and the needs of my patients. Dentistry is an evolving field and I am excited to be a part of what it will have to offer in the near coming future.

I will most likely run into many instances where I would have to make a decision based on my ethical values. I heard that some dentists would prep a tooth that does not need to be prepped, then later they would recommend RCT, then the crown, or even implants. Economically speaking, it is the most efficient way to make profit. With one tooth, we can potentially make thousands of dollars. But that's not why I'm here. My ultimate goal is to practice in underserved countries while I maintain an office in the States so that I can provide resources for myself to help those in need. In order to achieve this, I should evaluate my own actions constantly and that I won't fall into the temptations that many unethical dentists fall into.

Last two years at dental school was the most difficult time of my life. After having some relationship problems right before getting in, I felt like I was only going downhill regardless of what was going on at school. The first year I think at least I tried hard to keep up with school. Then the second year started when my depressive thoughts flipped its switch and turned into massive anxiety. The cause is still not clear to me, and I really hated myself for being so mentally weak. I honestly think I have never been so vulnerable in my entire life. I would put off studying until the last minute, and the grades reflected my unstable mental state. I dreamed of being an oral surgeon since I was in 10th grade in high school, but somehow I felt so lost all of a sudden. Thankfully, I still passed the second year and now I'm in clinic. Dealing with patients and listening to their stories have been an eye-opening experience for me, helping me realize once again why I am here.

There are times when I feel that I am clueless about what is going on. Definitely not something I want as a professional. To think of all the things to come in the future, I do feel a little overwhelmed. How will I start my practice? Will I even be able to graduate without any problems? Questions like these constantly bother my mind, but even after spending a month in the clinic I can see myself adapting more and more to the environment. Yes, I am still not competent, but I believe in myself that I can only get better. I don't want to be just a dentist. I want to be my patients' friend, counselor, someone who they can fully trust. I want to change the perspective of the general public towards dentists, but I would first have to train myself to be competent in what I do. I hope that over the next two years I would gain more confidence and treat my patients with gentle heart.

As I started seeing more patients, I realize how unprepared I am. Even though I have learned all the things we should know as dentists, I feel like sometimes I cannot provide comprehensive care for my patients. Dealing with patients changed my perspective on dentistry, and now that the board exam is coming up, I have more responsibility inside that I want to know as much as possible to become a competent dentist. The other day, a patient came in with benign prostate hyperplasia, and I was able to have a conversation with him about the disease and the medications associated with the disease. If I had had no idea what the patient was talking about, I would have appeared as nothing but an untrustworthy student. There is still a lot more for me to learn, but now that I feel this growing responsibility, I will strive to be a competent professional whom my patients can trust.

After starting clinic, the sense of professionalism grew. It's not about getting my lab work signed by a faculty anymore. Each work is done in a patient's mouth, and I can see myself trying my best to do a good job on the patients. Even though they may not see exactly what I am doing in their mouths, I feel obliged to do the procedures at my best abilities. I have only done some restorative procedures only in the clinic, but as I get exposed to other cases I will feel more competent.

Over the last two years at NYUCD, I learned what it takes to be a dentist. It was definitely more than what I initially expected; from back to back exams to labs requiring numerous work, I almost feel like I've become a different person now. Along with the knowledge I gained, I was able to cope with stress. As I started clinic, I started to feel more like I'm actually in this journey of becoming a dentist. I didn't think I would find myself having "fun" as I dealt with patients. I guess it was all worth it in the end after digging through notes for the last two years, and I feel more responsible for the knowledge I should maintain.

To become ethical, one must first be able to know what is right and what is wrong.  And then, after know what is right and what is wrong, one must understand the appropriate actions following the determination.  It takes knowledge, experience, and courage to become truly ethical, and I aspire to become a great dentist that could deliver this to my future patients.  

I definitely learned a lot about the ethical work that being a dentist requires.  There are just so many ways to cut corners in dentistry that ethics can become a very critical issue in the entire system of health care delivery.

Looking back at what I wrote 2 years, ago, I find that surprisingly, I also felt about the ways that dentists can mistreat patients from the beginning, and it is sometimes hard to judge what is right and what is wrong because of deadlines, expectations and such.  But somehow I felt like after treating these patients, the best way is to really let your patients like you, and then they will do their best to accommodate for whatever treatment you're doing, whether it's delayed or whatever.

When I was young, I was scared of going to dentists because I am fearful. As I grow up, I learn more and more about this world to understand that danger is real, but fear is just an illusion that we create spontaneously to help ourselves overcome the obstacles.  I am very interested in the fear aspect of dentistry, and I would love to spend the next four years in NYUCD not only studying dentistry and perfecting my clinical skills, but also learn how to properly manage others' as well as my fear.

Now 2 years have passed and I really learned a lot, especially upon entering clinic.  I learned to deal with all kinds of pressures from patients, faculties and clinic personnel, and learning how to provide the best outcome so that everyone is satisfied.  I think when I graduate from NYU I will be more competent to work in the real world ~  I love this experience, everyday I learn so much from hands on work.

becoming a professional is not only a reflection of ourselves in front of our peers but also a reflection of ourselves in front of patients.  Someday when I can talk to the patients and guide them in my treatment the same way I have learned in school, especially in ethics class, then maybe I will be more professional than before.

I think there are so many ways to really do harm and mistreat patients, due to all kinds of factors such as pressures from lab, from patients' family, etc...   I think professionalism is to find a way to really provide the best outcome for patient's benefit, to do what is best for the patient while not compromising too much.

Professionalism is really stressed in this school and I think it is definitely having an effect on student body.  As the time comes and we all move into the clinic I am sure there will be more time to mature and progress in terms of professionalism.

Now that I have entered clinic, I think it's really important to observe if the patient likes a professional dentist that lectures constantly or just wants someone who is professional while working.  There's a big difference between both, and I think it really affects patient's mood as well.

I still remember in my personal statement for dental school application, I wrote a story about how a little boy was frightened to go to the dentists.  But 15 years later, this little boy is a grown man and started learning all the knowledge that is required to become a competent dentist.  I wish that after four years of school, I can step out of NYUCD being confident to treat patients, and to grow up to become a respected and compassionate dentist like my parents, whom I admire and aspire to.

2 years have passed and I learned so much from didactic courses, and now it's finally the real deal ! I really hope that when I graduate from NYU, I wouldn't be anxious the night before treating patients haha.

Ethical values are unique to dental professionals because dentists have a "special" role in the communities they participate in.  Dentists form a trusting relationship which their patients and with their community and therefore have a powerful position both socially and ethically.  This empowered position may serve as a struggling point for many professionals because it gives them a sense of entitlement and  limitless boundaries.  I think it is most important for dental professionals to remember what motivated them to enter the field in the first place:  promoting preventative oral healthcare as well as treating oral issues all the while staying within ethical boundaries to ensure the optimal health of their patients.

During my junior year of college I had the opportunity to go on a medical brigade to Honduras where I worked with doctors, dentists, and oral surgeons.  Before the brigade, I had wanted to be an orthopedist, but after my experiences in Honduras, I knew that I wanted to be a dentist.  Through my pre-med major and my sculpture minor, I have attained the skills necessary to succeed and excel in dental school.

Within the next four years, I want to feel confident enough in my clinical and diagnostic abilities that I will be able to accurately assess and treat a wide variety of patients.  I want to develop a language between myself and my patients that is both educational and understandable and help to make my patients feel a part of their treatment plan.  I want to be prepared to diagnose and treat a wide variety of patients with a wide variety of dental and oral issues when I exit NYUCD in four years.  I want to have the ability to give my patients a number of treatment options and make them feel integrated in their treatment plan.  I expect that I will continuously learn and expose myself to the dynamic and ever-changing oral health care system and that my diagnosis and treatments will reflect those changes throughout my career.

Within the next four years, I want to feel confident enough in my clinical and diagnostic abilities that I will be able to accurately assess and treat a wide variety of patients.  I want to develop a language between myself and my patients that is both educational and understandable and help to make my patients feel a part of their treatment plan.  I want to be prepared to diagnose and treat a wide variety of patients with a wide variety of dental and oral issues when I exit NYUCD in four years.  I want to have the ability to give my patients a number of treatment options and make them feel integrated in their treatment plan.  I expect that I will continuously learn and expose myself to the dynamic and ever-changing oral health care system and that my diagnosis and treatments will reflect those changes throughout my career.

I've worked my entire life to prepare myself to become a respected healthcare professional. I studied hard in elementary school so I could get into gate classed in Junior High, and I excelled in Junior High to ensure that I could take AP classes in High School.  I graduated in the top 1% of my high school so I could study at an excellent college.  I graduated from USC with honors to make sure I could study at one of the top dental schools in the United States.  Now, at NYUCD, I have all the tools necessary to become a respected oral health care professional.

During my junior year of college I had the opportunity to go on a medical brigade to Honduras where I worked with doctors, dentists, and oral surgeons.  Before the brigade, I had wanted to be an orthopedist, but after my experiences in Honduras, I knew that I wanted to be a dentist.  Through my pre-med major and my sculpture minor, I have attained the skills necessary to succeed and excel in dental school.

My goal for these next 4 years and beyond is to become a competent dentist, but also a person who is extremely professional and approachable. I want to master all the skills it takes to complete dental school and become a dentist who is confident and efficient. I want to use the knowledge and skills I learn here to further my career in either orthodontics or endodontics. I want to work as hard as I can in hopes to become a very competent professional because my patients are going to count on me. I want to be able to be extremely professional and learn how to do all of this and have a successful practice.

Compared to D1, I feel like I have gained a lot of knowledge. Learning new things about the dental field is helping me become a better professional.

Now that we have just began our third year and entered clinic I am becoming more aware of the necessity of all the things we have learned in the previous years. While I feel comfortable performing certain procedures, I hope to learn more about various techniques and findings in the year to come.

A dentist, in my opinion, is someone who will use their knowledge, skills, and own moral codes to provide the best care for their patients. My goal for these next 4 years and beyond is to not only become a competent dentist, but also a person who is extremely professional and approachable. I want to master all the skills it takes to complete dental school and become a dentist who is confident and efficient. I want to use the knowledge and skills I learn here to further my career in either orthodontics or endodontics.

I hope my experience at NYU college of dentistry molds me into a competent dental professional who can provide the utmost care to my patient. I hope to remain empathetic with my patients and build strong interpersonnal skills which can allow my patients to trust me and my work. Through experience, I hope to improve my hand skills and provide excellent quality care.

Becoming a professional is more than just the DDS title. It goes beyond the workplace and is a public reflection of an individual in society. You are recognized as an individual who is held to higher standards and my actions not only reflect upon me but the dental profession as an entity. For this reason, it is not only to respect ones self but to respect the profession.

A professional is an individual who practices their profession not only in the workplace but their profession is their way of life. They follow a set role of ethics and will oblige by it for the betterment of the community.

As I continue my education, I feel that I learn more and more from every course and every obstacle whether it be big or small. My interactions with patients have taught me how to word my statements, how to ask questions in order to extract important information from patients, and most importantly how important it is to communicate with patients.

I hope to acquire the knowledge to become a dental practitioner, but to also gain the skill set which will allow me to become more competent as a professional. Furthermore, I would like to grow as an ethical individual and be able to provide care to the community by using my acquired knowledge in the dental field. I hope to continue my education post dental school and stay current with my approaches.
NA

I truly believe that my work ethic and determination to do well over the next four years will allow me to become a successful dentist. I need to keep reminding myself over the next 4 years why I am here and what my ultimate goals are. I am extremely interested in orthodontics and hope to build the connections I need to be able to eventually specialize.

After being in clinic and experiencing having patients for the first time, I realized for myself what the importance of professionalism is. Gaining the trust and respect of my patients is an invaluable trait that will be helpful in making the remainder of the treatment go smoothly. By watching the professional mannerisms of the faculty around me when speaking with patients, I have learned and progressed in my role as a healthcare practitioner, and I hope to continue to become better.

Becoming a professional goes hand in hand with being a dentist. Seeing professionalism in a dentist gives patients the confidence to put their health care in your hands and allows for strong patient-doctor relationships to form.  I hope to become a competent professional and build a strong network with other professionals in the health care field to optimize the treatment of my patients, and give me the confidence to refer my patients to someone I have a relationship with.

I believe I have made immense progress as a professional since I have entered dental school. Coming straight from 3 years of undergraduate college, I was young compared to the rest of my class and had very little professional experience. I have learned a lot about what it takes to be a part of a team of healthcare professionals and how to present myself so that my patients and colleagues trust me and the care I am giving them. I know that I have a lot of room to grow and will develop even further as I complete the rest of dental school.

A person's smile is arguably their most important feature.  It is a way to express happiness, show kindness, and has the ability to improve one's own, or even someone else's mood. I believe that being a dentist and giving someone the confidence of a great smile is a highly rewarding and satisfying job that I hope to become competent in over the next four years. This not only includes completing the course work, but also pushing myself to study and learn outside the boundaries of the curriculum to become a health care professional that is able to cooperate and coordinate with others. One thing that I have learned about dental school is that you only get out of it what you put into it, and I want to put my best effort into it. I hope to become a dentist with an influence that is larger than the confines of the office, and is highly involved in local and regional outreach programs.
Edit (9/14/15): After completing 2 years of dental school, my new goals for the remaining time here is to become more confident in the treatment that I provide to my patients. I would like to be able to create a complete treatment plan and have complete confidence that it is the best available option for my patient.

Ethics plays a large role in not only dentistry, but in everyday life. When it comes to patient care, ethical situations come up all of the time. An example would be if a patient would like to get a particular procedure done and we know that it would fail for any number of reasons, it would be best to stick to our professional judgement of not doing the procedure, rather than trying to please the patient. I have noticed that some patients really try to pressure you into doing something that you may not want to do, or pressure you into making the procedure go faster, but it is important for us to take our time and follow all of the steps to avoid making any possible mistakes. At the end of the day, if we follow what we believe to be ethical, we should be able to sleep better at night.

I am still trying to figure out exactly what I would like to do when I become a dentist. I have thought about pediatric dentistry for a while since I have spent so much time working with kids, but I think that solely working with kids might be difficult; especially if the parents are trying to be protective when they see that their child is possibly in pain. I have also thought about oral surgery, but I'm not so sure that I want to be in school for an addition six years after dental school. Now I am currently thinking about going into orthodontics or periodontics, because I can't see myself being satisfied with being a general dentist. I have also thought about going into academia and teaching at a dental school when I graduate; however as of now I think I would like to practice. I have applied to the Periodontics honors program, so I hope to get accepted and to assess whether or not I believe this will be a good fit for me.

Although I have come a long way since D1, I still have a ways to go to get to where I need to be. I have made some progress when it comes to doing class II restorations, but I need a lot more practice and guidance with other procedures such as root canal therapy, as well as fixed and removable prosthodontics. I haven't had many patient experiences yet, but I do feel as though I am starting to get a little better with communicating about what needs to get done. I still have trouble when patient's try to pressure me or when they get upset about hearing that they have to get teeth extracted, but I am slowly trying to progress with the patient care aspect.

When I originally decided that I wanted to become a dentist, I thought I wanted to either become a pediatric dentist or an oral surgeon. When I went for my Master's Degree in Biomolecular Sciences, I began to think about the academic side of dentistry as a profession. I enjoyed doing research and learning about how certain signaling pathways can affect teeth development; I investigating the role of Hedgehog signaling in regulating proliferation in the development of teeth in zebrafish. The research that I might want to do after dental school if I end up becoming a professor would be on oral cancer treatments. I am mostly leaning towards practicing dentistry as a profession, but I want to keep my options open in regards to a career in academia. I hope to continue learning more about the specialties and be able to better decide what will be a good match for me.

There are many patients that have presented into clinic with terrible past experiences with other dentists. They felt cheated, or like they didn't matter and their mouth was a source of income. It bothers me that this is the mentality of some dental professionals. In my current and future practice, I hope to provide my patient with comprehensive care and establish a treatment plan with each patient. I think it's important to stand by what is ethically and morally right, and not just drill and fill and send the patient home. I'm a huge believer in preventative care, and I want to make sure I embody that in my practice. Currently, I'm trying to establish a fundamental set of rules that I will personally follow throughout dental school and the rest of my career that encompasses ethics, professionalism, and the best dental care for my patients.

Over the next four years, I want to focus on becoming an excellent health care provider. I plan on doing so by not only practicing my skills in pre-clinic and clinic, but also by learning how to establish a trusting relationship with my patients. I want to work hard to be a great dentist, but one who exemplifies passion and true dedication to their career. Ultimately, my goal is to specialize in Pediatric dentistry, focusing on children with special needs. I realized my passion while working with a pediatric dentist who saw many children with Autism, Down syndrome, and severe ADHD (amongst other special needs cases). I knew that there would be no feeling more rewarding than helping these kids, many of whom do not have access to dental care. I am incredibly passionate about what I want to do with my career and as a result, I plan on staying active in the Pedo and Special Needs organizations and getting involved in pediatric outreach at NYUCD.

Working as a health care professional comes with many expectations, especially from the patients. They expect you to not only diagnose a particular issue, but treat it as well. They need you to understand their oral health, and explain it to them so they are informed. They trust your decisions in treatment options, and want a proper referral if need be. As a future dentist, I realize how high the bar is raised, and how much of a conscious effort I need to make to ensure that I am meeting my patient’s expectations. I want to understand and appreciate how each case is different, so that I can cater what I know to the specific needs of my future patients. What I've noticed is that each faculty has their own opinion on how to handle a particular case, and it's good to work with one person, do your own research, and establish one game plan that you can relay to the patient with full confidence. Being able to justify why you are doing one procedure over another is important so the patient knows that you are knowledgable and they can trust you.

Working as a health care professional comes with many expectations, especially from the patients. They expect you to not only diagnose a particular issue, but treat it as well. They need you to understand their oral health, and explain it to them so they are informed. They trust your decisions in treatment options, and want a proper referral if need be. As a future dentist, I realize how high the bar is raised, and how much of a conscious effort I need to make to ensure that I am meeting my patient’s expectations. I want to understand and appreciate how each case is different, so that I can cater what I know to the specific needs of my future patients. From being in clinic over the last month, I already see changes in how I treat and speak with patients. I had a differnt demeanor when talking to patient's as an assistant, but the way NYUCD handles patient care and teaches us how to establish trustworthy relationships with our patients, I can say my chair-side manner has definitely changed.

During D2, we took a handful of ethics, diversity, and behavior courses that I literally hated. I thought it was a huge waste of time. When I got into clinic, I realized how helpful and necessary these courses were, because they taught us so much about how to be professional and establish a solid doctor-patient relationship. I've had a great experience so far in clinic being able to communicate with my patients, and a lot of that is due to these classes that I once deemed as useless. I find myself thinking back to what I learned and how I can implement them in my patient care. My professionalism skills have improved so much, and I hope to continue improving them.

Over the next four years, I want to focus on becoming an excellent health care provider. I plan on doing so by not only practicing my skills in pre-clinic and clinic, but also by learning how to establish a trusting relationship with my patients. I want to work hard to be a great dentist, but one who exemplifies passion and true dedication to their career. Ultimately, my goal is to specialize in Pediatric dentistry, focusing on children with special needs. I realized my passion while working with a pediatric dentist who saw many children with Autism, Down syndrome, and severe ADHD (amongst other special needs cases). I knew that there would be no feeling more rewarding than helping these kids, many of whom do not have access to dental care. I am incredibly passionate about what I want to do with my career and as a result, I plan on staying active in the Pedo and Special Needs organizations and getting involved in pediatric outreach at NYUCD.

The road towards becoming a professional is a never ending one. I think that I will always find myself in that road looking towards becoming a better professional than I was yesterday. The word professional contains many principles inside and with the beginning  of the third year I will get to live by these principles on an every day bases.

The road towards becoming a professional is a never ending one. I think that I will always find myself in that road looking towards becoming a better professional than I was yesterday. The word professional contains many principles inside and with the beginning  of the third year I will get to live by these principles on an every day bases.

Being ethical and being professional goes hand in hand especially in the field of dentistry. The dental profession holds a special position of trust amongst our society. Many times in dentistry the decisions we make are no clear right or wrong, there are usually gray areas. There are five fundamental principles that we are taught to follow, patient autonomy, nonmaleficence, beneficence, justice, and veracity. It is important that we abide by these standard of ethics.

There are numerous intriguing factors that interested me in the field of dentistry. This includes the balance of scientific knowledge, decision making, and the precise execution of each case with each patient. However, there are two things that captivated me the most, with the first being that it enforces the importance of “thinking outside of the box”, and being able to envision a new appearance for each patient. This was evident when the treatment options presented to patients and the way each case were handled were different based on the medical history, age and current oral condition of the patients. Secondly, the importance of using perceptual and hands on ability to fulfill that treatment plan. Pursuing a career in dentistry will give me the opportunity to use my knowledge and talent in a field that leaves me feeling accomplished.

When clinic began, professionalism has become more significant as we began seeing patients of different backgrounds (race, sex, age, etc). It is important the way we act inside as well as outside of clinic. Patients view us as professionals and the way we present ourselves is important for us to build that trust and relationship with them.

When clinic began, professionalism has become more significant as we began seeing patients of different backgrounds (race, sex, age, etc). It is important the way we act inside as well as outside of clinic. Patients view us as professionals and the way we present ourselves is important for us to build that trust and relationship with them.

After finishing the second year of dental school, I have recently entered clinic and it is a completely different environment and dynamic than the first two years. Instead of worrying about meeting the grades, now is more about meeting patient expectations and being able to provide the best optimal care for them. It is important to learn from previous mistakes and not commit them again. Unlike making a mistake in lab where I can always re-do the work, now with patients they have an option to not return or find a different provider. Therefore, it is important to minimize mistakes and be able to learn from them if we do make one.

There are numerous intriguing factors that interested me in the field of dentistry. This includes the balance of scientific knowledge, decision making, and the precise execution of each case with each patient. However, there are two things that captivated me the most, with the first being that it enforces the importance of “thinking outside of the box”, and being able to envision a new appearance for each patient. This was evident when the treatment options presented to patients and the way each case were handled were different based on the medical history, age and current oral condition of the patients. Secondly, the importance of using perceptual and hands on ability to fulfill that treatment plan. Pursuing a career in dentistry will give me the opportunity to use my knowledge and talent in a field that leaves me feeling accomplished.
After finally completing second year of dental school and starting clinic I have come to realize the things we have learned the first two years are only the foundation or introduction to what's to come in this career. Everything we do in clinic builds on what was taught in classes. Therefore, to be a fully competent dentist we must build on what we know and add new things to what we have learned.

My progress has been trememdous in the past 2 years. I've grown as a person and more importantly as a professional. With the great responsibility and challenges that dentistry comes with I feel more capable to tackle everything which is thrown my way.

I begin my time here at NYUCD with the hope to become a competent and successful dentist, through my work to eventually help others while being a positive role model and lastly to grow as a person and lead a balance life. I am certain that the road towards achieving my goals will be difficult but I feel prepared for the challenges ahead. The next four year will fly by and hopefully I look back on my time here as great experience that formed me as person.

Ethics are moral principles or virtues that govern the character and conduct of an individual. As a dental professional ethics are our moral duties towards our patients and colleagues. Putting the patients' interests as priority, explaining the patient about the treatment plan, treating people without any discrimination, maintaining patient confidentiality and having a truthful communication are some of the important aspects of ethical behavior in health care. Inculcating valueslike being courteuos, empathic and humble towards my patients has helped me in developing a strong rapport with my patients.

There are certain instances in our lives which play a very important role in shaping our future. My fascination towards dentistry began when I was a teenager, I saw my grandmother in great agony due to toothache. We took her to a dentist who examined her and diagnosed the caries involvement of her tooth. He prescribed her some medicines and then carried out the appropriate treatment. As the treatment progressed, my grandmother was relieved of her pain and for this reason dentist appeared like a magician with a magical wand, who brought back smile on her face. This incident introduced a spark in me and motivated me to pursue my career in dentistry. The zeal to learn more and having access to some of the best faculty in world at NYUCD has definitely helped in becoming a better individual both professionally and personally.

Apart from being an empathic and trustworthy provider, its very important to maintain professional knowledge and competence. As a comprehensive provider we should be able to explain the complete treatment plan to the patient and should have the potential to convince the patient to accept it.  Since patients at NYUCD are from different cultural and socioeconomic background, its very important to understand the patient's concerns regarding their health, availability and finances. Figuring out these smaller details about the patients helps in managing the patients in a better way and at the same time patients tend to develop respect and trust for their dentist.

Professional etiquette is one of the most important factors contributing to a successful healthcare career. Our profession involves many personal interactions with a variety of people. Professionalism in dentistry is all about establishing respectable relationships with patients and colleagues. As health care professionals we have a huge responsibility of meeting up patient expectations. As comprehensive providers we need to put the patients' interests on the top and respect their dignity and choices.

My journey began with joining a dental school in my home country, attaining a degree(BDS), working with some of the renowned dentists in different fields both in India and United States and finally pursuing DDS at NYUCD and coming out as a competent professional admission in NYUCD and working towards getting DDS degree and coming out as a competent professional. Over the years I have seen tremendous progress in my professional career through my experiences with different professionals who helped me understand various aspects of dentistry and the emerging trends in this field. Being a part of research at UCLA widened my horizon of knowledge and gave me real insight into the field of research. Also I believe I have become more empathic and compassionate towards my patients and able to interact very comfortably with people from different ethnicities and cultures which has instilled a sense of confidence in me.

Entering a dental school and getting an undergraduate degree in dentistry has been like a dream come true for me. Having the ability of giving people a hearty and vibrant smile and giving a healing touch to those in pain, has always fascinated me to pursue the field of dentistry. I feel fortunate to be part of NYUCD and achieve my goal of being a Competent Dentist and to be able to learn about diverse cultures and ethnicity.

I am here to be the best that I can be. That being said I hold myself to the highest of standards. I contribute this to my upbringing filled with morals and values and I thank my parents for instilling these life lessons at a young age. Because of this my transition into dental school has been made easy. This is because the things that violate integrity do not tempt me. Everyday I strive to be the best and I will not suffice to take shortcuts that may impact my reputation and or career. I feel that I have a strong backbone when it comes to ethic dilemmas and usually know the right thing to do. Dental school has augmented my understanding of what it means to be ethical and I will continue to grow and stay ethically competent.

Becoming a professional is not only important to me but it is necessary in the health care setting. Integrity and autonomy are the two descriptive words that come to mind when thinking of the word professional. In becoming a health care professional it is an absolute must for one to possess integrity. First, integrity provides the basis of truthfulness and consistency that patients and other healthcare professionals can learn to rely on. Next, every professional must have the ability to self-assess and govern one’s own actions. This is where autonomy comes into play. A professional knows his limitations because he is independent, however in knowing his limitations he simply knows as a professional he is able to ask for assistance through referring or consulting other health care providers. I will become a health care professional, although, the only way I will get there is through maintaining my integrity and knowing when to ask for assistance through being able to refer my patients when needed.

My professional progress has been a journey filled with many great experiences and I have continued to do my best to in order to become the best.  Everyday I continue to learn and absorb as much as I possibly can. Through my time here I have also learned the importance and how to maximize my time. In addition, this process has taught me the essence of self-study. It is because of this ability that I feel NYU has provided me with an outstanding education. Not only do I continue to learn everyday while in dental school but I now have the ability to bring this this rewarding skillset into private practice. From the first day of clinic I was eager to treat patients and after being in the clinic for several months I now feel competent in providing the rudimentary of care and I cannot wait to enhance my clinical abilities.

“I am here to become the absolute best health-care provider. That being said I will not settle for meeting the benchmark I will inspire to surpass being average. “ This quote of mine from the first year of dental school still holds true and has not changed. However, many things have changed since the time I wrote my first personal statement. To start with I have not only learned an exceptional amount didactically, I have continued to learn new things about myself.  As a result, my future path has been redefined. Starting dental school I was extremely interested in Oral Surgery. My interest for this field still holds, although taking into consideration life goals and work-life balances other areas of dentistry have become more apparent. The field of endodontics seems to be the front-runner. Looking back at my first personal statement I have not changed the things liked about OS but have only added to the list. For instance I’m still passionate about research, surgery, and becoming a specialist but have now learned to incorporate personal goals and career goals in my professional decisions.

Dentistry is a science and an art, whose success is derived from understanding that patients are the number one priority. Becoming a dental professional encompasses all of that. As a dental health professional I think it is imperative to provide exceptional care no matter what procedure the might be from a complete exam and cleaning, a full-mouth restoration, or anything in between.

As a dental health professional, I want to be confident as a skilled clinician and take pride in providing the care patients need to keep their smile healthy. To give our patients the best possible service and results. I am always committed to continuous education and learning. I truly believe that top-notch care delivered in a warm, personalized environment is what makes the difference between good and great dentist; therefore, I want to able to fuse the clinical with the personal in order to achieve superior clinical results along with long-lasting patient relationships.

I have not really had a situation yet in which I felt that I had an ethical dilemma. Luckily, so far my patients have been pretty easy to work with, and so are the faculty. I keep doing my best to treatment plan effectively keeping in mind the needs of the patient and doing no harm.

As I delve deeper into clinic I start seeing that they did not teach us enough upstairs in lab. Of course we learned some of the basics, but overall I feel as if I am starting from the beginning. The denture process here is a little different, doing operative feels different in real teeth, and just generally the way I sit with patients feels different from a typodont. I do have to say that I have little trouble communicating with my patients, and j feel as if j am able to effectively work with both the faculty and the patients. I really enjoy the clinical work, I was terrified of root canals but after doing my first one I realize that as long as I'm careful and follow all the steps, it should work out. I look forward to learning more and more!

I am finding it pretty easy working with the faculty in the clinic. They are very helpful as long as I am prepared and have some idea of what I am doing. My peers are also good to work with, I have already learned so much from the upperclassmen and even from my own class! I think everyone is helpful and willing to work with us and teach us the ways of dentistry. I try to maintain my professionalism in how I dress, speak to others and carry myself. I always try to make a good impression, but still stay true to my own personality.

I expect to master the didactic material and develop as a comprehensive and respected professional. I want to service the community in a positive and formative way through outreach both domestically and overseas. I hope to develop greater confidence in the clinical setting, both in my interactions with patients and in the quality of my work. I would like to have a firm grasp on the concepts applicable to the most common dental procedures and be able to articulate the risks and benefits of work performed to my patients.

Becoming a professional is a process that not only begins at the beginning of dental school but is continued on throughout our lives as dentistry is an ever-changing, always evolving field. Although I am not comfortable seeing patients right now because of my little operative knowledge and procedural skills, I am always willing to learn what can make me a better professional in the eyes of a patient.

Now that I have been in clinic for a few months, I have really begun the process of becoming a professional by actually practicing the procedures I have learned in pre-clinical lab on actual patients. It is an exciting journey yet it is stressful at times. I look forward to what the next two years have in store for me.

As I am entering my D3 year, I realize that my goals as a student at NYUCD didn't change.  However, as I started treating real patients,  the meaning of being a professional became less of an amorphous ideal, and more of a real challenge. At this point in my career, besides the medical aspect of the profession, I noticed that I have to put greater effort into my communication skills when interacting with patients, faculty, and my classmates. I accept the challenge as an honor, and am doing my best to be successful at it. My primary goal is to provide the best dental care to my patients, while learning and growing along the way.

To learn how to maintain a standard of excellence amongst the dental community that translates into leadership amidst the progression of dentistry. To master my role in the patient-doctor relationship, for the efficient benefit of my growth as a healthcare provider and the improvement of overall patient health.To fully understand all specialties of dentistry and the compliment between them to a degree that allows me to make an educated, prepared, and appropriate decision on which aspect of dentistry is suited best for me. To identify deficiencies amongst communities worldwide and how to meet those needs effectively.

To learn how to maintain a standard of excellence amongst the dental community that translates into leadership amidst the progression of dentistry.
      
      To master my role in the patient-doctor relationship, for the efficient benefit of my growth as a healthcare provider and the improvement of overall patient health.
      
      To fully understand all specialties of dentistry and the compliment between them to a degree that allows me to make an educated, prepared, and appropriate decision on which aspect of dentistry is suited best for me.
      
      To identify deficiencies amongst communities worldwide and how to meet those needs effectively.

I have enjoyed seeing patients in clinic. l more comfortable with Axium than I was back in July and am getting more used to the clinic environment. There have been a lot of firsts and with each day I am becoming more confident in my clinical skills. I still have a lot to learn and am looking forward to getting more clinical experience at NYU and also on the NYUCD Nepal Global Outreach trip.

There is a big difference between didactically learning about ethics versus applying ethical principles in the clinic setting where my decisions impact the lives and health of living human beings. It is a humbling experience to understand and appreciate the impact dentistry has on patients, their health and their self esteem. I have worked towards making ethics a top priority so as to always do what is in the best interest of my patients.

My clinical experience so far has been a juggling experience managing patients, appointments, roster maintenance, etc. However, I feel lucky to be learning all aspects of dentistry, clinical and managerial, because this will make me competent and efficient at practice management in private practice.

I am finally in clinic! The big day came a few months ago, and I could not be happier and more excited. It is such a rewarding experience working with patients and helping them one smile at a time. I am nearing on three quarters of completion of dental school, and time has flied! I have experienced myself develop from a sleep-walking dental student running from systems pathology to sim lab to a budding oral health care provider.

I am about three and a half years into the beautiful community at NYUCD, and I could not be more proud of my colleagues and I. After trekking through the rigorous curriculum in D1 and D2, we have finally embarked on the journey of clinic. Having spent almost one semester in clinic, I am finding myself developing into the oral health care provider I have always envisioned myself to become.

With knowledge comes more power. I was once told knowledgable people are the most dangerous and I partially believe that statement. Many people teetered the line of ethics to get into dental school, and no doubt some will continue to do so will throughout school. I do hope that this teetering of the ethical boundary will not bleed into other areas, especially when the time comes to manage patients.

School is a priority, always is. But I must keep in mind why I chose this school and why I chose to live in this city. I accepted the rare opportunity to live in NYC during my youth and I need to take advantage of what this city can offer me.

Started training jiu jitsu, and have been dedicating more and more time to training. I think its a good balance that I need to help me get thru school.

My attempts to keep my schedule full have been futile. Although I have patients on my roster, the needs of my patients at the moment do not keep me busy.

I've worked quite hard to dig myself out of the hole I was in. Now I get to start fresh with a clean slate. This is a new beginning, but I can't forget what I sacrificed to get here. I am no longer doing this just for myself anymore.

Becoming a professional is a long and hard process. It does not only involve learning the theory behind the work but also how to act and maintain the responsibilities of a professional. To become a professional means to develop a network of other professionals in order to successfully treat those in your care.

The white coat ceremony was a big milestone in becoming a professional. It was a very significant step, indicating that I will be treating patients in the near future and I have much more responsibility.

I want to pass boards on first try. Stay friendly, easy going, and personable so that others may reach out to me if they have the wild idea to do so. I want to be competent and professional when dealing and treating patients. To develop good bedside manners. Have impact on teens/children not only in local areas but internationally too. I want to find my niche in my class, the school of dentistry and in my profession.

As time progresses, I am slowly becoming more comfortable with my classmates and have found a group to study/hang out with. I realized that there are too many people in our class to know on an intimate level so I devote my energy where I feel is  needed.

The second year is a different ball game compared to first. It takes quite a bit of determination and stamina to get through the constant barrage of exams and practicals. I have a feeling that fall semester is a warm up for spring.

The transition into clinic has been relatively smooth. I realized that I must always be prepared ahead of time to provide adequate treatment.

It is my own responsibility to be honest to ourselves, to the faculty, and most importantly to the patients. As a student doctor, I understand that I need to treat patients as a whole, not just their teeth. I would also keep in mind to always have respect to the patients' decisions and treat comprehensively for the benefit of patients' health. Also I need to ensure all patient information will be kept in privacy.

I expect to become very comfortable interacting with patients in the next few months of my introduction into clinic. I find myself having forgotten many of the small facts we once learned in a lecture setting, and I need a little extra time to brush up on all of my background knowledge before completing procedures.

As stated, I need to put forth more effort in dressing and styling my hair more professionally. I think I act professionally toward my faculty, peers and patients, but it's also difficult to judge myself in this manner.

To me becoming a professional means presenting myself in a way that makes patients comfortable with trusting me with their (oral) health. I believe that I am improving in this aspect. My weaknesses include dressing professionally and projecting confidence, which I believe is important to patients of an educational institution.

Upon completion of dental school, I expect to be proficient in the classroom material and chair-side skills taught to me by the NYUCD faculty. Through development of cohesive relationships in clinics, I can best prepare myself to begin a dental career. I am determined to polish my professional skills for peer and patient interaction. Most importantly, I plan to enjoy my time in dental school and to provide the care and attention that my husband and son need.

In the next four years in NYUCD I want to not only have the knowledge of dentistry but, also be able to apply in in every step along the way. I want to know not only the standard procedures, but also alternative ways as different situations may come up. I want to provide professional care while being able to comfort the patient. I want to be able to work in every field/specialty of dentistry although I do want to specialize. I also plan on participating in many clubs and as many outreach programs as I can. I want to network with many different dental and medical professionals to be able to give patients the ultimate care. I want to be successful student as well as a successful health care provider.

Becoming a professional is something that doesn't happen overnight. Professionals to me are those people that have a strong foundation of knowledge and master the skills and techniques of a specific trade. They have specific training in their field and are admired or trusted by the public to perform their that job for which they are trained. A professional is someone who acts according to ethical standards and abides to a set of specific legal guidelines. Working to become a professional will require devotion of many hours, days, weeks and years practicing my craft. I hope to become a trusted dental practitioner and the best professional I can be.

Over the next four years I hope to grow as a person. I want to learn and develop the skills I need in order to give the best possible care to all my future patients.  I hope to build and develop strong interpersonal relationships with my peers, faculty and future patients. I also hope to learn more about other cultures and ways of life to be able to better understand and communicate with a diverse patient population. I plan to become active within the College of Dentistry as well as the New York City community.

After being in clinic for a few months, I have learned a lot about communication and patient care.  It is sometimes hard for me to explain to patients why they may need a certain procedure, and I also know I need to work on clarity.  I am also hoping that before May of 2017 I have gained more confidence.  This has always been an issue for me in my professional life, but I've never had to worry about the care of another person before.  Patient care and comfort is a big issue for me; I never want one of my patients to think I don't have compassion for them.  As the year goes on and I am exposed to more patients, treatment plans, and procedures I hope I will slowly gain some more confidence.

It has been a couple of months that I've been in clinic full time with considerable number of patients in hand. The first few weeks, I was catching up with the clinic rules and steps to basic patient care. It has been full of new lessons and adjustments to such drastic change in learning environment, from didactic to clinical setting. One thing that I've been continuously trying to do was to focus on the patient's well-being and empathy towards them even in rather confusing and hectic moments of adapting to the clinic. I believe I will have to continuously remind myself to keep putting the patient as the first priority, throughout my career even beyond the school. Another thing that really struck me throughout the first few months is the importance of comprehensive and thorough treatment planning. Before actually seeing patients, I thought that technicality was the major part of patient care. Now I see that good and solid treatment plan is required to support whatever clinical technique I may use on a patient. I am trying to work with faculties from different specialty backgrounds to grasp the bigger picture of interdisciplinary efforts for each case.

Ethics is not merely a course, but a lifelong dedication to upholding the standards and principals of the profession. Everyday, every lab session, and in every lecture, the fundamentals of approaching patient based clinical treatment to our patient population in a moral, and ethical manner are fostered and promoted. Moreover, a course such as ethics is not merely a class for students. It is an ideal and standard for everyone apart of the institution to uphold and better. Ethics starts from the top down, and without a systemic dedication to practicing our institution in a ethical approach, all is moot.

D3 has now officially begun and I am very excited to be transitioning into a clinical setting. With every day and session that passes, I learn more through my experiences with patients. How to treatment plan, as well as how to assess patient health statuses is a fundamental skill I am shaping every day. I am focusing up my mental capacities again, after a recharging June, to tackle board exam preparations. I look forward to continue working with my clinic faculty and staff to continue expanding my proficiency!

While managing patients and treatment plans brings with it a new concept and feeling of "stress," I can tangibly feel myself becoming more skilled and competent with every passing week in clinic. My Oral Surgery clinic rotation in September opened my eyes to the world of tooth extractions and post-op instructions. I genuinely can say that I enjoyed the process of extracting a tooth, along with the physical act of luxating and forcep-ing them out. I hope my rotations further along the year are as stimulating. I also hope my patients continue to come with vigor as the weather turns cold.

To me, becoming a healthcare professional is very exciting. For one, it is a position worthy of respect and admiration. I will be a leader in my community, a person capable of administering real and positive improvements. As cliche as it may sound, I will be in a position to help people who are in pain, often times in the matter of one office visit. Becoming a professional means a great deal to myself and my family, but above all, doing so means accepting the responsibilities- both positive and risky- that come along with being a leader. I am also looking forward to becoming a more active board member of my club, the Dental Economics Club. I believe this will be a big year to throughly explore the club's mission statement

As D2 is progressing towards its end, I find myself feeling more confident and competent in my abilities. With clinic hours now a real part of my schedule, and with it the induction of patients, things are for lack of a better phrase, getting real. I feel motivated, self induced pressure, to take my didactic courses with more vigor, as the concepts in them are now seen in a light beyond just test questions. I am trying to tie together all the ends, to get as best prepared for the clinical portion of dental school, and I cannot wait to get there.

I hope to build up my clinical proficiency as best and, ideally, quickly as possible in my four years at NYUCD. Personally, I seek to mature to the extent of finding and maintaining a standard of professionalism and excellence that I may bring to my patients on a daily basis. Finally, I look forward to utilizing my large class size by approaching it as an opportunity to network with as many peers and future colleagues as I can (delve into the existingNYUCD alumni base if possible).

I feel that Dr. More's ethics course in the past 2 years definitely helped me to understand the ethics that I as a dentist should be fully aware of. Dr. More really delved into details that I didn't know before and his examples helped me to really understand what could have been an abstract concept.

Although I know the next 4 years at NYUCD will be rigorous and tough, I still hope to have a lot of fun and build wonderful relationships with faculty members and my peers. I don't plan to specialize, but I would like to participate in research that helps to improve the oral health of our society and to keep up with the rapidly advancing science and technology. I also hope to participate in one of the outreach programs offered at NYUCD to bring awareness to our community how important oral health is and also to appreciate all the wonderful opportunities and resources that I have. I want to gain enough experience and knowledge in dentistry so that I can be prepared to professionally work with various patients and cases on my own.

As of entering D1, there are more areas that I am not competent in than in areas that I am. There will be many obstacles and struggles along the way, but I am not afraid to make mistakes and I will try to learn as much as possible from the mistakes that I made so that I will not repeat them again. I believe that gaining a plenty of experience and knowledge is a key to becoming a competent and professional healthcare provider and I hope to reach that by the end of the 4 years at NYUCD.

I hope to be a competent and professional healthcare provider who is capable of communicating with her patients in an effective and understandable manner. I hope to feel more confident in carrying out challenging tasks that I may face in the future with my patients by gaining enough experience and knowledge in dentistry during the 4 years at NYUCD.

I can confidently say that I have improved a lot as a healthcare professional in the past two years at NYUCD. Of course, there are still a lot more to learn, but I feel more competent especially through different lab courses which taught me to perform various procedures from restoration to crown preparation. I hope I will be more ready by the end of D2 before I enter the clinic and I will seek every opportunity to improve my hand skills.

By the end of 4 years at NYUCD, I hope to be a professional and competent dentist who is not only able to carry out any challenging procedure proficiently, but also an approachable healthcare provider who her patients can trust and rely on. Not only do I wish to be successful academically, but I also hope to build wonderful relationships with faculty members and fellow classmates.

In dental school and my future career in dentistry, I strive for continual self-improvement and forward development. I will apply my previous volunteer experiences, along with my newfound knowledge to interact and connect with patients on a personal level. Moreover, the strong clinical training that NYUCD offers will enable me to provide exceptional oral healthcare with the highest proficiency and quality. I aim to embody the mindset that dentists are not only healthcare providers, but also trusted members of society - viewed as companions and advisors. I know that this profession requires much more than academic excellence; it involves manual dexterity skills, attention to detail, critical thinking, and the communication skill set required to educate patients on the significance of oral care and hygiene. My contributions to society will not be limited to providing outstanding oral healthcare services to the general public, as I intend to broaden my scope of care to aid the less fortunate populations. I strongly believe that NYUCD will provide me with the opportunities to gain experience through outreach programs. NYUCD is my avenue towards achieving my goals. I am focused and ready to begin.

The first two years of dental school have been challenging however, for the most part I have found it to be enjoyable. Reflecting back to when I first started dental school, I was unsure of whether or not dentistry was for me. Having gone through these two years I now know for sure that I have picked the right career.

My goal at NYUCD is to become a competent dentist. In order to achieve this goal I will need to develop my interpersonal skills so that I can treat patients to the best of my ability. Furthermore, I would like to develop a support network of both peers and faculty with the hope that they can help me accomplish my goal. Lastly, I hope to develop the technical skills required to be a competent dentist.

When faced with an ethical dilemma, I will perform all the steps necessary in order to be an ethical dental professional and human being. I will continuously evaluate myself as well as seek out peer evaluations in order to ensure that I am doing everything that I can to make ethical choices.
NA

I strongly believe that accumulating as much relevant knowledge as possible is an essential part of being an excellent dental provider. However, I believe that there are many more important characteristics that one must possess in order to become a professional dental provider. In addition to being knowledgable, a professional must also be accountable, compassionate, respectful, and much more. I strive to be a provider who is all of these things and someone that society can count on to help them make well-informed decisions about their oral health.
I will continue to learn and develop as a professional well beyond graduating dental school. I believe that learning is a continuous process and strive to be better every day.

Through dedicated studying and practicing, I see myself as a dental practitioner who not only treats patients on a daily basis, but also as one who teaches and empowers them to make choices that will impact their oral health in a positive way. I have a  I am excited for the opportunities to learn, meet new people, and give back to my community.

Being a professional in the dental field has many components; it requires compassion, technical excellence, clinical knowledge, and the ability to know what's best for patients and execute it in the most effective way possible. Through didactic courses as well as clinical, hands-on experience, I will be able to learn what is the best course of treatment for my patients. Working with my peers in this journey will help me become a professional, as dentistry requires collaboration and teamwork between peers. Dental school will help me practice and develop these skills, and enable me to become a competent professional. I feel that I've learned so much from my first year and second years, not only in didactic courses but also in learning how to work with others on our journey to becoming dental professionals. Now as a D3 and entering clinic, I'm really looking forward to more patient interaction and actually getting to practice my professional skills, in working with patients, faculty, and my fellow students.

My goal is to become an excellent clinical dentist by developing my manual dexterity, learning how to communicate effectively with my patients and learning to make the best decisions in their individual treatment. I aim to be very involved in the NYU community, in order to develop meaningful relationships with faculty members and peers, and be an active, contributing participant in our collective dental school journey. I will challenge myself in learning as much as I can in the basic medical sciences, as this will help me provide excellent, whole-body centered care to my patients. I would also like to get more involved in volunteering in my community, and helping to address the lack of access to care in dentistry.
