I plan on learning Implantology in the 4th year. At this stage of dentistry, I feel that I have so much to learn in the other departments. Out of these departments, I feel that I am most competent in cariology, and least competent in Prosthodontics. I plan on working on my weaknesses so that I can become a general dentist that has the ability to complete procedures in all of the dental programs. I am excited and eager for the upcoming year.

As a third year I plan on taking advantage of the DDS program at NYU. So far the clinical experience in the first semester of D3 has been a very educational one. I have learned so much in each different specialty. I have becoming very interested in Implantology. I plan on learning more in my fourth year in this department. Understanding the bigger picture of dentistry has become more of a passion than a profession. Approaching each patient for the best treatment has so many variables and roadblocks. I plan on learning how to approach complex dental patients with the understanding of phasing and efficicent treatment planning.

I have not had any ethical dilemmas as of yet, and I consider myself lucky. Many times it is easy to know what is right from what is wrong when it comes to treating patients; do what is best for the patient. However, the line may be blurred when what is best for the patient isn't what the patient wants. I must always keep in mind that I can only provide care which I deem as the best possible option for the patient, and to defer treatment if I'm not able to provide the appropriate level of care.

Dental school is challenging in many respects, not just academically. Over the last two years I've had to put in more work in the library and in lab than at any other point in my life. Tough as it may be it has been a tremendous learning experience for me. I had to learn to balance school and my own personal life in a manner which I never had to before. In the past there was always plenty of time for leisure but dental school didn't allow any time for idling. It hasn't been easy keeping up my personal relationships and maintaining good academic standing and though it has been a challenge I'm proud of myself that I've been able to make it this far.

In the eyes of the public I am a healthcare professional but I still feel like a kid at times. Sometimes it's hard to take myself seriously and I can't believe that other people are willing to defer to me for their oral healthcare. When I'm in the clinic I put my best game face on and try to treat patients with the utmost respect, as a professional should. I'm always looking out for my patient's best interests and I think as long as I keep that in mind, I won't have any trouble developing into a successful healthcare professional.

It's only recently that the public has begun to view me as a professional as clinic has only started a few months ago. It was strange at first, being in a position of power and actually being an expert on the topic of dentistry while talking to my patients. They place their trust in me and believe me to have all the knowledge when it comes to anything related to the oral cavity. I do find that I'm much more comfortable now talking to patients about their oral healthcare needs than I was even a few months ago. Being a healthcare provider is a huge responsibility and it is only now dawning on me the extent of what it means to be a professional.

I'm starting to learn that I really enjoy the doctor patient interaction and that I love working in the clinic. I look forward to going into clinic everyday with the possibility of learning something new with every interaction. There were times when I doubted that dentistry was the field for me as I struggled in lab to do a proper class II preparation but being able to talk to patients and to use my knowledge to make a difference in their lives has been nothing short of great.

I want to make the most of the time I spend here at NYUCD by learning as much as possible both inside the classroom and outside of it. I think that to become a great dental professional requires the skills forged through hours of practice inside a simulation lab and the knowledge attained from sitting through countless hours in a lecture classroom. But I also think that to become a great dental professional one must learn the art of patient interaction and this can only be done outside of the classroom, in the real world.

Beyond a career in dentistry I hope to be able to continue becoming a well rounded individual in all aspects of my professional and personal life. I think it is very inspirational when I come across professors that have lived such interesting lives and have great stores to tell. I still really like the appeal of being a general dentist and being able to do many different procedures throughout the day. However though perio assisting this summer, I starting to develop a real interest in perio, such as the surgical aspect of this specialty.

The past two years have really provided a good didactic foundation to build upon in clinic. The labs we have done have allowed us to prepare restorations, RPD, complete dentures, crown preps, address aesthetic concerns etc. Classes like DOD have introduced us to oral pathologies we may encounter and various oral and systemic diseases. I'm excited to add upon this knowledge in clinic and in subsequent courses to properly treatment plan and treat cases when addressing patient needs.

My private personal statement echo's all that I stated publicly, with the addition that at this time I have no intention on specializing. I do however now have more interest in doing a year of residency after graduation in order to get further opportunities to complete procedures I was unable to in school and hone my skills before venturing out on my own.
I also have an interest in pursuing an honours program while at NYU in my 4th year

Reflecting upon my first two years of dental school, I can pin point many times that ethical standards came into play. The first year of dental school was plagued by many cheating issues within our class which test our moral grounds and how we live up to them. Often times, we would have upperclassmen share previous exams and study sheets and it was our decision to distribute them to create a level playing ground when it was exam day. During second year, we saw many of our classmates going to all distances to succeed on practicals and competencies, whether that meant bringing pre-prepared teeth or drilling outside the mouth. It was up to us whether we approach our classmates and challenge their moral standards.

I would love to develop my skills in working with pediatric patients. I enjoy working with children and had been a private tutor working with elementary and junior high school children for many years before dental school. For the past few years, I have been shadowing in the pediatrics department to learn more regarding the special ways that a dentist must attend to pediatric patients. It is crucial that the dentist work well not just with the child but additionally with the parents, who are a crucial part of the child's treatment since they help with maintaining the dental work.

I hope to develop into a competent professional throughout my experiences at the dental school. A professional is not merely one who knows the procedures and tools of his trades, a professional must also act his part and be able to communicate his duties to his patients. By observing the interactions and relationships between the dentists and the patients in the clinic, I hope to be able to observe and mirror the relationships I see. 
Community outreach further develops one into a professional because one is responsible in representing his entire field and line of work. Being able to develop successful relationships with the community is crucial to ones success in future practice.

I have seen myself develop as a professional throughout my first two years of dental school. I have volunteered in clinic and assisted on the board examination. I am learning how to take in information and put it all together so that I will be able to present it to my patients in clinic. I have learned how to interpret literature which is an essential skill as a professional because it is always a balance of either "buying in" to what literature is saying or taking it with a grain of salt.

As an aspiring dentist, I would like to ensure that I am professional and competent at performing dental procedures in a timely and nearly flawless manner. I would like to maintain a clear path of communication with patients and attempt to destroy the stigma of a dental visit being a scary, and ruthless experience. I would like to serve my community by volunteering my services and encouraging people to seek dental care not only during urgent situations but making it a routine part of life as a preventative measure. I understand that the financial aspect of dentistry may prevent some from receiving treatment and I seek to provide some services at a reduced cost to those at need, 
            	As members of the same field, interactions between professionals will be  vital to our success in the field.  One of the most important relationships in my future will be between myself and my patients. I would like to ensure that they will be fully comfortable with me performing dental procedures. Over the next years, I will observe many different patient-doctor interactions and learn the best ways to ease the fear of patients.

I have learned a lot about the ethical and moral dilemmas that face practicing dentists. The classes taught by Dr. More has helped us in realizing that one must consider all options for ethical situations, and do whats best for the patient. Monetary gains can drive the greed of many already practicing dentists in the world today, but one must do whats best for our patients in order to be the best dentist possible. I look forward to experiencing more of these dilemmas that may surface while working in the clinic with patients. As part of the Student Professionalism and Ethics Association I have learned a great deal more in meetings with dentists about real life ethical scenarios and how to handle them properly.

Going forward in dental school I aim to be able to deliver comprehensive dental care to a variety of communities and improve myself professionally as well as clinically. I will strive to be engaged in the school student body as well the city around us and utilize the peer and mentor resources available to augment my abilities as a student and a future dentist. In the future I hope to be able to practice as a general dentist, providing preventative and therapeutic care as well as instilling healthy dental practices in my future patient's lives.

My experiences through three years of dental school so far have guided me in the right path to becoming a well rounded dental professional. The self assessments and peer assessments that we do allow me to see points of improvement for myself and direct me to how I need to gain the empathy, ethics, and skills needed. Working in both the pre-clinical and clinical settings with my GPD group has allowed me to foster great working relationships with my colleagues and build a sense of camaraderie and teamwork. Going through experiences with actual patients makes me be able to realize how I've improved or gained professional skills. I can now see that my communication skills with patients has drastically improved as well as my hand skills and critical thinking.

My experiences through three years of dental school so far have guided me in the right path to becoming a well rounded dental professional. The self assessments and peer assessments that we do allow me to see points of improvement for myself and direct me to how I need to gain the empathy, ethics, and skills needed. Working in both the pre-clinical and clinical settings with my GPD group has allowed me to foster great working relationships with my colleagues and build a sense of camaraderie and teamwork. Going through experiences with actual patients makes me be able to realize how I've improved or gained professional skills. I can now see that my communication skills with patients has drastically improved as well as my hand skills and critical thinking.

I feel as though I have grown a lot through dental school thus far in a multitude of ways. I have strived to be a person/dentist that is well rounded in regards to academic excellence, clinical skills, and communication skills. I believe that these three aspects are critical for a successful dentist to have. I feel as though I have improved in each one of these areas since I have been in dental school and that as time goes along, I will be able to be fully well rounded in each of those regards.

Going forward in dental school I aim to be able to deliver comprehensive dental care to a variety of communities and improve myself professionally as well as clinically. I will strive to be engaged in the school student body as well the city around us and utilize the peer and mentor resources available to augment my abilities as a student and a future dentist. In the future I hope to be able to practice as a general dentist, providing preventative and therapeutic care as well as instilling healthy dental practices in my future patient's lives.

Trust, ethics, morals, and values are integral part of a good society. As a oral health care provider, we are responsible to stick onto the highest norms of trust, ethics, morals, and values. These will build a good relationship between us and patients and other members of society or community. I would keep up these above aspects in my life and maintain them to the highest norms.

I would like to treat patients with utmost care, respect, and compassion. I would like to deliver best treatment possible to them considering their overall health, social and financial conditions. I would also like to take responsibility to bring awareness in the community. We need to work as a team rather than an individual to bring about change in the masses. I will put my best to treat patients. I have taken and will also take every feedback positively to help for my better professional and personal growth. I grew with an attitude that, learning is never ending. This attitude in me will help me grow professionally and personally.

I feel that growing professionally is growing not only just in terms of education, but also in terms of behavior and attitude. It is a responsibility of us as a professional, to helps others who are seeking for help.

A professional is responsible to deliver his/her tasks effectively and efficiently in whatever profession s/he is into. A professional is not just responsible to deliver tasks, but should also represent their profession the best way possible. A professional should also be responsible for society to help the society. I hope I would keep up and maintain the same professionalism.

To any professional, each day should be a learning day. A person who thinks that s/he knows everything and doesn't need to learn anymore, has stopped growing professionally and instead, is bringing more harm to himself and also to the community. We need to stick to the highest standards of code of ethics to bring respect to our profession and to show the utmost professionalism.

I believe that, "prevention is better than cure", I am committed to help patients understand the importance of overall oral health and their role in their oral health. I am confident that I will be able to learn more knowledge about recent treatment options, techniques, and also learn skills which are essential for a dentist to become successful. I always provided and would like to provide a compassionate care to patients as I would like my family to be treated by others. I always believe that there is a lot more out there to learn in dentistry. I would take constructive criticism to improve and to become a better person. I believe that an opportunity to make a difference in others life and bring smile on their faces is most fulfilling and rewarding.

Following our ethics course with Dr. More, I believe that ethics and ethical decisions are very important not only in a classroom setting, but also in a clinical setting and most importantly, in my dental practice once I graduate. I believe in honesty and following the rules. Although students are often inclined to take no action when witnessing unethical actions, I hope to be able to step forward and confront the student personally. Although I would not be comfortable in involving the peer review board or faculty, I hope I can at least address the student. Most importantly, I hope to be able to follow all rules while here at NYUCD and not make unethical decisions in the classroom and towards my patients. I believe providing the best possible health care is important and I hope to make only ethical and sound decisions when it involves my patients and peers.

These past two years at NYU have really taught me a lot about myself. During D1 I was able to completely focus on the didactic courses and I felt that I was excelling. However, D2 was such a struggle for me. Having to balance classwork and lab work turned out to be really difficult for me. I realized that although I did well in the didactic courses, I was struggling with lab. Failing CR1 turned out to be a blessing in disguise for me. I was so disappointed in myself at first, but it really showed me that I need to spend so much more time in lab and not be afraid to ask for help. I think that experience has made me more comfortable in clinic with asking my peers and faculty for help. With my first pulp exposure last week, I really learned that things happen in clinic and lab and you just have to make the best of each situation even if it is not what you initially had intended for!

To me, becoming a professional and being professionally competent in the field of dentistry means being a well-rounded individual. Professionals have a thorough understanding and knowledge of dentistry and sufficient experience in the clinical setting to be able to treat patients. Professionals have learned the appropriate ways to treat patients, peers, and colleagues and do their best to provide the best possible oral health care to others. They are well-educated and have performed well in not only a classroom setting, but also in their pre-clinic and clinic rotations. Professionally competent individuals are honest, ethical, and hard workers. Most importantly, becoming a professional in the field of dentistry means putting my patients first. I hope to be able to accomplish these goals after graduating NYUCD and becoming a professional.

To me, becoming a professional and being professionally competent in the field of dentistry means being a well-rounded individual. Professionals have a thorough understanding and knowledge of dentistry and sufficient experience in the clinical setting to be able to treat patients. Professionals have learned the appropriate ways to treat patients, peers, and colleagues and do their best to provide the best possible oral health care to others. They are well-educated and have performed well in not only a classroom setting, but also in their pre-clinic and clinic rotations. Professionally competent individuals are honest, ethical, and hard workers. Most importantly, becoming a professional in the field of dentistry means putting my patients first. I hope to be able to accomplish these goals after graduating NYUCD and becoming a professional.

Following our ethics course with Dr. More, I believe that ethics and ethical decisions are very important not only in a classroom setting, but also in a clinical setting and most importantly, in my dental practice once I graduate. I believe in honesty and following the rules. Although students are often inclined to take no action when witnessing unethical actions, I hope to be able to step forward and confront the student personally. Although I would not be comfortable in involving the peer review board or faculty, I hope I can at least address the student. Most importantly, I hope to be able to follow all rules while here at NYUCD and not make unethical decisions in the classroom and towards my patients. I believe providing the best possible health care is important and I hope to make only ethical and sound decisions when it involves my patients and peers.

These past two years at NYU have really taught me a lot about myself. During D1 I was able to completely focus on the didactic courses and I felt that I was excelling. However, D2 was such a struggle for me. Having to balance classwork and lab work turned out to be really difficult for me. I realized that although I did well in the didactic courses, I was struggling with lab. Failing CR1 turned out to be a blessing in disguise for me. I was so disappointed in myself at first, but it really showed me that I need to spend so much more time in lab and not be afraid to ask for help. I think that experience has made me more comfortable in clinic with asking my peers and faculty for help. With my first pulp exposure last week, I really learned that things happen in clinic and lab and you just have to make the best of each situation even if it is not what you initially had intended for!

Being a competent dental professional entails many serious responsibilities and moral standards. I am confident that I have good judgement and moral foundation. When I am faced with ethical decisions in my career and personal life I expect to always take into consideration the Principles of Ethics, and strive to only do good to my patients.

My goal is to become always be confident and competent in everything I do. I also aim to be and efficient practitioner. I am very interested in cosmetic dentistry and also endodontics. This year I hope to explore shadowing opportunites and learn as much as I can regarding these topics in dentistry.

Dental school has been course of exponential academic and personal growth. Having started clinic, I have realized how little I actually know. It has really brought me a new perspecitve of how much room I have to grow and how much I have to learn. It is a great experience and I am looking forward to all the progress that is to come.
I aim to become a confident and competent oral health practitioner and be able to build lasting relationships with colleagues, mentors, patients and their families.

Patients believe that correct ethical ground on healthcare professionals as given. We are going to be in situations where our personal interest will conflict the ethical codes that we should follow. Being a professional oral care provider means that we put the patients in the center during our progression to becoming a dentist. This will help us solidify our identity in ethical situations and determine the personality of our professional career. 

Ethics in the clinic setting is a little bit different. I want to be able to the best for the patient but sometimes it's the patient or other factors that prevent me from doing so. For example, I just had a patient who received crowns on #8 & 9 that was approved by the financial manager prior to sending out for fabrication. After the crowns were delivered, I received an email stating that the crowns are not covered and the patient will be billed accordingly. I feel that the patient is being wronged by being forced to pay for a procedure that we pre-approved but at the same time, it's not something that I can rectify.

Becoming a professional means striving to become a competent oral healthcare provider. A competent dentist needs to have great skills at hand but they should also encompass other various skills. Establishing a foundation in communication, ethics, integrity, respect is critical in developing into a great dentist that not only excels in his manual proficiency but also delivering the highest level of care in the best way possible. And this reflection hasn't changed since D1.

The D1 year has been a difficult yet fruitful experience in our professional progress. The didactic courses provided the histology and physiology of our body system and the pre-clinic courses exposed us to fundamental concepts of dentistry and the learning experience of procedures we will be performing in the future. Ethics, D1 leadership seminar, SAPL, and clinical seminars provided us with information that can help us build our identity as a professional healthcare provider.

The D2 year was probably the most difficult academic year in my entire career. However, it helped me change my cramming study habits into a balanced one. Introduction to the clinic was nerve-wrecking at first, but I got used to it.

The D3 year started out really slow, but I'm beginning to catch pace. I used to content with not having patients and lodging in the locker room area but now, I am hungry. I get antsy when I don't have patients and I'm always begging my AC to send me to 1A. I'm enjoying the process.

I have several goals as a dental student here at NYUCD. I want to develop better study habits and organization skills that are necessary to match the rigorous curriculum. My primary focus here is to learn the crafts of a great hands-on dentist. I wish to excel in a clinical and lab setting as well in academic courses. I want to create strong networks both inside and outside of the school that can hopefully last throughout and after dental school. After graduation, I wish to be a competent, passionate, friendly professional to provide and care for the oral health of New York City. I want to be a dentist that my patients can trust me in issues on not only oral health but other issues as well.

After finishing the hardest academic year of my career, I am ready to shift my focus on being a better clinician. The clinic has been a slow start for me but I have changed my ways to push myself to be better and work harder. My personal goal for the D3 year is to be constantly work and gain clinical experience.

Ethics can become a challenge sometimes during patient treatment in the clinic. We all have requirements to meet and competencies to take and sometimes we may find ourselves drafting a more elaborate treatment plan than what the patient actually needs in order to benefit ourselves. However, as a health professional, I must keep in mind my patient's interests above my own. So far I have really kept to the ethical standards and have not done something for my patient that is against his or her own wishes. Ethics is communicating to the patient all the alternatives to a treatment plan and then let him or her decide what is going to be done.

Now that I'm officially treating my own patients in clinic, I hope to integrate everything I've learned thus far in all my years at the dental school and present myself as a competent, knowledgeable, and ethical health practitioner.

A professional means to act in an ethical and professional manner where I would place the patient's best interests above my own. It doesn't only mean to perform the technical aspects of my field in an efficient manner, but it also means communicating and behaving in a professional way.

A professional always treats everyone equally and does not let his or her own personal emotions influence his or her decisions about the task at hand. A professional is also one that is competent and knowledgeable in a specific subject area.

During the time I have spent in clinic thus far, I feel that I have matured a lot from the time I spent in the preclinical setting on the 11th floor. I have come to realize that proper communication and ethics are very important when treating patients and are two factors that will help make me stand out as a responsible healthcare professional.

Now that I have officially transitioned into the clinic and have started treating my own patients, I find that I have grown and matured as a health practitioner. It used to be that I would just memorize information solely for the purposes of acing school exams. Now, it's all about applying the theoretical principles I have learned in class on a case by case basis in managing my patients. I strive now to become a well rounded clinician, one who can be held accountable for my own actions and one who does what's best for the patients all the time.

Ethics is morality, sense of right from wrong and has many important components like do no harm, justice, etc. I always try to maintain an ethical professional conduct with my patients, peers and professors. I try to self assess what I can and can't do. I always inform my patients about the ideal treatment options available, pros and cons of the procedures that I would be doing and treat my patients to the best of my abilities. I strive to continually update myself with the courses and knowledge in the field of dentistry. I would pay attention to my patients needs and concerns and deliver care that is most apt for that patient. I would also like to keep myself updated with the advancements in the profession post graduation to help treat my patients better.

Coming from a foreign country with different teaching methods, I had certain positive notions about US Dental Schools and NYUCD has been a true blessing and holds up-to all my expectations. Having experience in practicing dentistry back home and here at NYUCD as a student, I have come to realize that there is always a scope to learn as long as you have the zeal to. Extensive curriculum at NYUCD keeps you on your toes and makes you want to work even harder to become one of the best clinicians. School experience was a little overwhelming to begin with as we were being integrated into the regular program. Clinically, it here has been one of the most satisfying experiences when it comes to patient care, learning from our peers,professors and mentors. I have come to identify my lack of experience in certain areas of patient care and have been focussed on working towards improving them. I would strive to work harder and treat my patients with the best of my abilities and become a good clinician. Cohesiveness of our Group Practice has been an added strengthMy experiences here have strengthened my communication skills in treating diverse populations.

Professionalism is a composite of several characteristics like being ethical, skillful, have good judgmental abilities,being a team player, possess a good character, perform tasks to the best of ones knowledge and ability, knowing when to delegate,having an approachable and friendly demeanor and critiquing ones own work for the best possible outcome. I want to incorporate all of these and more to grow as a professional. I like to spend time to get to know my patients to build rapport which in turn would have an positive impact of treatment outcomes as well as patient attitudes. I have learnt that showing patients that you care has a tremendous impact on their behavior. Professionalism also entails working together as a part of a group. Cohesiveness and help anyone in need attitude of our group practice enabled me to gain insights into being a team player and form a good foundation my future in the profession. I would go forward following all the qualities I mentioned to become a successful professional.
Professionalism also entails effective communication with patients incorporating their needs/concerns and beliefs. I hope to follow this throughout my career.

I want to incorporate all of these and more to grow as a professional. I would go forward following all the qualities I mentioned to become a successful professional. Professionalism also entails effective communication with patients incorporating their needs/concerns and beliefs. I hope to follow this throughout my career.

From my start here at NYUCD, I feel I have grown as a professional. I have tried to learn from my past mistakes, to work together as a team(peer and self assessments,group exercises and assisting peers) and benefitted immensely from the case presentations and treatment planning exercises that help you think out of the box, gain more data into existing patient medical conditions and draft complex treatments plans that is more satisfying to the patient and the treating dentist. I have gained more insight into how insurance plays and the importance of progress notes and documentation. I am still learning on ways to manage patients and giving ample time to get to know my patients to understand their concerns better for providing good care.

Coming from a foreign country with different teaching methods, I had certain positive notions about US Dental Schools and NYUCD has been a true blessing and holds up-to all my expectations. Having experience in practicing dentistry back home and here at NYUCD as a student, I have come to realize that there is always a scope to learn as long as you have the zeal to. Extensive curriculum at NYUCD keeps you on your toes and makes you want to work even harder to become one of the best clinicians. School experience was a little overwhelming to begin with as we were being integrated into the regular program. Clinically, it here has been one of the most satisfying experiences when it comes to patient care, learning from our peers,professors and mentors. I have come to identify my lack of experience in certain areas of patient care and have been working towards improving on them. I would strive to work harder and treat my patients with the best of my abilities and become a good clinician. Cohesiveness of our Group Practice has been an added strength. My experiences here have strengthened my communication skills in treating diverse populations.

I want to become the best oral health care professional possible. This is a difficult task but I feel NYUCD has the best education, clinics, outreach programs, and environment to provide me with the opportunity to obtain my goal. Part of becoming the best oral health care professional is the professional aspect of the job description. I believe the way I care about this health care field and the way I project myself to my peers and patients should be one and the same. I should exude professional competency through my skill, work, and demeanor.

In order to mature professionally, I will take advantage of all that NYUCD has to offer. I will build a basic foundation that will develop into advanced knowledge and an expert skillset of an oral health care professional though education and experience. This maturation will develop through coursework and exams, preclinical and clinics experiences, peer and patient interactions, peer and self-assessments, outreach programs, and leadership roles.

In order to mature professionally, I will take advantage of all that NYUCD has to offer. I will build a basic foundation that will develop into advanced knowledge and an expert skillset of an oral health care professional though education and experience. This maturation will develop through coursework and exams, preclinical and clinics experiences, peer and patient interactions, peer and self-assessments, outreach programs, and leadership roles.

Upon completing my D2 year, I have excelled pre-clinically, academically, and now ready to excel clinically. I have finished the foundation of my dental education and now ready to apply my knowledge to my professional clinical experience. By starting clinic this summer, I am able to utilize all that I have learned over the past two years and take the next step towards becoming the best oral health professional that I can.

I wish to be recognized by my patients, peers, and field as a trustworthy, competent oral health care professional and advocate through integrity, knowledge, and experience. I am working toward this goal by working hard and learning as much as possible from experience, the NYUCD curriculum, and scientific evidence.

Ethic's has not had a huge role in my clinic experience yet.  Honestly we are not driven by money or MDR, just yet.  Everything we think we should do is checked and confirmed by multiple faculty.  So far I feel like I have done the right thing by my patient but we will see.  Maybe the one time I had an ethical dilemma was with a difficult patient who complained during an SRP, and although I wanted to rush and get it done for the appointment to be over,  I continued to work diligently to have the best outcome possible.

The challenge of clinic is REAL!  I enjoy every minute I have a patient but dread the times I don't,  assisting is a good learning experience but nothing like actually performing the procedure.  I am starting to understand the strategies of how to maintain different patients and it seems to be working, but I have not really executed any of my treatment plans in full swing yet.  Kind of scared to see how many will stay, really not just for MDR or CEEs but honestly because I see the pain and frustration of my patients over their oral condition and honestly want to help them eat solid food, get out of pain, and have that esthetic look they want.

Nervous but motivated is my professional attitude right now, which is understandable for me in the first weeks of clinic.  But nervous does not mean apprehensive, I am ready to take on anything that comes my way because I know I have the support of the clinic behind me.  So far I can say I am able to be the professional I want because of friends and faculty that are there to help me with everything I do.  Been really supportive in shaping my development and cannot wait to see what this year has in store.

Now we can finally say we are shaping the professionals we want to be.  Before clinic it was all speculation about the professional we wanted to be or how we would conduct ourselves, now it is time to show what backs up the talk.  In my opinion it is crucial in these first few weeks to truly be professionals and set the standard we want to have for the rest of our careers.

Like I stated above, right now I still feel like I am walking on baby legs in the clinic.  Progress will be to start and become a bit more independent in the procedures I have completed and to take on the new ones I have not attempted yet.

Now that we have a couple of weeks under our belts flying free in the clinic I think many of us have faced situations we were not ready for in the mindset but had the skills.  I know there were times when I was scared to perform a certain procedure but as soon as I started the nerves went away and the training kicked in, like a well trained athlete I felt like I was ready and it was a great feeling.  I cannot wait to start executing some of these treatment plans and get to all the procedures I know I am ready to take on.

There are also many other things I want to improve on:

There are still many procedures that I have not yet performed on a real patient, such as endo, prosth, or extraction etc. For some procedures, I have yet to find the right pt or start the rotations. But some, such as endo, which I didn't get much clinical practice on in D2 (the simulation was rather unhelpful), I feel like I've been inadvertently postponing because I'm afraid to jump into it. I do my first endo case this Tuesday. Mildly anxious, though I've reviewed the notes and shadowed a few. I have to remind myself that this is a learning environment, that as a student not every procedure will be perfect; do the best you can, and if you make a mistake, just fix it, learn from it, it's not the end of the world.

I need better time management skills. I feel like I'm often rushed towards the end of the tx, then I start to panic, and in the midst of getting swipes and writing notes, sometimes forget critical things. Guess I have to be more methodical about it and take steps to make each procedure a physical habit at least, since a mental reminder doesn't always work. Try to be more patient and conscientious.

Becoming a professional dentist means having the knowledge, technical proficiency and experience, as well as accepting ethical and social obligations, maintaining professional integrity and behavior, and above all, being compassionate as a healthcare provider who works to benefit the patients and the public.

The past six months as D3 have been exciting and radically different from D1 and D2. Coming into D3, I learned that there is much more to patient care than academic excellence and technical skill sets. Good communication with patients and building rapport, things which I hadn't thought much of in D1/D2, became significant because it affected pt management; how much trust they had in me and liked me affected the continuation of their tx, home care, recalls, even their appointment adherence. Another thing that became more important was professional conduct in front of colleagues and faculty, as well as patients. We cannot succeed alone in clinic; we need mentors and peer support, and learning from senior students and faculty is the fastest way to becoming proficient. My goals this year is to build a good working relationship with my community, learn to execute my didactic knowledge, and become a reliable member whom patients and colleagues alike can trust.

I truly believe that ethics cannot be taught.  Ethics is something that a person learns as they grow up and is taught by the people around them when they are young.  Thus, it is (almost) impossible to teach someone in dental school to be ethical if they are not.  In a way, ethics is makes up a part of who we are as a professional.  That being said, I believe I have the ethics and principles instilled in me to make ethical decisions and to provide culturally-competent care to my patients.

To be a professional is to be able to do what is right and what's best for my patients.  I want to be able to show the patients that I am competent, while also letting them recognize that I am here to do what is best for them and their dental and overall health.  I want to be the kind of professional that the patients trust and come to love, while being exactly who I am as a person and enjoying life without changing myself.

So far, it has been a pleasure and enjoyable opportunity to work in the clinic as a student dentist.  I know I am progressing and learning so much from everyone in the clinical setting.  It is my goal to become the best dentist I can be so that I may provide the best healthcare possible for all my future patients.  I believe I am developing at a content pace to becoming a fully competent professional and am happy with my progression thus far.

So far, I didn't face ethical situation in clinic that much. Also, I think professor More's lectures provided many possible ethically important situation, so I believe that it prepared me when my ethic is challenged in clinic.

I set up 3 goals to have successful 2 years in clinic; time management, workout, and peaceful mind.
1) As work in clinic is based on person to person, I need to prepare myself for the situation. With the packed academic schedule and many requirements, I should be good at tracking my work and dealing with time.
2) Also, working as a dentist requires physical labor. For balanced life in school, I will keep working out and will not skip it.
3) Lastly, even though I setup good plan, it could be failed by unexpected circumstance. Having peaceful mind is the only way to save me.
Hopefully, I can keep maintaining these goals and survive well in clinic.

I think professional is mastering specific area in one's life and it takes time. So, I consider becoming a professional as life time process. I try enjoy what is happening around me and feel optimistic. I guess that is how I can keep going forward to become a professional.

After I got accepted to dental school, I thought about transitioning my life to professional. Even though I just started to learn academic knowledge about oral health care, my family considers me as a profession already. I feel so embarrassed because I believe that professions should maintain not only high level of competency on their specialty, but also solid professionalism about their life. I might not have either of it yet.
      However, I believe that I can improve myself little bit of every day if I try hard and keep working one it. Because I like learning science and working by my hands, I look forward to obtain clinical technique in some day. I want to focus more on improving my communication skill with my colleague and patients by exposing myself to outreach program and experience in clinics. I expect that I can learn from working with my GPD group and listening to mentors and professors. I hope in someday, I can become proud of my professionals even in front of anyone.

At least, at this point, I am confident in the area of regular check up, prophy and taking radiograph. Also, I could include oral hygiene instruction and class 2 restoration. However, there are still a lot of skill I need to master. By practicing in pre-clinical lab and assisting other skilled faculties, I wish I can progress more to become confident professional.

I always aim to maintain balanced life and I believe that I will gain great experience in NYU dental school to learn broader perspective about life. The reason why I chose NYU dental school for the beginning of my future career was that it provides not only a chance of learning fundamental academic knowledge but also great social environment to learn people. I believe that dentist is a professional who provides oral health care to patients under fully trustful relationship. 
      In four years in dental school, I want to improve myself academically and clinically to become trustful dentist. Also, personally I want to keep balancing my life by participating in social activities and outreach programs. If there is a chance to work as an instructor or researcher in an institute, I would love to join there because I like teaching and learning. Eventually, I want to own my practice near my home town to contribute my life to community.

As I mentioned above, I'm fairly concerned with how NYU teaches students to value patients through the lens of CEE's and MDRs.  This doesn't strike me as any different than teaching students to value patients in terms with how much money they can make us.

Privately, I want to be able to better explore my ability to make mistakes in clinic.  I know it isn't always ethical, but being able to make mistakes is something that definitely comes up in dental school.  Not that I would be willing to make them on patients, but this is the place to make them, so I want to be more comfortable making mistakes if that involved me becoming a better practitioner.

Privately, I am always in awe of Dr. Rochlen.  He someone I look up to immensely, and model myself after his composure in clinic.  He's confident, understanding, and is loose enough to show patients that he has a human side.  I hope that I will be able to be a professional like him in the future.

I feel having a strong mentor is the best method towards becoming a professional.  Having an example of how to compose and present ourselves helps immensely, and I'm happy to say that there are many prime examples of professionalism within our own clinic.

I feel I've made great strides towards becoming a professional.  I feel I am well respected among my peers, and am viewed as responsible and competent.  Through my roles as a leader in Xi Psi Phi, as well as always being available to help assist people in clinic, I find people innately trust me.  Recently, I've done a crown prep with Dr. Estafan and she approached me yesterday to complement me in the way I presented the case and myself to her.  She was quite impressed and this was quite a boost to my ego and towards my path towards being a professional.

I suppose that my personal statement has changed a bit since having spent a few years in dental school.  I'm actually a lot less concerned about my academic standing compared to how I conduct myself in front of my senior colleagues.  I also am much more concerned about making my patients, and classmates feel comfortable and welcomed in an otherwise hostile environment, being the dental chair or dental school, respectively.  Clinically, I am aiming towards expanding my roster, and being able to fill up my clinic hours.  I have recently been doing mostly emergency cases, and while helpful, have not been yielding very reliable patients.  I do question the way we teach dental students to value patients by their CEE's and MDRs, as it feels like an implicit message of objectifying patients.  How is that different than saying a patient can be worth X-amount of dollars, it really isn't.

I think that I have a good understanding of the ethics involved in the dental clinic and pride myself on having a strong, moral compass. I always emphasize the importance of choice to my patients and try to give a genuine, accurate opinion of each treatment option.
NA

Professionally, I know that I have a lot more to learn. Hopefully I can improve on my shortcomings with more experience in the clinic, but I know that I still a lot more to do before I can be comfortable with my professionalism. Admittedly, I get easily disheartened and go through periods of apathetic indifference and become extremely lazy, but it's been something I've been putting a lot of effort into correcting.

In the foreseeable future, I hope to become a great dentist. I would like to continue my education to become an orthodontist but I do not want to limit myself and want to leave myself open to new opportunities. While I am in school, I want to participate in an outreach program and learn how to work with other practitioners with professional competence. Socially, I want to me meet new people and create strong relationships both with other practitioners and patients.

Being in the situation I am in now, I don't know if I'll be pursuing a career as an orthodontist. Personally its been pretty tough just managing everything with school and just getting by. Hopefully in the upcoming year I'll grow more accustomed to the clinic lifestyle, which is the only short term goal I have for right now.
I trust myself that I will make an ethical decisions in school, at the clinic, and in the community. I will become a responsible person who values honesty and fairness.

At the moment, my biggest concern is having a solid future plan after graduation. I am at the stage of learning and exploring. I hope by end of this year, I have a clearer picture of what I want to do, and what my true passion lies. I also find it difficult to be confident in front of others. I hope there is an improvement as I become more experienced and knowledgeable.

I think I need to improve communication skills and give more effort to be more interactive with both patients and faculty. It is difficult to change current personality to the personality I believe I need to be successful.

From my experience in clinic so far, I learned that earning trust from patient and being a dependable provider is the most difficult aspect of this profession. I hope to gain this quality by pushing myself to be more pro-active, and always having patient-centered thinking.

So far, I learned how to perform SRP, prep and filling, taking comprehensive exams and evaluating patient's x-rays. I am also learning communication skills by interacting with staffs and patients. I feel I am struggling with stress management and lacking interpersonal skills especially with patients.

It has been two years since I started my education in NYUCD. I find one of the most important quality for a dentist be successful is confidence and good interpersonal skills. I also find this quality very challenging to learn.  By the time I finish clinic and graduate, I want to be a charismatic and confident dentist whom patients and coworkers can rely on. Undoubtedly, that quality should come from experience, skill, knowledge and caring mind for the others.
NA

Being a professional means many different things. The most important thing at the moment has been balancing the expectations of my patients, the school, and my own expectations for myself. Speaking of my own expectations for myself, I believe altruism is an important part of being a professional, and I want to put more into this, such as dedicating time outside of school to outreaches. I think becoming more involved in other areas, such as research, would help me develop my professional skills, and this is an option I want to explore further.

Now that we are halfway through our journey at NYUCD, it seems to be a good time to reflect on things. D1 and D2 were certainly learning experiences in many ways, and the transition to clinic was, at times, daunting. But now that we are getting settled in, it is time to make sure we take advantage of all resources and learn as much as possible. These next two years will go by quickly, and I hope to experience as many clinical situations as possible. I am also still hoping that my exact career path will become more clear during this process. I am continuing to work on my goal of helping my patients not feel nervous around a dentist, and not dread coming back.

Over the course of the past year I've realized that facing ethical dilemmas is a frequent occurrence in dental school; which is perhaps only an indication of what a potentially lucrative career in health care and management will be like. Deciding between the easy choice, the most rewarding choice and the "correct" choice will always fall into a gray area with plenty of "what ifs" and "buts". Taking the time to determine the most ethically sound choices will ensure that these are the natural choices in the future.
As the scramble for CEE and MDR continues to be emphasized to us, I can't help but begin to think about my patients as "procedures" or simple, a means to graduate. It's a conscious and deliberate process of forcing myself to think that way in order to keep the patient's well-being as the highest priority.

My goal is to take advantage of the academic, clinical and social resources available at the school in order to become a skilled, well-rounded and competent oral health care professional dedicated to treating, raising awareness, educating and improving the overall health and quality of life of the local and global community.
      Along the way, I will strive to develop strong personal and professional relationships that have a positive impact in my life as well as in the field of dentistry.

Becoming a dental professional requires gaining the necessary foundational knowledge and experiences. I hope to gain this knowledge, experience and skill through basic science classes and labs, pre-clinical labs, clinics, hospital rotations, and local and global outreaches. The other aspect of becoming a professional is to be conscious of the ethical and social responsibilities that come with nearly every decision. 
Through exams and competencies, as well as feedback from peers and advisers, I hope to be evaluated and measured as a competent professional.

D1 has been about gaining technical skills, scientific knowledge and professional growth.
In September, I secretly questioned whether I had the steady hands to make it as a dentist. Over the next few months I found myself completely comfortable with a high speed hand piece and scoring 85s and 100s on practicals. This put me in a somewhat unique position to help my classmates and impart some of the skills and advice that I had received from upperclassmen and faculty. 
The amount of scientific knowledge I have gained over the past year is astonishing. In the beginning, I wondered if it was humanely possible. By the end, I was thirsty for more.
One hard lesson that I learned was that I need to be more organized and more proactive when it comes to science courses. Time is a valuable thing in dental school, and learning to manage it better and maximize productivity is my immediate goal going forward.

My goal is to take advantage of the academic, clinical and social resources available at the school in order to become a skilled, well-rounded and competent oral health care professional dedicated to treating, raising awareness, educating and improving the overall health and quality of life of the local and global community.
      I've been pursuing this goal by challenging myself to do better academically. D2, although more difficult and stressful, was a much better year in terms of grades than D1. Additionally, I joined Class Council in D2 as a curriculum rep and continue this role into D3. Keeping the class informed of our academic responsibilities has naturally forced me to stay on top of my own responsibilities. 
      In clinic, I approach every patient and every procedure as a learning opportunity. I Know my skills are not the best - I don't expect to deliver the best care. However, I know that every clinic session is another step towards improving my skills. 
      I was one of the outreach chairs for ASDA in D2. We developed 3 new local outreaches from the ground up and revamped an educational outreach. This role allowed me to gain more social awareness of the barriers to healthcare at home. As part of the Global Outreach team to Nicaragua in D3, I was involved in treating over 700 patients. Personally, I performed 3 RCTs in 4 hours, 18 extractions over 2 days, and 26 restorations in another 2 days. Equally important, I met with many young Nicaraguans and discussed their daily lives, their struggles to obtain healthcare, dental care and an education. It was a powerful experience in dentistry and public health.
      Along the way, I will strive to develop strong personal and professional relationships that have a positive impact in my life as well as in the field of dentistry.

As a dental professional, a patient puts a great deal of trust upon the dentist as often patients do understand the complexities and prognosis of their own condition. With that being said, a great amount of care and detail must be given to each individual as your decisions as well as how you present them can greatly impact their lives. I understand that becoming a professional does not only include being proficient in your manual and intellectual skills, but also the ability to gain the patients trust and to be always consistent with the high quality of care your patients expect from you.

Through my journey at NYUCD I have learned and still learning what it takes to become the excellent healthcare provider in the community that we live in. Now having moved in to the clinic environment, my goal is to use the knowledge and relationships I have accrued over the last 2 years to provide the best quality of service I can.

Ethics is a very tricky subject.  The best way to break it down is probably to state the most obvious and honest treatment plan that one can offer a patient without compromising health and law.  second is to modify this plan to suit the needs of the patient and to explain the things that can go wrong and have the patient understand.  last is to perform procedure being very careful and not to harm the patient and inform them of anything that went wrong

What I have learned from the one month in the clinics.  Everyone is different.  There is one set of rules and MANY ways to follow them.  Each student and each faculty operates in a certain way and over time people will find each other to produce the best outcome.  So far, I am learning who my peers really are, something I wasn't able to see in the pre-clinics because it was each man for themselves.  Now we depend on each other and I know who I can rely on and who I can't.  Everyday is a valuable learning experience and I wont take it for granted.

Being a professional now is different than what I thought before.  It is not just how to talk to patients.  You should carry yourself the way you want people to view you, in other words set an example.  Dress well, stay clean, be approachable, talk friendly, listen well, be thorough, treat all as if you have all the energy for them, dont compromise any persons health just because of stress, and maintain integrity throughout.  All people deserve good health and I am obligated to deliver.  period.

As I begin clinic, I realize the important and impact I have on patients.  They come with a problem and we fix it.  The field is so complex and can take many turns which is why it is very crucial to review the important steps and follow protocol when it comes to working in the clinics.  Dentistry has many routes for creativity and adventure but it is of utmost importance that we as professionals educate ourselves and our patients on what occurs in this field.  Detail is very crucial for success but the overall picture is the way to begin any procedure, and of course the career.

My professionalism isnt what i call "progressing" but rather molding into where I want it to be.  For now, I am still learning that professionalism is part of the profession and both are a process that will take many years to develop.

I hope in my clinical years that I achieve the confidence and knowledge to tackle any case that is presented to me.  With the complexity of the science and the demand from our patients' requests, we have to be able to piece together many parts of a puzzle that would yield the ultimate result.  I am really enjoying the beginning of this journey.
asdf

These past two years of dental has focused on a lot of the didactic portions of the dental profession. Second year was the most difficult for me, in terms of trying to keep up with the amount of lab work, practicing in pre-clinic on the weekends, along with staying on track with my grades and coursework. It really tested my strength and ability to stay focused, motivated, and as positive as I could be. I had difficulties and really struggled with CR1, but felt accomplished and proud of myself when I had passed the class and the competencies. As third year has just begun, it took me a little while to adjust to the clinical portion of dentistry and putting everything we had learned so far into practice. Within these next two years, I hope to continue to grow as a professional, better communicate and teach patients the importance of oral healthcare, as well as gain more confidence in my hand skills.

Becoming a professional is not easy. It takes dedication, motivation, focus, and the will to not give up. That I have learned within these past two years, and I know that there are still obstacles and hurdles to pass for years to come. I hope to be able to take everything that I have learned in dental school, from my colleagues, mentors, and faculty, and be able to become a competent and compassionate professional.

Becoming a professional takes the ability to transform everything that we have been taught in the didactic and pre-clinic courses, and bring that into the clinical setting. Professionals are confident in the material and knowledge that they know, and are able to educate and help patients understand the importance of oral healthcare. With the ability to self-assess, and receive peer feedback, we can continue to strive to improve ourselves and the treatment of patients in a professionally competent way. In order to become a compassionate, understanding professional, constant interactions among a diverse group of colleagues and patients is necessary. Being a well-rounded individual in knowledge, technical skills, and communication is key to becoming a professional.

These past two years have given me the confidence in being able to learn the important material needed to help me in my career. It has also taught me ways to be more efficient in studying and I have bettered my test taking skills as well. I always felt as if my hand skills were lacking compared to my other classmates. I always felt like I had to practice two times more than everyone, and sometimes it took me two times longer to do procedures than others. But being in clinic, I have become more confident in my hand skills. I finally feel that a lot of the time I spent practicing on my own time in pre-clinic last year is finally being paid off. I hope to gain even more confidence as I gain more experience throughout these next two years.

These past two years of dental has focused on a lot of the didactic portions of the dental profession. Second year was the most difficult for me, in terms of trying to keep up with the amount of lab work, practicing in pre-clinic on the weekends, along with staying on track with my grades and coursework. It really tested my strength and ability to stay focused, motivated, and as positive as I could be. As third year has just begun, it took me a little while to adjust to the clinical portion of dentistry and putting everything we had learned so far into practice. Within these next two years, I hope to continue to grow as a professional, better communicate and teach patients the importance of oral healthcare, as well as gain more confidence in my hand skills.

I am both excited and nervous as I begin my transition from the preclinical world of didactics and mannequins into clinic. I am eager to apply things that I have already learned and to refine my skills even more. It is so refreshing to be at a point in my education that everything I learn is incredibly applicable. I am eager to reach the point in which treating patient's and making clinical decisions on my own is the norm, however, I will cherish these times of learning. I hope to explore various specialties further although I certainly have found some disciplines along the way that have continued to intrigue me throughout my time at NYUCD. I look forward to developing my skills clinically while fostering productive, respectful, and positive relationships with my patients, faculty, and colleagues.

Being a dental professional requires the integration of pre-clinical skills and didactic course work in a clinical setting while maintaining positive and respectful relationships with patients and colleagues. I have enjoyed getting to know my peers and the faculty that we work with on a daily basis on the clinic floor. I have enjoyed the clinical aspect of dentistry and having the opportunity to integrate everything I have learned so far at NYUCD. Though I have had many patients that were very pleasant to work with, there have been a handful that were much more difficult. Learning to remain calm and to communicate in a productive manner with the latter, though frustrating at first, has become a challenge I have appreciated enduring retrospectively. It is with the more difficult and curious patients that I have found my interpersonal skills improve the most with.

Being a dental professional requires the integration of pre-clinical skills and didactic course work in a clinical setting while maintaining positive and respectful relationships with patients and colleagues. I have enjoyed getting to know my peers and the faculty that we work with on a daily basis on the clinic floor. I have enjoyed the clinical aspect of dentistry and having the opportunity to integrate everything I have learned so far at NYUCD. Though I have had many patients that were very pleasant to work with, there have been a handful that were much more difficult. Learning to remain calm and to communicate in a productive manner with the latter, though frustrating at first, has become a challenge I have appreciated enduring retrospectively. It is with the more difficult and curious patients that I have found my interpersonal skills improve the most with.

This year has really changed my perspective of what being a professional is like. Previously, I had a lot of ideologic conceptions of being a professional where I theoretically would make my patients happy all the time. However, it is practically impossible to make the patient 100% satisfied all the time - whether it be about the cost of their visit or the procedure itself.
I realized that professionalism is all about balance and being realistic. I have to balance the needs of the patient with my own expectations of what I can do. I also found out that it is easier to tell the patients outright the pros and cons for all the options that they have, as it builds a rapport of trust between the provider and the patient.

As we have started our year in clinic, I've come to realize how different reality versus theory is. Having a patient is not like what we had experienced during our clinical courses in D1 or D2 year, where the manikin could be moved and propped into any direction we wanted. On top of that, every patient is different from the 'ideal' standard that we always worked with previously in simulation lab. However, irregardless of how different it all seems, I still stand by my original ideology that I will be providing optimal care for my patients, to the best of my abilities. I also would like to continue working with my colleagues on my clinic floor to help improve our abilities of clinical skills and applications. One major thing I am continuously thankful for is the strong teamwork that our GPD has, and I would like to see everyone in the clinic thrive through the next few years.

I have continued this year with the same integrity that I entered the school with. However, some students around me have exploited each others weaknesses and with held information from each other upon the commencement of the year in order to out do each other in the anticipation of specializing. I have never been the person at the top of the class nor the person to try hindering people around me to make myself look better. I am a firm believer in putting yourself out there and trying your best and hoping it will all work out. The only person I can trust is myself.

I have made great strides in gaining professional competency since the beginning of the year. Most importantly I have learned to trust myself with regards to both hand skills and test taking. This has given me confidence and motivation in moving forward as a D3.

I have learned to trust myself with regards to judgement in preparation for both exams and procedure preparation. I started out dental school very timid and uncertain of my own abilities moving forward in a professional career. I had so often doubted myself academically upon the fact that it took multiple tries and extra schooling to gain admission to dental school. What I have come to realize is that the system is flawed and as long as you are willing to put in the time, you will get out of it what you want.

I look forward to learning the dental and patient management skills in clinic to help better prepare me for success after graduation. By being submersed in the dental profession and observing the professionals around me I will begin to pick up important traits that will be expected of me as a professional.  As my social life develops and by staying well rounded outside of class I will be able to grow and better assess my strengths and weaknesses through peer interactions. Most importantly I look forward to patient interaction and gaining the knowledge of dealing with individuals in a friendly way while conveying a high level of professionalism. Thus far, reflecting back on my interactions with both my classmates, professors, patients, and even in my personal life I have grown significantly since beginning school here at NYU.

I have made great strides in gaining professional competency since the beginning of the year. Most importantly I have learned to know what I don't know. There is nothing worse than going blindly into a procedure or answering a patients question with out knowing the real answer. The more I learn about the day to day operations in the clinic and the more points of view I learned from different doctors, the more I learn about myself and what type of dentist I will be one day.

I will strive to gain the professional competency and social skills to provide the best health care possible for my patients. I look forward to better understanding the business dynamics of dentistry along with the procedural protocol as I move forward into my D3 year.

When it comes to ethics I believe that I withhold VERY honest values.  I do not have a bone of bad intention in my body and I am the type of person who struggles to even process a conscious thought of malicious intent.  Although I do make mistakes as we all do and sometimes make not the best choice, I trust in myself and my integrity that I am ethically moral and sound.
My public personal statement is a reflection of my private thoughts, but I guess in a private statement I'd like to express my desire to practice ARTISTRY in dentistry.

In addition to my public statement, I also hope to become more patient as a professional as well as highly informed and practiced in the economical and business aspect that resides in dentistry in order to be highly successful.

When it comes to becoming a professional, I feel I am on the right path.  I am a person who believes in her actions and values to be of pure and good intention and I strive on my virtue of honesty.  However I hope to improve on become more eloquent in my communication skills regarding the doctor patient relationship.

I have made a lot of professional progress this year.  One personal achievement I have accomplished is the ability to understand my peers reaction of my overwhelming personality and tendency to be in my own world and slightly introverted when I am focusing in bench lab and through self reflection help them see my kind heart and the effort I am putting forward to be more present and aware of my peers.  When I received my peer assessments this semester I had a significant difference from last semester in regards to seeming "mean" and actually being nice.

I stride to master the artistry of dentistry through the use of the immaculate technology available to us today in conjunction with my eye for perfection and passion for a beautiful and healthy smile.  In my vision, I am a dentist who practices with grace and diligence, and my patients walk into my office and sit into my chair knowing that in coming to me they are going to leave happier and healthier.  It is in my personality to care deeply for those who are close to me, and I hope that I establish long term relationships with my patients in which they trust that it is in my best interest and professional ability to provide my patients with a smile that is disease free and esthetically supreme.  Another interest of mine is to participate in the expedition of technology and chemistry that is involved in the instruments and materials that it takes to keep the tissues and peridontium strong resilient and beautiful.  All the while keeping a warm pleasant and energetic setting in my office that is welcoming, honest, and kind.

Certain principles that I hold of the utmost importance in my ethical beliefs are honesty, integrity, and humility. It is my duty to put the patient's best interest before mine for the simple fact that they come to me with a problem that they hope I will be able to resolve. In addition, it is imperative that as a practitioner, I do not take an authoritative stance while providing care for my patient, but rather focus on patient autonomy. This will allow the patient to intrinsically motivate themselves for change to better improve their oral health as well as the quality of their lives.

I am humbled to be part of the NYUCD community and look forward to coordinating responsibilities and duties I have as a medical health provider to relieve my patients out of pain and discomfort while continuing to further my knowledge and enlighten myself with new practices and habits  as a dental care professional.

Now that I've seen a couple of patients in clinic, I have noticed that first impressions are key to success. This means that as a professional I have to look the part with a shirt and tie or scrubs. Also it is key to come to clinic and be prepared and review cases in order to truly be confident and competent treatment time.

In order to be a true professional, I believe there is always room for improvement to enhance my skills as a competent and confident dental practitioner. Maintaining a professional appearance does not only come with the price of a shirt and tie, but understanding the importance of punctuality and quality in my work. These are the attributes I will strive to master throughout the next four years in an effort to better myself as a professional as well as a person.

Eager to start making some.
Its been a month in clinic and now we are treating actual patients.

As a proud member of the NYUCD community, I am committed to providing the highest quality dental care to the global community with dedication, diligence, and utmost integrity through a family oriented oral health practice.

I think being a professional is not just about one's education and abilities, but more so about how they make a patient feel. A true professional helps make a patient feel at ease and lessens their anxiety. They speak respectfully and seek to understand the patient's goals and desires regrading dental treatment. They are not just concerned about the procedure but more about the patient's well being and satisfaction.

In the past two years, I have grown a great deal as a professional. Mainly, my hand skills have gone from non-existent to actually being able to perform restorative procedures on patients and feeling comfortable doing so. Now that I am in clinic, I interact with patients and try to maintain good bedside manner, trying to make sure they are feeling ok and are comfortable. Additionally, after two years of courses in dental anatomy, microbiology, etc, I understand the science behind dental issues such as caries and more effectively able to explain that to my patients.

I consider myself an ethical person.  I make mistakes from time to time as everyone does, but when it comes to patient care, I see myself as having a nearly sacrosanct responsibility to do what is best for my patient.  One must do no harm and deliver the standard of care within his/her understood scope of practice.  Anything else is being a charlatan, frankly.

I wish to become competent as a clinician.  I desire a simple life where I can provide for myself and my family, do work I enjoy, and do work which positively effects the medical/dental condition of my patients within the highest expectations of ethical and professional practice.

Every day, every experience I have, be it positive or negative, I view as an opportunity to grow as a person in some way.  My time at NYUCD has presented me with many such opportunities, and I have definitely grown into someone more professional and mature in my time here.  I plan on expanding far past where I am, as well.

Being a professional is being one who can be trusted as an expert in his/her specified field.  It is someone upon whom the laypeople rely for advice, recommendations, and treatment.  Being a professional is assuming responsibility.  We have an ethical obligation as professionals to assume and maintain this responsibility throughout our lives.  Therefore, professionalism not only extends to delivering the standard of care, clinically, it includes the way we talk to people and treat people as well as how we treat ourselves throughout all facets of our lives.

Every patient experience I have had has shaped me into a professional in some way.  Experience with the actual dentistry is what fuels the development of the clinical skills, and patient interactions of all other kinds fuels the development of professional skills.  Among these professional skills are ethical practice, time management, treatment planning, and communication, among others.
