Then, there are days where I have not patients and feel like clinic is a waste of time.  I am learning a lot, but there is still a world of knowledge to be learned.

I will graduate from NYUCD in 2017 and will be a complete and competent dental practitioner.  I will accomplish this goal by mastering the necessary technical skills in conjunction with the social skills needed to succeed in the dental profession.  This aspect of being able to communicate is just as important as the knowledge and skills needed to be a proficient dentist.  In addition to these dental aspects, I will meet many new people and form bonds to build friendships that will last a lifetime.  I will maintain a good attitude.  I will immerse myself in as many of the clubs, organizations, and events that NYU has to offer.  I will care for my patients and I will be an asset to my school and peers and will be proud to be member of the NYUCD family.

Becoming a dental professional is not only an honor but it's a responsibility that we have to uphold as healthcare providers. We are the gatekeepers to healthcare and as such, we must always uphold the highest level of competency, ethics and professionalism.

In the last few months I have learned that dental school is not all about obtaining clinical skills but it's also about building relationships with patients, faculty and colleagues is of outmost importance because it can shape my experience positively and push me to become a more competent, effective and confident practitioner.

Dentistry has given me the opportunity to combine my love for art and healthcare. As an artist I promise to design, create and enhance smiles. As a healthcare provider, I promise to educate, promote, prevent and treat my patients with the outmost care and competency. My goal is to never lose sight of my passion, make my patients a priority and love what I do so that everyday I wake up with a smile on my face and a dedication to be a vital part of the dental profession. I have continued to dedicate myself to public health by volunteering abroad in Nicaragua, co-founding Generation Smile (a cleft palate/cleft lip student organization at NYUCD) as well as involvement in class council, Pediatric Club and Aesthetics Society.

Continuously reviewing ethical principles and applicable literature to provide care within the scope of ethical principles. Ethical principles should be incorporated into my practice because I want to become a dentist that is trustworthy and display empathy towards my patients.

To excel in my studies in order to be a competitive applicant in a dental specialty. To always pursue perfecting my technical skills to provide the best care to patients by staying up to date with the newest technology advances in dentistry. And to find a good balance between family and work.

Personally, I believe becoming a professional will take time. Everything I learn at school will help me develop the skills to become a confident dentist. I value the interactions I have with patients and classmates throughout school because I believe it will truly help me learn how to interact with various people and improve my professionalism in the workplace.

To be viewed as a competent provider that instills confidence of my skills in my patients and colleagues. I would like to display confidence in myself in order for my patients to feel comfortable receiving treatment. I believe it is important to keep up to date with new information and skills in order to be knowledgable and provide honest care for my patients.

In order to progress in professionalism, I believe it is important to continuously meet with colleagues and also document in a journal for self reflection.  As important feedback is from others, I think professional progress will be effective with self reflection and self acknowledgement as an attempt to advance in professionalism.

To excel in my studies and continuously refine my hand skills to provide excellent quality care to patients as a well rounded, confident dentist while developing interpersonal skills with my peers. Always seeking to improve my communication skills with my patients to help them feel comfortable whenever they seek treatment. Never losing sight of providing care with empathy and honesty. Throughout my career, I want to stay passionate in reaching out to the community to fulfill the needs of underserved patients globally.

In transitioning from preclinical education to being in the clinic full time, we are now finally experiencing what it is like to be a healthcare professional. We interact with and treat patients on a daily basis, and this is vastly different from sitting in simulation lab and learning how to do crown preps or how to drill the perfect class II preparation. In the clinic, your skills in dentistry are not enough. Interpersonal skills now have a huge role in our success. I feel lucky in that I came into dental school with well developed interpersonal skills due to my previous career as a public school educator, in which I had to interact with children, parents, colleagues, and administration on a daily basis. Of course, clinical skills are important and you must provide your patients with the best possible standard of care, but your communication and interpersonal skills are equally important. I find that it is much easier to treat a patient who likes you as a person and enjoys interacting with you, than it is to treat a patient who finds you to be unpleasant to be near.

I feel that I have made large strides in my professional progress between D1 and D3. I entered D1 with the hopes of specializing in orthodontics, a field I knew very little about. After being exposed to a multitude of courses and clinical experiences in the last two years, that has changed. I discovered an aversion to the field of orthodontics at the start of the D2 year, when we took an introductory course. Then this past summer, as I started doing my periodontal assisting competencies in 5W, I discovered a strong interest in the field of periodontics. This discovery has fueled me to pursue my interest in the field with observation in 5W, reading literature on advances in the field, and a strong consideration of applying both to the honors periodontal program in D4 and to a periodontal residency.

We are at professional school and we are soon going to be professionals. It is highly recommended for us, professionals, to be ethical and think about our actions. There were few times where I saw colleagues not being ethical. I'm very disappointed. I hope we as dentists can always provide the best treatments for them, not for us.

Rather than applying for an orthodontics residency program, I decided to apply to a GPR so that I can become a general dentist who can do many various procedures. But in order to do that, I should work harder and try to observe and do as much procedure as I can.
Although there were few hard moments where I wanted to give up studying, it was my dream that kept me going. Hopefully, school and the faculty guide me as well in my pursuit of my dream.
I'm doing my best to excel academically and clinically. My relationships with my GPD colleagues became much better and closer. Hopefully, I can develop good relationships with my patients as well.
I'm working very hard toward my goal and so far its going ok. I passed my first board exam and D2 year. Seeing patients really make me excited to go to school early in the morning.

Through four years of NYU dental school,  I would like to truly understand what dentistry is professionally and to master the necessary skills to become an exceptional dentist. It is my goal to learn everything the faculty has to offer and be able to provide fine technical skills to my patients in the near future. Also, I would love to participate in the Global Outreach Program as it is my dream to help those in need outside the country and give them back the beautiful smile they once had.
As I see real patients in the clinic and develop relationships with them, I want to learn more and more to be a better dentist.
I think it is important to be an ethical health provider, so I can build up a trust relationship with patients.

Personally, It is most important to get along with peers and mentors in school. I would like to build wonderful relationship with people in NYUCD. Also, I strive to achieve knowledge and skills to give a proper health care to my future patients. I would like to have stronger passion in dentistry so I can say I really love what I do in dental field.

In order to become a competent practitioners, I learned a lot this first year of school. not only knowing the basic knowledge on dentistry but also I learned how to become ethical, responsible and competent to become a professional.

In order to become a competent practitioners, I learned a lot this first year of school. not only knowing the basic knowledge on dentistry but also I learned how to become ethical, responsible and competent to become a professional.

Day by day, course by course, I am getting more knowledge and skill to become a professional. after one year of studying, I learned how to restore teeth and knowing how dental structure is composed of. I am looking forward to learn more in this upcoming semester.

Having clinical experience through 4 years in NYUCD, Developing connections and relationship with other peers and mentors, and learning how to provide the best health care to patients will help to be a competent professional in dentistry.
By giving a best treatment to patients, I would like to contribute a good health care in Dentistry.
I would like to be more adaptive and skillful in communicating with the patients, especially to earn more trust from the patients.

I would like to be more efficient in setting up, preparing for the procedure, and executing the procedure. In order to achieve that, I would need to be more skillful with my hands and time management.
I would always take comprehensive patient care approach, to look at every component and not to neglect things for thorough exam.
I feel more competent in restoring carious lesions especially after performing a wide Class II restorations on one patient.

Within 4 years of dental school, what I would like to achieve is to obtain a DDS degree which would open up more opportunities such as proceeding onto becoming a specialist. In addition, I would like to build a professional social network: a group of professionals that I can turn into.
testing

After my first few months in clinic, I have realized how important it is that as a professional I am always prepared.  Before each session I make sure that I understand what procedure I am performing, determine whether there is any information I need to brush up on, and determine how what if any preparation can be done prior to the appointment to optimize my patients time.  Whether it's making sure that I am in clinic early to have my operatory set up prior to the appointment, to making sure I have reviewed the radiographs and study models prior to finalizing a treatment plan, it is important that as a professional I project readiness and competence to my patient.  Being adequately prepared for every patient encounter is critical to that.

As a professional, I feel as though I have made great progress in clinic. After completing 10 Class III and several Class II restorations, I have begun to feel more confident in my clinical abilities.  I feel comfortable giving local anesthesia, talking to patients about their care, and working with an array of faculty on various dental treatments.  As I continue in clinic, it is important for me to continue to build upon my basic skills, and learn the nuances that make an adequate dentist a great one.

When I enter the dental field I want my patients to have faith in my skills and abilities, knowing that whatever procedure is necessary will be done with care and precision.  In order for this to occur, I need to develop a vast knowledge of dental sciences as well as hone my clinical skills.   However, this alone with not make me the dentist I want to become.  I look forward to  building personal relationships with my  patients here at NYUCD, so that I learn how to establish the trust needed for consistent oral healthcare.

I find that CEE drives students to make decisions.  The school tries to change its culture and wants to create an ethical and professional environment but the way that CEE is organized, it makes this difficult to accomplish.  The CEE minimum keep rising, while we get less points for what we do. While I will apply and hopefully get into an honors program and I am doing it for the experience, I think it is wrong to remove CEE but not MDR.  If we are in clinic working, why shouldn't we receive credit? Also, on rotations, I have noticed that people seem less motivated because they know they aren't receiving any credit, and it makes the overall environment different.

I have had a few friends and family come in for an exam and prophy and I treat them as I do with every other patient but I usually have the opportunity afterwards to get very honest feedback, especially from family.  I have been so happily surprised with the feedback I received about certain things that I have been doing with my patients that I didn't even realize have caused my patients to become more invested in their oral hygiene and care more about their overall oral health.  I believe this has helped me to build a rapport with my patients and put their faith in me as a professional.  One of my family members told me their expectations were not so high and the way that I treated them and interacted with them was beyond anything they imagined.  It feels really great to have validation from the people that know you best that you have grown so much and you are becoming a professional.

My goal is to use the dental skills I will obtain at NYU College of Dentistry and combine them with my anthropological background to promote oral health as a public health concern in marginalized communities in the United States and abroad. Eventually, I would like to establish a non-profit organization in Honduras that will assist financially children from low-income families who to continue with their education.
During my time in clinic, I've learned that part of being a professional is being able to treat your colleagues with professionalism regardless of the differences in character you may have with them.

Becoming a healthcare professional includes an understanding of the different factors affecting dentistry: including economics, politics, and cultural dynamics. They’re all intertwined and it’s really difficult to detach one from the other when hearing a patient’s story. In order to be a successful dentist one has to be aware of the different issues that are affecting each patient we treat.

As a clinician now, I can see how ethics is very important. I whole-heartedly believe that the patient is who should be valued, not the points to be gathered from each procedure/patient. Unfortunately, majority of students are pressured into doing what is best for them because of the high "points" we have to accumulate, disregarding the patients true needs.

Attending dental school not only provides an outstanding understanding of the science and beauty of the practice of dentistry but also the pleasure of building personal and professional relationships. These relationships are what allow dentistry to be a rewarding profession.  As a dental school student, I want to develop very strong interpersonal relationships with my colleagues as well as my professors. Over the four years, I want to be able to build a strong network of professionals who can rely on myself as a clinician and vice versa. As a student, I want to establish a growing passion for dentistry and develop an inspiration that will continue to make dentistry rewarding in the near future. Upon doing research and volunteering in the orthodontic field, I want to provide orthodontic care to patients in need whether in an office setting or through an outreach program. As a healthcare provider I believe communication is imperative, not only to the patient but with other professionals as well. As a 3rd year, I can say I am sure the path I have chosen was correct. I enjoy every minute of clinic, although sometimes it is slow. Patient are very important to me and helping them to the best of my knowledge and ability is what I strive for and will continue to do so.

I see myself developing a more mature professional as I continue through my path as a dental student. Currently, as I look back, I feel that I have grown in how I have come to understand dentistry as a whole. Although the actual skill involved is important and it is what sets apart each individual in the field, I believe even more-so, the interaction and treatment of patients is the factor which will even better your dental practice.

Writing this now, unpon completion of my D1 year, I can say it was quite an adventure, full of learning experiences. I thought it was a great time although sometimes even though I did my best, I didn't feel as if the exams exemplified my knowledge. I did learn a lot and I feel that I've become more competent in certain aspects of the dental field, however I've just begun. I cannot wait till I experience the next 3 years as a dental student.

Now as a D3 student, I feel I have grown mentally as a colleague and a practitioner. I enjoy seeing and helping patients at the best of my ability.

As a student at dental school, I want to establish professional and personal relationships within the dental field with both patients and other professionals. Acquiring the technical hands skills and practicing them with great proficiency will be another important aspect I would want to take out of my four years of school.

As a D3 student, I able better able to understand the aspects behind patient-centered care, which I believe is a very important part of being a competent practitioner.

Ethics plays an important role in dentistry. As a healthcare provider it is important to follow the code of ethics. I understand that as a healthcare professional I have a duty to treat the patient according to their desires within the bounds of accepted treatment. Furthermore, the patient-dentist relationship should consist of trust and confidentiality. The welfare of the patient should be the dentist’s top priority.

Although dentistry is a rewarding profession it is a challenging field. Constantly, new advancements and technologies are emerging. One of the greatest challenges faced by practitioners is the advancement in the technological field. Over the years, simple procedures such as taking conventional x-rays have now become digitalized and charting has also become computerized. A patient committing to the clinic is more inclined to visit a clinic that is technologically advanced. As the world of technology expands, dentists face a challenge of keeping their clinic and knowledge in par with recent advancements. NYU offers the appropriate resources for its students to be exposed to these advancements in order to excel in the field of dentistry. It is my goal to learn about these advancements and gain knowledge to become a successful practitioner.

I feel there are certain qualities that are important to become a dental professional. In my eyes the most important is promoting oral health and disease prevention. As a professional we have a duty towards our patients to educate them on the importance of oral care. By doing this we can prevent certain conditions and diseases as well as better the general health of the public. Through my dental experience in NYU I would like to emphasize on educating and promoting oral health to every patient that I treat, since I feel that this is the duty of a dental professional. I would like to focus on this aspect of dentistry more.

As a professional we have certain responsibilities towards our patients and society in general. I feel it’s a dental professionals duty to educate the public on the importance of oral health and the way oral health impacts the general health. As a professional, it is important to keep my dental knowledge up to date to provide effective and efficient treatment to my patients. In addition, to me a professional requires certain qualities such as good interpersonal/communication skills and good work ethics.

As an advanced standing student, I have been exposed to one month of pre-clinical work at NYUCD. I feel more confident with various cavity and crown preparations. I had a chance to work with great mentors during this time and learned a lot about dentistry in this part of the world. I am looking forward to continue my education at NYU. In clinic, I am being introduced to a more hands on approach to dentistry which has helped me further broaden my knowledge in this field.

Dentistry is dynamic field full of challenges; my passion for it escalates day by day. My initial goal is to learn about the new technological advancements in dentistry and to improve my clinical skills. I am fortunate to have great mentors at NYUCD who review the patient’s medical history and discuss cases in detail. I am hoping in the next 2 years I gain the knowledge and skills to become a competent healthcare provider. My objective is to ensure that I am able to provide the best oral care for others, I possibly can.

As a professional you are required to make all types of decisions based on what is in the best interest of the patients. At the same time there can be things that you need as a student in order to graduate, but you have to be able to look past what you need, and make sure that you encourage the patient to do what is in their best interest as opposed to what is in the best interest to you as a student.

The process of becoming a professional is a challenging one, which involves patience, good communication skills, and learning from our faculty. Throughout my time here in clinic I feel like with all the hands on experience, and the practical situations that arise on an everyday basis, it gives me the chance to grow as a professional. It helps me understand what kind of challenges I will face on an everyday basis as a practicing dentist.

Working as a professional dentist for the last six months in clinic, and reflecting back on that time in clinic has allowed me to see how much I have grown as a professional in the last few months. The skills that I have developed both in terms of clinical skills and skills with interacting to patients have improved tremendously over the last few months, and I look forward to developing these skills even further as my time in clinic continues.

Over the next four years I want to first and foremost gain the clinical skills required to become the best possible practitioner. In addition I want to build strong relationships with my peers and future colleagues, and feel like a part of the NYUCD community. Also deepen my passion for dentistry by gaining the hands on experience of working with patients.

I have found the word "professional" difficult to grasp because I find myself being true to my definition of a professional which is putting the patient's needs as my priority.  However, in interacting with faculty, I have realized that they have their own version of professionalism. It is important for me to strike a balance between what I think I want my version to be, and reap from them what I like about their "professionalism" while staying true to myself.

My mission: to improve the lives of others in my community through the knowledge, artistry, and interpersonal skills/empathy reaped through education at NYU.  

I wrote this statement over two years ago, now in 2015 I still believe that this is my mission. Although, now having patient interaction--I realize it is more complicated and gray than black and white.  However, I will continue to strive to fulfill my mission.

Being an International dental student from India, getting admission in one of the best dental schools in USA is a dream come true. I feel this is an amazing opportunity to continue my dental education and excel in field of dentistry. Through two years of education, I want to hone my skills of dentistry I acquired back home. I want to be the best professional with good clinical  skills and patient management strategies. By the graduation time, I want to be a confident dentist who can effectively address and treat diverse patient population and  I am confident that through the tremendous support of faculty and great patient pool at NYUCD I can reach my goal.

Professionalism means commitment and responsibility to your own interests and striving for excellence in the field through continuous learning and practice. Every day I spend at NYU, I try to learn as much as I can and make the best use of resources available in order to become a better professional than I was before. In addition the diverse patient population we see every day prepares me to communicate and treat effectively, which helps me on  becoming a competent practitioner in the real world.

Being an International dental student from India, getting admission in one of the best dental schools in USA is a dream come true. I feel this is an amazing opportunity to continue my dental education and excel in field of dentistry. Through two years of education, I want to hone my skills of dentistry I acquired back home. I want to be the best professional with good clinical  skills and patient management strategies. I am confident that through the tremendous support of faculty and great patient pool at NYUCD I can reach my goal.

I always think there is a right answer on how to behave or on what decision to make inside your heart. I have learned alot about ethics in the last two years of dental school and hope to keep my values close to heart and make the right decisions. Treating my peers right has been important to me and plan to continue to put my self in others shoes.

The type of mentoring is unique and I want to become a better leader, dentist and human being through my studies at New York University College of Dentistry. There are some areas that I know need improvement in such as communication.

Becoming a professional means to trust yourself and to know you are working to the best of your ability. While I have grown alot since entering dental school, I still hold myself to a high standard, sometimes unrealistic. I am learning to be fair when judging myself and how to not let my own judgement of myself hold me back from growing. Comparing yourself to others is helpful at times but we all have our strength and weakness. I am working on focusing on making my strengths stronger and at the same time not letting my weakness hold me back from moving forward.

Being a professional does not only mean that you a profession. A professional is someone who conducts himself with respect and has respect for others. A dental professional should strive to do best by his patients and satisfy their needs to the best of his/her ability. A professional uses knowledge to serve the community and educates their patients each visit.

There has been alot of professional and personal progress made in the last two years, I have learned the science that will make me a competent dentist and have developed the hand skills that allow me to enter into the clinical environment. We have added so much to our repertoire and it excited me that for the next two years we will learn how to apply it to improve lives.

I look to gain the experience and knowledge which will make me a good dentist and achieve a passion that will allow me to build my interest in the profession on a day to day basis. I want to build on my career everyday and get as much information as possible so that I can make the best informed decisions for my patients.

In many ways, I am shocked that I am able to do what I do in clinic. It was one thing to do a crown prep or a restoration on a mannikin head, but it's completely different to work on a real patient. I always imagined myself working on patients, and now that it is a reality, it seems very surreal. Now that I am in the clinic, I believe I am much more competent to work in the real world. Initially, I had doubts, as do most people, but slowly these doubts faded away.

I believe that I have grown professionally. Besides being much more competent in the dental field, I believe that I am much more able to handle the stressors and expectations of dental school, as compared to my D1 year.

Ethics and morality are ever present in my mind. unfortunately we have some professionals who lack that internal compass or simply ignore it and place the patients and the profession at risk. Patients are affected by dentists that either perform unnecessary procedures, with the only intention of financial gains,  or perform procedures without proper training, unaware of their clinical competence or lack thereof. Dentist who fail to refer and instead opt to keep it in house. In the other side of the coin, colleagues are affected once the population starts changing their views towards dentists, and what our motives are.  I conduct myself in an ethical manner and hope that it will continue that way. I hope that I see patient needs first and foremost instead of a dollar sign. Patient trust is true success!
I intend to become a well versed Professional, one that patients can trust not only for themselves but also for their loved ones.
It has been a long journey but one that has gratified me in so many ways. I look forward to learning more and more here at NYU and beyond to become a well versed professional.

Becoming a knowledgeable professional for me is very important. Lots of time and effort is dedicated towards this goal. It empowers me to be able to offer options to achieve optimal oral health for my patients. Seeing gratitude in patients eyes, and in words expressed, makes the hard work put in worth the while.
I sincerely feel that my professional progress has escalated to new heights here at NYU, and only hope that this progress grows exponentially.

My goal is to become a knowledgeable and well versed dentist while continuing to be ethical, caring and compassionate towards my patients and colleagues. Although I have graduated from dental school in another country I have come to realize how much more I still need to know to become that ideal of a professional I have as a goal. Now I'm able to fill in the blanks in terms of knowledge.  Patient treatment includes much more that basic sciences, it also includes manual dexterity, ideal moral and ethical compass, and compassionate attitude towards patient's conditions.  The patient needs to feels that,  I as professional, have his/her best interest at heart to ameliorate his pain and/or "fix his chief concern".

Had our White Coat Ceremony last Friday the 30th of January, 2015. What an accomplishment, I am so proud, joyful, grateful to be here. This has truly been such a humbling experience, through everything that I went through the month of January and how hard it was for me to start this semester; I must say that the White Coat Ceremony has been the perfect ending to the start of a new year. My parents flew all the way from California, in the middle of a NYC winter to be here. Oh God, they were so happy and proud. They make me want to work harder and harder, graduate, make some money and start paying back my dues to them. The dentist pledge was such a summative statement about why I chose dentistry from the beginning, I can't wait to graduate so I can start making change where it counts, for those that need dental care so badly and cannot afford it. Ethics is such a big part of any career, but even a bigger part when you are treating patients.

I want to be a super dentist; a dentist that does everything so well. A quick, painless dentist. I want to learn my chair-side manners so well and make every patient feel good about their dental experience with me.

From July 1st to June 17... HARDEST YEAR OF MY LIFE!

I think I will look very good in those nice suits and learn how to be  part of the professionals in society. The way that I see becoming a professional is also becoming a bigger part of the community. It is incredibly important and very essential to achieving my ultimate dream in life.

Being a professional is one of my aspirations in life. It is one of the things I also appreciate about being a dentist, since this career also allows me to be a professional and a leader in my community and practice. Nonetheless, being a professional is a challenging phrase. I believe that it actually takes a lot to become a professional, since there are so many aspects to the word. Sometimes I am a little intimidated of this word, just because I would not want to claim being a professional without being certain that I possess all the characteristics of the word. It amazes me how much society values professionals and look at them with such respect. One of the aspects that I appreciate about all professionals is that the looks and dress-code of a professional matters quite a bit. The first impression you take about a professional or an individual is pretty dependent on the way they dress/look. I like that about the concept of professionalism.

It feels so good to be done with my first year of dental school, I think I have grown so much. It was an amazing year and I have learned way more than I thought I did.

Thought it felt good to finish D1.... Finishing D2 FEELS AMAZING!!!!! Clinic is going to be so much fun, learn as much as you can is my goal!

Being in clinic is such a dream it is absolutely unbelievable that I have come this far. This is the best feeling in the world to be able to do what you love, make people feel better, and live the lifestyle that I have been dreaming of all my life.

Had our White Coat Ceremony last Friday the 30th of January, 2015. What an accomplishment, I am so proud, joyful, grateful to be here. This has truly been such a humbling experience, through everything that I went through the month of January and how hard it was for me to start this semester; I must say that the White Coat Ceremony has been the perfect ending to the start of a new year. My parents flew all the way from California, in the middle of a NYC winter to be here. Oh God, they were so happy and proud. They make me want to work harder and harder, graduate, make some money and start paying back my dues to them. The dentist pledge was such a summative statement about why I chose dentistry from the beginning, I can't wait to graduate so I can start making change where it counts, for those that need dental care so badly and cannot afford it. 

What an amazing feeling to be in clinic right now. 

Best part of D2? Now. It's over!
I strongly believe that ethics is foundation for becoming a Professional and NYU teaches Ethical practice to students and I am very grateful for being part of NYU.

Initially transformation in the clinic was very tough as I entered the clinic in the middle of the academic year , but with grate support from my GPD, faculty and colleague students I feel like I belong in this clinic.

I still need to improve time management, and also how to deal with multiple things at the same time. I am working on how to prioritize things and work accordingly. I will work hard to improve in these aspects for becoming a better dentist.

Strong foundation of knowledge and skills are important for a professional but equally it is important to address a patient as a whole by being empathic, giving moral and emotional support rather than just treating the presenting dental symptoms. I have learnt to recognize a patient as person on whole rather than just treating his dental problem. 
Ethical practice is another aspect I have learnt in clinic which is a strong foundation for being a professional. 
Exposure to diverse patient population, I have had grate opportunity to improve patient management and communication skills which are necessary for my transition to be an efficient professional.

Communication skills are most important factor for success of a dentist and ones practice. Initially communication was a big hurdle for me. In clinic, my interaction with diverse patient population and fellow colleagues has improved my communication skills remarkably. Patient management has became easy with the improvement of communication skills.

I strongly believe in strong determination, motivation and hard work, which lead me to be a part in NYU dental school. Although, being an international Dentist with some practice experience back home, there are numerous things for me to learn. 
Five months in clinic has provided with immense experience and knowledge about various procedures and techniques which are important for my transformation to be a dentist in united states. I will utilize this opportunity to work with grate faculty to be a Competent Dentist by the end of my Course.

The disparity between excitement and disappointment depending on whether I was able to see a patient or not has made me realize how much I enjoy dentistry and interactions with my patients. Everyday, I am trusted by my patients to treat them with both respect and excellence. Therefore, I was able to separate my personal life from the professional environment to focus providing service to my patients. Words can't describe how gratified I am each time a patient leaves satisfied with their treatment.

During my years at NYUCD, I would like to pursue professional competency whilst remembering to give back to the community. To my peers and faculty members I would like to be an understanding and approachable individual who stays optimistic in times of adversity and perseverance.

Ethics are of utmost importance in the healthcare field. I believe that a patient's trust is earned when they know a provider is transparent and delivering the best care possible. I feel that I already have a well-established foundation and strong belief in living and working in an ethical manner. I have found it easy to apply such standards to patient care and know that my patients trust the decisions I make because of it.

I will strive to become the best dentist I can upon graduation. I hope to excel in the clinical aspect of school while working for the best grades I can in didactic courses. In clinic, I want to gain the trust of patients and create a professional relationship with them. I think that the biggest area for improvement in this is gaining and speaking with more confidence when interacting with patients. I believe that this skill will come over time as I continue to become more comfortable with being a healthcare professional.

I believe my previous work with the public as a tennis instructor has been a great help in my communication with the patients I have treated. I also feel that becoming a professional in the healthcare field is a privilege and needs to be treated as such. I will continue to work my hardest and treat patients, fellow classmates, and faculty with respect and give them my best effort. I feel more comfortable as a professional with each week and am sure this trend will continue. I think that I am only at the tip of this iceberg in this aspect of my education.

Although I am still in the early stages of becoming a professional, I have noticed myself becoming more confident in my interactions with patients. This ranges from the way I greet them to how I go about administering anesthesia and performing different procedures. I hope to continue to enhance these skills and feel good about the treatment I am giving patients. It is also very important to me to contribute to the profession of dentistry in a way that reflects positively on myself as well as my peers. I will do this by adhering to ethical standards and always doing my best for each patient.

After treating several patients I realized that I am becoming more professional with each appointment. At first I felt I was nearly faking it but now I am more confident in explaining treatments to patients as well as maintaining my composure in tough situations. I know I will continue to progress in this aspect of my dental education with each patient I see.

My goal is to become a proficient dentist who is prepared to enter the practicing world as a professional when I leave school. I will do my best to succeed in class while still maintaining time to relieve stress by exercising and exploring the city. I am taking advantage of the community surrounding NYUCD by actively participating in outreach programs in The Bronx. It has given me valuable experience in educating the public on oral hygiene and a chance to give care to those who need it. I plan to continue this throughout my remaining time at NYU.

When practice in a health professional field, we are not only regulated by our personal ethics but also by professional ethics which are principles shared among health professionals. When we practice in dentistry, we might encounter ethical dilemma in which the choices available for resolution are not pleasant. When I practice dentistry, I am committed to professionalism and meeting ethical obligations for autonomy, beneficence, nonmaleficence and justice, and should engage in health promotion.

Entering clinic is a big transition from didactic aspect of the school. After being in clinic for more than 3 months, I realized dealing with patients is more than just providing excellent dental treatment work to them. We also need to build up a good rapport with patients, establishing a trusting relationship with patients and make sure they are emotionally well too while we are providing dental care. Also, I am still learning on how to create an appropriate dental comprehensive treatment plan for patients, especially for the complex cases in which multiple problems exist. Doing dental procedures on patients is very different from doing it on mannequin in labs, so my goal is to improve my dental skills and providing appropriate comprehensive care through hard working and active learning in clinic.

After entering clinic for a few months, I believe equipping myself with competent hand skills and academic knowledge is a basic requirement of becoming a professional. Among various health care providers, dentists have relatively the most interactions with patients because during appointments, we get to know them and their background more. When seeing the patients and even outside the clinic, I think I should act professional and be respective. However, I believe the most important component of being a professional is taking responsibility for our patients and try to respect and understand patients' point of view without compromising to provide standard treatment care.

After entering clinic for a few months, I believe equipping myself with competent hand skills and academic knowledge is a basic requirement of becoming a professional. Among various health care providers, dentists have relatively the most interactions with patients because during appointments, we get to know them and their background more. When seeing the patients and even outside the clinic, I think I should act professional and be respective. However, I believe the most important component of being a professional is taking responsibility for our patients and try to respect and understand patients' point of view without compromising to provide standard treatment care.

I have entered the clinic for 7 weeks already. It is more stressful than I expected, but I am glad that I received lots of help from loving upper class students and friendly faculties. Becoming familiar with Auxium system was the first obstacle I needed to overcome with and currently I am still learning how to use it properly. In the beginning, the clinic pace was very slow but now my patient pool is gradually increasing and I learned how to do proper comprehensive check up and treatment planing. Right now, I am confident with taking radiographs, doing prophylaxis and giving anesthetic injections. However, I am still a little bit nervous of doing cavity preparation since there is a risk of exposing the pulp when caries is deep into the dentin. So far, I haven't done any endodontic and prosthetic procedures but I am planning to shadow upper class students for these procedures to become more familiarized.

Entering clinic is a big transition from didactic aspect of the school. After being in clinic for more than 3 months, I realized dealing with patients is more than just providing excellent dental treatment work to them. We also need to build up a good rapport with patients, establishing a trusting relationship with patients and make sure they are emotionally well too while we are providing dental care. Also, I am still learning on how to create an appropriate dental comprehensive treatment plan for patients, especially for the complex cases in which multiple problems exist. Doing dental procedures on patients is very different from doing it on mannequin in labs, so my goal is to improve my dental skills and providing appropriate comprehensive care through hard working and active learning in clinic.

Ethically, I have seen more gray than black or white in the recent past. With leaked exams, "shared resources" for quizzes, and people working on others' behalf, I am not sure where I stand in terms of accepting it as a reality or trying to be a pillar of opposition. I have decided to try and be the contrarian and hope to sway others in my direction without necessarily demanding that they do the same.

I believe this is an important factor when it comes to treatment planning in clinic. I have always tried to do what's right even though it did not benefit me in terms of graduation requirements but it was right for the patient.

Over the next four years, it is my desire to immerse myself in learning the various principles and disciplines of dentistry and strive for excellence in learning and applying the same. I also would like to explore different facets of dentistry and make a choice of whether I would like to specialize or become the best General Dentist practitioner I can ever be. I hope to overcome psychological obstacles of being older than several of my peers while seriously considering the path I want to take.

As an addendum, I also believe that it is my duty to make small changes to the college and people around me. I have therefore taken up the position of tutoring chair at ADEA that helps me connect my passion (film and photography) and apply it to dentistry. I will be making a series of videos with a classmate for incoming D1s.

I believe being professional is more than just being able to do a certain procedure with a minimum level of competency. I am hoping to hone my skills and want to learn how to command respect in the eyes of peers, patients and staff. I want to learn how to run a practice successfully, interact with patients effectively and treat staff fairly. In an attempt to get to that destination, I am hoping to hold myself to the highest standards possible and hope I live up to them.

So far, clinic has been rocky. I hope to steady this ship while holding my principles dear and make sure I put the patient first.

I am hoping to learn more than the bare minimum to become a competent dentist. I hope to use the dexterity this degree will provide me with, and complement it with a professional demeanor that I hope to cultivate in the years to come to provide a patient with quality healthcare services. 

I believe I have met some of my expectations in this regard and hope to grow more in the near future. I also feel that being a professional is as important as being clinically proficient to provide the best possible patient experience.

Three years later, I feel I have learnt a lot. I know there is more to learn than I can ever imagine, but I am satisfied with where I am now and thirsty for more. There are some immutable changes that I have undergone during my time here, and I hope to attack every obstacle, take every opportunity I come across and improve myself with the same intensity that I have shown recently.

More than anything, I would like to figure out where I place myself in the dental environment in the future. I still need to identify my strengths and weaknesses, likes and dislikes through seeing more cases and shadowing more. I hope to gain a better perspective on who and what I want to be in the upcoming year and a half and hope I find my answers.

As dental school progressed, at various points, I felt a cacophony of emotions from being inspired and challenged, from victorious to utterly furious, and defeated. However, at the end of it all, I feel like I have taken many steps closer to my goal of not just moulding myself into a competent and a confident dentist, but also a facilitator in the process of achieving greater health standards in the community I hope to serve. I am a changed man compared to the one that walked into this institution three years ago. I have my peers, faculty and well-wishers to thank for that. I hope that the process of learning feels as rewarding for the rest of my life as it has over the last three years.

Through the vast number of ethics lectures I have had at NYUCD, I have learned about many key ethical principles that we must always follow as dental professionals. Violation of any of these principles is a violation of ethics, and as a healthcare provider, ethics is of the utmost importance. It is very important to allow our patients to have autonomy and so we must present all treatment options along with the pros and cons so that the patient can make an informed decision about what they would like. Also, we must strive to provide the best treatment for our patients and to avoid causing them harm. By following these ethical principles, I will be a better clinician and will be able to best serve my patients in the future. There are always difficult cases where different ethical principles may come into conflict and learning how to ethically proceed is an important skill to have.

I want to continue to built my educational foundation and learn more about how best to interact with patients. To accomplish this, I periodically watch live webinars online and read up on topics related to patient communication and specific dental procedures. As I am also passionate about aesthetic dentistry, I am doing additional reading on my own time and networking with aesthetic dentists to learn as much as I can about how to deliver high quality aesthetic results for my patients.

Working towards becoming more professional can be very time consuming. However, I have to remember that by improving myself professionally, I will become a better dentist and can provide a better patient experience in the future. I have thus begun to inform myself about organizations that enhance professionalism and excellence in dentistry including ASDA, AACD and AGD. I have also taken active roles in NYU Aesthetics Society and in ASDA to become more involved in the dental field and to network with other professionals who serve as role models for myself. I have also taken many continuing education courses online to learn more than what the school teaches as providing excellent patient care means consistently updating my knowledge.

It is interesting to see how we as dental students are viewed by our patients. While I often feel like it is not my place to tell someone more than twice my age how they should be living their lives, patients have an expectation that we, as dental professionals, will tell them how to optimize their oral health. Being a professional involves possessing the correct knowledge to share with your patients in a respectful and effective manner. It is also important to dress professionally since patients can make many assumptions about a person from their appearance alone. By dressing and acting maturely, patients feel like they are in capable hands and will be open to listening to advice that is given.

Completing two years of dental school and reflecting back over the time has made me aware of the vast amount of knowledge I have acquired since the beginning of D1. It has been an amazing journey so far, and at times overwhelming. Over the past two years, I have learned a lot of didactic knowledge and have honed my skills in a simulation laboratory setting. These next two years are very exciting. I am now treating patients and learning how to interact with them appropriately as a dental professional. I am also learning how treating people is very different from working on plastic teeth on a simulated dummy. It is a wonderful change and I am enjoying the challenges that come along with it.

After spending a little over one month in clinic, I feel that I have had many new experiences. While it was scary giving my first injections to a real person, I learned that having confidence in my skills and abilities is important to both myself and to my patients. I have spent the past two years preparing to enter the clinic and I have realized that I need to have confidence in the skills that I have developed. I have also learned that it is very important to listen to the chief concerns of the patient. While I may want to provide a plethora of treatment to try and improve their oral health, by starting small and addressing their main reason for coming to see the dentist, I am able to ensure my patient experiences comfort and interest in their oral health.
I strive to act for the benefits of my patient. So far I have not had an ethical conflict.

Clinic is really challenging. I want to be competent by the time I finish school. Each struggle puts me closer to my goal. Almost everything can go wrong in some way. Patient may not show up. Supplies may run out.  All I can do is trying to be well prepared for each procedure. I can't wait to be competent.

I feel like paper work took huge amount of the time. I need to be good at treatment planning but I am not there yet. I want to get started with many procedures but I haven't been able to due to all kinds of reasons, i.e. insurance, patient not coming on time, losing patient to PG. I wish I can just focus on the work.

Like my fellow classmates, I have a sincere interest in becoming a competent dentist. I try my best to be prepared. Nonetheless there is a lot of unforeseen difficulties. Timing has been the most challenging aspect of the clinic.

Finally I learned to use axium. It still consumes huge amount of clinical time filling out every form. I learned to work with patient to improve their condition. I am now familiar with where I can get different kinds of supplies. I have done fair amount of basic procedures.

Clinic has been exciting, fun, and challenging all at the same time. I strive to be a little faster every day. There are a lot to learn. Often there is very limited amount of time, and there is so much that needs to be accomplished. There is almost always help available. I am excited to witness as each of us becomes a better clinician as the day goes by.

As a community leader, I will abide by all the ethical and legal standards that are required for a dentist during my diagnosis, treatment planning, management of patient records, and handling in special circumstances. Not only as a health care provider, I will maintain ethics as a good citizen. I understand that sometimes ethical standards are more strictly measured by public for dentists. I understand that dentists have the honor of being community leader and high figure, and therefore, I will be more mindful about my behaviors, considering its influence on the public.

I will stay on top of every course material in order to strive through rigorous dental curriculum with efficient time-management skills and diligence. I will also pay attention to balance the educational duty with social relationship with my colleagues. Training in dental school is different from that from the undergraduates, because its education involves the interpersonal skills, empathy for patients, and cooperation with colleagues. Not only the academic success as I want to continue education for specializing, I will also make sure to develop good communication skill with patients, faculties, and other student doctors.

I do not feel I am competent enough to be called professional at this moment in many aspects. Not only didactic knowledge and clinical skills of a dentist, I will be competent to be professional in time-management, communication, respect, appearance, and responsibility for the community. For now, I am lacking professional clinical skills while treating patients. But, I will do my best before the procedure to practice and be prepared for the day's procedure, in order to provide safe and thorough treatment for patients. Also, I will achieve the professional manner to treat patients with excellent communication skills.

I do have many aspects lacking to be competent for a professional at this moment. However, I am ready to absorb education, manners, communication skills along with ethics and respect for others in order to be a professional. My ability of self-assessment and accepting peer evaluation will teach me my strengths and weaknesses in order to improve myself. Likewise, for my clinical skills, I will do best to prepare for difficult procedure, perform thoroughly, and master it to achieve professional-level dental treatment skills, for both diagnosis and treatment.

As the year goes, I will self-assess myself in order to judge my strengths and weaknesses that I need to improve. As I started the clinical sessions, now I feel more that I am not competent in many aspects to be called professional, in terms of clinical skills, medical and dental knowledge, and communication skills. However, I will not be afraid of admitting my ignorance, asking what I am not certain, and improving myself to achieve the ideal dentist before graduation.

I want to be a student with thorough scientific knowledge and clinical hand skills, who can adapt criticism as a means to improve oneself and who can effectively and emotionally communicate with patients and colleagues. I will be the community leader who feels genuine empathy and responsibility for community and provides outstanding dental care to people in needs. Not only patients' dental health, but I will also be competent to evaluate the overall health of the patient in order to make thorough and safe diagnosis and treatment plans. In order to do so, I will achieve comprehensive medical health education, not isolated on oral health.

Based on what we learned throughout the orientation and the first few classes on 'Professionalism and Ethics,' a dentist requires not only the skills and knowledge as a technician and a practitioner, but also a sense of conscience and ethical background to refrain from making mistakes or maltreating patients. (2014-5)

Communication with patients is very important. And to do well, I believe there is ethics behind it. If you try to make deliberate use of your position as a dentist and make unethical decisions in clinics, there seems to be always a bad consequence following the miscommunication with patients. I will be as honest and caring to my patients, and build a trustworthy relationship with my patients for the next 2 years. (2015-6)

The primary reason why I chose dentistry as my lifetime career is because I am always fond of those who laugh unaffectedly and have big smiles on their faces at most times. And my goal here is to give them even better smiles, smiles that are not just unaffected and big, but beautiful aesthetically. For such reason, I am most interested in cosmetic dentistry, more specifically in orthodontics and orthognathia, if my grades turn out to be on that level. Also, I'd really want to continue on with my experience in chorals (singing), and probably further develop it as my second career if time permitting. (2014)

My goals became more distinct, and I am looking forward to participating in CTOR this year. I'd like to do ortho residency once I graduate, and it'd be my pride if I could achieve it during the four years at NYUCD. (2015)

Of course, making a living by doing what you learned in school or institutions is one big part of being a professional, but I believe meeting the expectations of the people who ask for our services is the more important part of being the "real" professional career-wise. I hope I can satisfy what my future patients expect of me, and I will endeavor to make it possible. (2014-5)

Becoming a professional in every career requires a deep understanding of knowledge and skills related to the field because customers (patients in our case) expect a certain amount of professionalism from the workers they consult. (2014-5)

What I felt to be professional in medical and dental field is not to make mistakes. I understand everyone is subject to making mistakes in a lifetime, but at least in dentistry I feel like I should make no mistakes because it has direct consequences in the treatment outcome. (2015-6)

Hope to see this updated in the near future! No words to say for now, but I will make records as years run on. (2014)

It has been about 3 months since we D3's started seeing patients. From what I have experienced so far, it is always a good idea not to hasten to complete diagnosis and treatment planning because you may easily neglect some findings, especially when you are doing head & neck exam. It takes time to carefully go through all that is required to do for each patient, but I realized that as you put more time and effort to the diagnostic procedures, the more you could find in patients' mouth, giving you more opportunity to perform complex procedures like fixed & removables. (2015)

I will become a dentist who really cares about patients' concerns, open-minded to criticisms from colleagues and other professionals. I will never hesitate to take in people's ideas and make improvements based on the constructive criticisms given upon me. Outside my school life, I will retain my private life, managing time and stress effectively so that my own concerns will not affect my practice in the clinics. (2014-5)

I am looking forward to developing methods of improving the field of dentistry through advancements in technology. Also I am looking for ways that I can be a community advocate for oral health in my surrounding community. I also want to develop new business models in the field. Also try to find what really interests me in dentistry, specifically in research and in new developments in the equipment of dental field.

My goal in the next two years is develop the theoretical, clinical and ethical skills that I need to be an advocate for oral health. I look forward to being a committed member of  outreach programs and organizations that provide such advocacy. Also, I plan to discover new clinical and technological developments in the field of dentistry. I also look forward to find ways to change the field of dentistry in various business models. I also try to find what really interests me in the general field of the healthcare.

I am disappointed that there have been problems with cheating on tests and exams within my class. I think there should be stricter punishments for being caught as I think it devalues the dental education when people are able to continue these habits and not face consequences.

I am also concerned with how people treat patients. I recognize that the school puts pressures on us. In order to graduate on time we have MDR requirements and certain number of CEEs to complete. I do think we must think of patients first. It's not ethically sounds to see a patient as CEEs before seeing the patient as a person first. 

In addition, I think that nonmaleficence, first do no harm should also have environmental considerations. I think as responsible health care profressionals we should also be educated on the impact of our work on the environment. Environmental health impacts our patients health. The waste and materials used in dentistry should be more critically looked at to ensure we are not doing harm to our current and future patients.

I had initially hoped to get involved in the Survivors of Torture Program as a D4 elective. Since then I have felt like I had more of an interest in faculty practice and oral medicine. I do not intend on doing a general practice residency so I think faculty practice would act almost as a mini residency to allow me to see many patients in a single day and allow me to increase my speed and efficiency when treating patients. I have an interest in oral medicine as I have gained a lot of respect for the faculty that run the elective as they have been great professors in OMPR and General Pathology. I also have a history of cancer in my family and feel like I would be good empathizing with patients who have a suspicious lesion and have come in for a biopsy.
 I have looked into pediatrics as I completed 6 month clinic observation at Bellevue. I do however think this may be something I consider after I have practiced for a few years. Due to financial constraints and anxiousness to get out of school and get into practice, I will put this off and reevaluate in a few years whether it is something I would like to commit to.

I find the greatest challenge for me in my best attempt to be a professional is my nervousness and cautious nature when it comes to treating patients. I am not at my best if I don't feel confident and it is really challenging to feel confident when you're trying to complete a task you have only done once or twice before. I don't think nervousness and professional go hand in hand. A patient needs to feel like they trust in their doctor and if they aren't confident in themselves how can they be confident in the doctor? I have overcome this with really developing strong relationships with my patients. I think they understand that I am very knowledgeable and that I am cautious as I do not want to make a mistake (and this stems from my interest in offering them the best possible care) and through this they are able to have trust in me. I would much prefer if I could be confident in myself and be able to stay calm during a procedure but that will come with time and experience. I am confident that my nervousness will be reduced with time as it has already reduced in the passing months.

I intend to conduct myself in an ethical and moral manner inside and outside of the dentistry profession. I need to show up early, be prepared and always do a through, organized step by step evaluation of the patient and his/her needs.

The definition of a professional is simple to state but really challenging to follow through on with every single patient in every single circumstance. Some days are harder than others, you're frustrated, you have challenges outside of the clinic that are on your mind. I think a professional is someone who really tries their best to uphold a standard but recognizes his/her short comings. A professional knows when to step away from a situation and breathe and manage a situation to the best of their ability recognizing the difficulty.

I have worked hard in D1 academically and I was also able to make a lot of connections through my work as D1 Greening Rep. I hope to shadow more in clinics in the next year.

I have been given the opportunity to explore sustainable dentistry. I spoke at an ASDA conference about this topic and am presenting at the EUEC conference to discuss how environmental health affects our patients health.

I have been doing clinic observation since February at Bellevue in the pediatric dental clinic and looking into pediatrics as a specialization. 

I am a secretary in the interdisciplinary education group- I am learning how important interdisciplinary work really is in detecting errors and finding a holistic care for the patient.

My intentions as a future dentist are to promote happiness, health and overall wellness in the lives of individuals as well as the greater community. Over the next years, I hope to gain valuable knowledge and a skills set that will support this intention. I desire to become a confident and competent professional by growing alongside my colleagues and self-improving along the way. I will seek a balanced lifestyle and aspire to be the best I can be.  I also intend to have an active role in the NYU community specifically in the realm of environmental conservation and sustainability.

The ethical challenges I've faced in the clinic have more to do with red tape, bureaucracy and policy than my patient interactions. It is interesting how the system at NYU sets you up in a way which makes doing things by the book much harder. I think it's excessive but I've learned that it's much easier in the end to follow the rules. Regarding patients, my best practice is to make highly detailed notes about everything discussed.

I feel like I am getting much more comfortable in the clinic setting now that my initial frustration from being inexperienced has faded with time. Now my biggest challenges are time management, patient management, and staying organized about clinical requirements. It's hard not to get swept up in clinic and forget that there are certain requirements and studying that has to be done outside of that. I often wish I could just focus on treating my patients rather than have the stress of formatives, competencies, and exams over my head. I really enjoy working with patients and I've learned so much in the first few months in clinic. I'm proud of the amount I have accomplished but I'm looking forward to learning even more in the months ahead.

I feel that I'm getting a better handle of the flow of clinic and how to manage patients. Efficiency is something you have to pick up on early and learning how to maximize your time with each patient is essential. I've gotten better but there is still room for improvement. I also need to work on defining my duty as a professional to patients especially regarding policies and financial information. While it's something we need to acknowledge I can't feel guilty about it every time.

I feel the past few months have allowed me to settle into seeing myself as a healthcare professional comfortably, although I still stumble when trying to make the distinction to my patients that while I'm their healthcare provider, I am still a student and don't have the full authority of a dentist. This can manifest in even the simplest things, like asking them to call me Dr. Lui or referring to my colleagues as doctors in front of them. I've decided it's better to err on the side of being more of a professional than a student, but it will take time for me to make it an unconscious habit.

I have been working on visualizing how I would want the perfect dentist to treat me; someone who is confident in their skills but down to earth enough to treat their patients as equals or at least have the patience to explain things clearly. It is definitely a challenge to do so using Spanish as well but I have been working on my vocabulary, both dental and conversational.

I want to learn as much as I can about providing my patients the best care possible and mastering techniques which will allow me to formulate and deliver comprehensive treatment plans for my patients. I want to be able to competently diagnose caries, endodontic involvement, periodontal disease, and other oral diseases. I hope to create meaningful relationships with my patients, colleagues, and faculty and establish myself as a colleague who is competent, trustworthy, and helpful.

We've learned about a lot of varying procedures, which can be great in ideal circumstances, but now that we enter clinic, there's not going to be any ideal circumstances or clear answers. I've been surprised how honest and candid some of my patients have been with me, and they put a huge amount of trust into me. I think it would be unethical for me to try and perform a procedure that I know I am not skilled at just to get CEs or MDRs.

I recently started to panic since it seemed that despite my best efforts, I was lacking in treating patients who needed restorative procedures. How crazy is that? I should in theory be thrilled that my patients need slight maintenance care like a regular prophy, or replacing some worn sealants. Instead, I was worried that my patients didn't have enough disease. 
I hope that in the real world, my patients will be healthy and maintain their oral health, and that I can also make an income providing preventative services. If this is realistic, I don't actually know. But I hope so.

I'm still working on becoming more professional. It seemed that during this year our environment was more relaxed in a lot of ways because the work load was so intense. I am good at being on time and I will avoid having my patient wait for me at all costs, but I've gotten used to looking a bit disheveled during the year, maybe procrastinating with certain things, misplacing things, all of which need to stop now.
Sometimes you just have to fake it til you make it. I'm honestly so nervous doing procedures for the first time, but I have to put on a reassuring, confident attitude.

Now that we're in clinic, I can truly appreciate the importance of being on time, to set up for your patient, to not keep them waiting and to maximize your time. I can understand how physical appearance and mannerisms can affect patients. Many of the people who come to see us are nervous, uncomfortable and truly scared, and it can be reassuring to see someone who presents themselves as a professional.
One thing I'm noticing is that I think I might be apologizing too much. I'm so unsure of everything I'm doing. I know how to do a class II, definitely. But I don't know if the specific way I'm holding my hand, or bur is hurting the patient, etc. I keep asking patients if they're ok or if something hurts. I feel like it might be too much, as if I'm portraying a lack of confidence.

I'm honestly not sure on how much professional progress I've made so far. Ive been so focused on academics and just trying to make it through D2 that it doesn't feel like I've grown that much professionally. Honestly, in the three days I've been in clinic full time, I feel like I've grown so much more than in the past year. I used to dress casually, misplace materials, etc but now I've become incredibly aware how my actions and appearance can cause my patients to doubt me, or even scare them.

So now I've been in clinic for 7 weeks or so and I'm building confidence. I try and look put together, and get here early to set up and come up with a general game plan for the appointment even if its just a cleaning. Clinic can get so hectic that I feel if your not completely on top of things, everything can start to fall apart and its a mess.

Now that I've finally experienced my first few days of clinic, I think my idea of the kind of dentist I want to be has started to change. I've been so focused on the past two years on the test ahead of me, on passing that next practical, that I was starting to forget why I was here. There's nothing inherently wrong in wanting to do well academically and get 1s on your practicals, but I want to provide my patients with the best possible treatment, I want to perform work that will perserve their function, please them esthetically, keep them out of pain and last. Also, I'm noticing how hard it is to be focused on keeping your patient comfortable while your running around clinic, or staring closely at one particular surface, etc., and I hope to become the kind of practitioner that always stays aware of my patients comfort, happiness and feelings

As a student in a professional school, I feel like it is of genuine importance to stick to the ethical values we have learned over the course of our dental careers and lives. In the clinic, we are given many different requirements we need to meet by the end of the school year. When treating patients the easy way out would be to just think about ourselves and the our requirements. However, as a professional, we know that is not the right thing to do. As a professional, I feel like my number one priority is always to do good and always treat my patients for their best interests.

In order to become a professional in dental school, I will strive to acquire high level of skills and knowledge. I will also learn and apply ethical principles throughout the next four years in dental school. It is very important to be able to assess ourselves as professionals, as well as know how to take advice from others, when it is given in a respectful manner. I feel like I need to work on my timing, that I need to become faster at doing some procedures.

Over the last few months in clinic, I feel like I am improving significantly as a clinician. I remember my first weeks in clinic that I was  so overwhelmed about the idea of treating patients. As months have passed by, I have noticed that now I enjoy being challenged everyday in clinic, such as doing new procedures. What I would like to get better at in the months to come, would be to become faster at doing procedures, at the same time without compromising the quality of my work.

After completing my second year of dental school, I have come to realize how far my knowledge of the field has come. This motivates me and prepares me for the following years. During my third and fourth year I would like to be more involved in community service activities with the school, and even go in an international outreach.
I will always be ethical and honest in my decisions in clinic. I want to establish myself as a main in integrity and someone that people can count on and trust.

Clinic has been everything I hoped it would be. I love it! I have learned so much and being able to actually apply the knowledge I learned in the past helps me retain it better. I want to be establish myself as one of the hardest working individuals in clinic. I will never be afraid to ask a question on something because I think the only stupid question is the question that is not asked. I am here to learn first and foremost. I love being around my patients and interacting a healthcare team. I want to continue to grow and become a great dentist that people will want to go to in the future. Everything so far has been terrific and I am glad I am in this clinic!

Clinic is everything that I hoped it would be. I cant express how much I love being in clinic and being around the people I have in my clinic. The first two years of dental school were a little rough and not very exciting. I love helping my patients, I love interacting as a healthcare team, I love everything so far about clinic. I have learned so much in these past few months with knowledge I will be able to retain. I am a very visual and hands on person and being able to actually apply stuff I learn makes me retain information and learn it better.

Becoming a professional and finally treating patients has been a wonderful experience. I will always try and be professional to my patients and give them the care they deserve. I hold myself to a higher regard and my patients always hold me to a higher regard so I will always try and give my patients the best possible treatment and care that I can.
I hope to become the best dentist I can become and will always give my best effort in everything I do. I will always put my patients first.

During my last two years in dental school at NYUCD, I want to continue to learn to become the best possible dentist I can. I want to establish myself as one of the hardest workers and most passionate people.
