I will strive to achieve this goals along with my healthcare team so we can push one another to all becoming great dentists by the time we graduate.

There are many times that I face ethical dilemmas when treating patients in clinic. Most of the time, it is related to the best care treatment vs. ability to afford the care. For example, I had a patient who had a root canal treatment done and a composite filling on top of it and her composite filling was partially broken on mesiolingual portion. Upon evaluation, the best care will be getting a crown for that tooth so that the tooth is not at risk of being fractured. However, she reports that it's only been one and a half years since she received this treatment in our school by a previous student dentist and she cannot afford the cost of a crown.

For remaining one and a half years of dental school, I would like to treat as many patients as possible and to experience as many and diverse cases as possible so that I can become fully competent when I graduate from NYUCD. I would also like to have a rapport with my patients as I am treating them and I hope to build up more solid and closer friendship with collegues. I am very grateful for having faculty members who are caring, passionate, and respectful in our clinic. Thus, I am not only learning dental procedures from them, but I am also learning about their good attitude, communication skills, ways to deal with patients, and much more.
As I completed more than two years of dental school, I feel becoming a professional in dentistry is rewarding yet challenging physically, emotionally, and mentally.

After experiencing clinics for almost six months now, I feel a lot more comfortable dealing with patients and become able to handle assigned sessions more effectively. In the beginning, I was very nervous to meet new patients and was not able to finish plans for the day within a time, thus I used to book double sessions so that I can get something done for the patient at least. Even now, I am not completely comfortable to meet new patients or perform new procedures, but I am getting better at managing time and treating patients now.

Last year, I stated that my goals over the next four years of dental school are to become competent enough to treat my patients with confidence, to build up a solid network with peers, alumni, and faculty members, and to develop professional, yet empathetic communication skills and I am glad that I am getting closer to what I desired to achieve after completing D1 and D2 courses. Especially after experiencing clinics for nearly half year, I feel much more comfortable in treating patients and communicating with them. Even if I am still not fully competent, I am satisfied with the fact that I am learning something everyday and slowly getting better at treating patients.
I want to practice dentistry making ethical decisions so that I can maintain my self integrity and also so that I can make the best decisions for my patient.

During my four years at NYU, I hope to put forth my best effort in didactic studies and utilize all that knowledge in practice. I want to make sure I get the most out of my four years at the school so I can become the best dentist that I can become. I hope to practice my communication skills and build a good work ethic to ultimately become a competent and reliable professional.
I feel much more confident in my clinical ability as well as my ability to connect and communicate with people. I know I will learn much more in the following year, but I am pleased with my progress.

I feel it is of utmost importance for a dentist not just to provide excellent oral healthcare, but also to be a professional. To me, dentists are role models for the rest of the community as they must uphold great responsibility and moral integrity. As much as I wanted my very own "white coat", I agree with NYUCD's decision to postpone the white coat ceremony till second year. I definitely think that it takes time and effort to become a professional. Ultimately, I hope to become a dentist and future professional whom my patients can comfortably rely on.

I feel I have come a long way thus far, even though it has only been one year since I started dental school. I feel much more confident in my clinical ability as well as my ability to communicate with patients and my fellow classmates and professors.

Update (9/26/15): I feel much more confident in my clinical abilities compared to when I was a D1. I did a tooth colored only prep and temp (for the competency) and I was happy with the results. Before taking the competency, I wasn't nervous at all (compared to when I was a nervous wreck during D1 before practicals), because I was much more confident. I have still much to learn and practice, but I am happy with how I am progressing.

During my four years at NYU, I hope to put forth my best effort in didactic studies and utilize all that knowledge in practice. I want to make sure I get the most out of my four years at the school so I can become the best dentist that I can become. I hope to practice my communication skills and build a good work ethic to ultimately become not only a competent and reliable professional, but one that consistently strives and provides excellence to my patients.

Being ethically competent takes a lot of effort and consideration. Each patient is unique and has unique background, cultural experience and ethical values. It is my obligation to find out as much as possible about the patient to provide ethically best possible patient care.

I want to grow as an individual to better understand people and their needs, and be able to balance myself emotionally. I want to learn time management skills to be able to actively participate in research, outreach programs, and have leadership positions along with achieving excellence in my studies. I aim to succeed in establishing relationships with colleagues, patients and community and use all the resources available to better serve my community. Through lifelong learning, I hope to be a competent dentist, and gain the trust of my patients and colleagues through my hard work. My ultimate goal is to teach in dentistry and have my private organization which will address people in need.

My goal is to gain the trust and respect of my patients, colleagues, and people surrounding me in my way of becoming a professional. I want to challenge myself with different patient cases which will let me continually learn and self improve as a health care practitioner.

My goal is to be a competent health care provider, who is able to solve all the problems that any of the patients might experience through effective communication with other health care specialists and colleagues, best treatment plan and best ethical consideration. Meanwhile, I try to learn as much as I can from the faculty. Faculty are mu role models for the kind of dentist I want to become.

Dental school has been very challenging last 2 years.However, due to my hard work and dedication, I was able to continually improve my hand skills and learning skills, and throughout the time became better academically and clinically.

My goal is to achieve excellence in patient care by gaining the best possible hand skill experiences and improving my ability to effectively communicate with people from different cultural backgrounds. I want to be an active explorer in dental field by participating in dental research  and different outreach programs. As a dental student I am aiming to contribute to the school and dental profession  with my  gained knowledge, experiences and unique cultural background.

Over the next two years, I want to be academically successful but also know that I embraced the opportunities outside of academics. In the past I've been content with being just a bit above average, but I feel like I am in a point in my life where I would like to excel so I never feel held back by things I "could've done differently". I'd like to be someone who is known as someone who gets things done, and is confident in her abilities.

For me, becoming a professional is constantly seeing knowledge and furthering myself in a certain field. I think that its hard to say that over the next year and a half I will learn everything I will need to be a competent practitioner, so my goal is to try to learn everything I can in school, but continue my quest for knowledge as I move on in my career so that I am always up to date on the latest studies and technologies. I want to provide the best most appropriate care for my patients, and constantly educating myself is the only way I will get there

Being a professional in any field signifies that there has a been a commitment made to gain the knowledge to be proficient, with dedication to constantly learn and improve yourself in that field. Once I graduate from dental school, I will have this basic set of knowledge in the field of dentistry that I need to continue to build upon and grow. I also feel that as a professional of dentistry it is important to dedicate yourself to growing the field, so that it does not become stagnant and obsolete.

Over the next two year I have many goals I would like to aim towards. I would like to gain a well-rounded view of the world. I want to live a more balanced life, where I take control of my study habits while incorporating a healthy active lifestyle. I want to gain confidence in my abilities to a level where I am not afraid to display my skills. I want to stop having regrets by embracing new experiences and utilizing resources available to the best of my ability. I want to actually feel like I gave a 100% to the challenges I'm faced with, and be content with giving it my all. I want to be mentally challenged and know that I can take it and be successful.

I follow the 'Golden Rule'. Treat others as I would want to be treated. Also I would never ask others to do things that I'm not willing to do myself, even if 'it's in the rule book'. 

I've seen other students on the 4th floor done some unethical things to each other. I supposed that they are stressed and behaved defensively. I don't want to mistreat other people, because it's not a nice thing to do. I will stay focus and work hard and stay out of people's way. I will show everyone respect and speak politely, to those who shows me respect.

I want to get the DDS degree and move one with my life. Now that I've been in clinic for 6 months. I realized that there are so many things that I don't know; the more I know the more I know that I don't know much. My goal for the remainder of my DDS education is to learn as much as I can before I graduate. Dental schools only give foundational knowledge to students, the students have to be a proactive, and life long students to stay relevant in the ever changing dental field.

As I had stated above, becoming a professional means that I should be willing to learn from other people. The lessons that I take home at the end of the day should be able to mold me into a more mature, respectful, and knowledgable student/dentist. Being a professional takes hard work. It takes a lot of self-awareness and discipline to behave in a manner that is consistent with NYUCD's policies, as well as satisfying patients' expectations. There were times when I acted in ways that I thought were slightly off setting from NYUCD's policies. I felt regret for my mistakes. Yet, at the same time these mistakes were chances that helped me improve myself. I guess becoming a professional is something that takes time and a lot of hard work. I am constantly trying to be a better healthcare professional. With the help of my faculty and peers I will be a well trained dentists who takes care of patients to the best of my abilities.

When a person becomes a professional that person must assume responsibility for his/her actions. I believe that the rest will take care of itself. Being a professional means that the student is willing to work well with other students, faculty, and patients, while showing respect and and courtesy, in order to achieve the highest possible academic and clinical learning standards possible. I'm working on becoming a better professional everyday, but there are a lot to learn; both from myself and from my peers. Please help me and teach me, and together we'll help everyone learn.

I'd like to think I've made progress of becoming a professional. But I'll let me friends judge me on becoming a professional. As a student-dentist who is working to becoming a dental professional, I'd have to say that the road getting to the goal of being an efficient, self-aware, knowledgeable dental professional is hard. It's definitely doable, because many dentists (faculty, doctors whom I've shadowed) are the epitome of these standards. As for myself, I can only focus on the immediate future and strive to behave in ways that would make me a decent professional. I've certainly made progress if I compare the Landon 6 months ago versus the Landon at this moment, but like I said there's a long way to go.

The experience that I have learned from being a student at NYUCD has helped me grow so much during these past couple of years. My time at NYUCD thus far has taught me a valuable lesson, which is if I want to become a compassionate, and very good dentist I will have to become an active-life-long-learner. There are so much to learn from the faculty and my colleagues, yet there are so little time. It is my sincere goal that by the time I graduate from NYUCD I will have grown into a wiser, compassionate, a more prepare dentists who can meet any challenges that come my way in private practice. With the help of my colleagues, friends, family, and most importantly Dr. Resnick, I am confident that these two coming years will be the most productive years in dental school.
How deep are my ethical roots?

In the next four years I wouldl like to become a better person. 
I would like to learn a skill, or a tool that I can use to help people to restore something that 
is lost, or to help people to fix something that is broken. I would also like to lay down 
a foundation for becoming somebody greater than general dental practitioner. My second goal 
is to build up professional framework not only with my peers (future collegues), but also with faculty, 
advisors and patients. I would also like to achieve a social status so that I can become a part 
of a social group that shares the same values and principles. Last but not least, I would like 
my family to be proud of me and my children to look up to me as an example of success.

I definitely gained more confidence in my actions and words. I would attribute it to both becoming a parent and two years of dental school. In order for me to have an influence on people's health, to make a positive change in their lives, I have to be more assertive in the way I treat patients. When patients come to me and see young student dentist, I am immediately faced with their mistrust. This is something that I can't change, but I can work on improving my self presentation and the delivery of treatment. Actions speak louder than words.

For a while I have been thinking that becoming a professional means to learn some singular skill to its perfection. Second year into dental school changed my perception on the definition of profession. My profession requires a lot of interpersonal skills as well. I have already learned how to be a good scientist, not I need to learn how to deliver exceptional care to my patients. I owe it to them and to my profession to adapt by investing into work ethics. 
I wish I could say things slow down, that we regain our ability to learn in a humble manner. But instead we only seem to adapt to this brutal pace, pushing on to the finish line of graduation. Often times, in a rush to complete a treatment I forget that there is a patient behind this treatment.

I am making progress at the expedite pace. I am certain that I can keep this pace for two or three more years. Once I am out there on my own, I would like to be still making progress at the same speed though it might be challanging.

I would like to learn a skill, a tool, a method; that I can use to help to restore for people something precious and vital that they lost, or broke. Use what I learned to ameliorate their pain, discomfort, embarrassment, or disease.
I would like to continue reinforcing the foundation I started earlier in Genomic research, so that I can also introduce personalized therapies into my future clinic, thereby increasing the potential for successful treatment, reduce wasteful expenditure, and prevent prolonged suffering.
I am focused on expanding my professional network, not only with my new peers (future colleagues), but also with the faculty, advisors, and patients I will be working with. I believe the right connections should foster opportunities, inside and outside Academia, to unite with others who share the same values and principles as me; to create a healthier, happier, and more productive planet.

ethics in dental school is a really tough issue. the first two years of dental school are full of tests and practicals. your life is about making sure you pass everything. that is the only goal and the only thing that matters. ethics can be pushed aside in this cut throat and selfish environement. But then, at the end of third year, we are thrown into clinic. I clinic it is not about you, it is not about passing a test. once you enter clinic everything is about the patient, or it should be. NYU gives its students a lot of requirements and a lot of different kinds of requirements. that creates a situation where a student can benefit from behaving unethically towards patients. this is not acceptable. once one loses the ability to use ethics and do the right thing, it becomes really hard to enter a profession where people have to trust you for you to do your job. you do not want to be in an environment where you learn unethical behavior to get ahead. in the real world there are not dental school requirements. there is a human being coming to you to help them, you'd better behave appropriately.

I think it will be important to understand dental theory as well as possessing technical skills in order to be the best dentist I can be. I would like to be able to find time to serve the dental needs of my community not only while I am a student at NYU, but also when I am a practicing dentist, even though this may mean needing to sacrifice time and money. I think the dentistry can greatly impact an individual’s life and I would like to be able to help people who may not have the means to get the treatment they deserve. I would like to be kind and clear to my patients. The dentist I shadowed before coming to school is incredibly compassionate and I strive to be a dentist like him. A goal I have during school is to still make time for myself outside of studying. I would like to be able to maintain my relationships and be able to work out while still learning how to be an excellent dentist.

Professionalism is an interesting concept. we are told from day one at nyu that we know are part of the dental profession and that we must always conduct ourselves as professionals. if a dentist does anything bad (shooting lions, bad case of road rage, using known dirty needles), it reflects poorly on all of us and all members of the dental community suffer from one person's actions. By becoming a student at NYU we instantly became a part of the small community of dentists. It is important to be professional so that we have the respect and trust of our patients. If our patients do not trust and respect us they will start taking their dental health into their own hands and oral health will decline. we also need to be professional so that other dentists can be proud of the profession we are all a part of.

I think I am making a lot of progress to being a professional. I understand so much more about dentistry now than when I arrived at dental school. I am really learning that there are times when you just need to put your nose down and work as hard as you possibly can. I feel like dental school is about to be very different. We are through with a lot of our courses and beginning the transition to clinic. Its crazy to think that the time has finally come where we will be seeing patients and actually functioning like dentists, but I think I am ready for the transition. Mastering how to be a student is different than mastering how to be a dentist. I think now is the time when we will really learn if we know how to be dentists.

My goal as a dental provider is do perform excellent dentistry and be someone my patients feel they can trust and be someone that makes my patients feel comfortable when they are in my chair. Starting clinic I am learning that it is not always obvious what I making  patient concerned. I want to be the sort of dentist who does not have anxious patients. I know this is a touch goal and maybe one that cannot be achieved, but it is something I want to strive for none the less. I also think it is important do perform good, ethical work. In clinic at school this is somewhat difficult because so many procedures we are doing for the first time. I am really going to work hard to make sure that my first time is my very best. I just hope that with time and practice my very best becomes excellent.

I vow to utilize the skills and knowledge learned in ethics class in order to act in a professional and ethical manner at all times during clinic and school. This includes being honest, trustworthy, and a responsible professional.  In clinic I have learned that you have to put the patients needs and health first over our own needs/school requirements because healthcare should be patient centered.  We in 4CDA are taught to be patient centered as evidenced in the Jonie video made by a graduate of 4CDA.

Becoming a professional means understanding the needs of the patient and providing the best care possible for them.  It comes through experience and knowledge gained from class and clinic.  A professional is someone who comes prepared, is on time, takes responsibility, and does whats best for the patient.

After two years of didactics and simulation labs, I have come to learn that that what we learned to be "ideal" in simulation does not always transfer to clinic.  While a lot of the principles of dentistry still apply, I've learned that in treating real patients we have to augment what we consider to be the ideal treatment because there really is none.  We make clinical decisions based on whats best for the patient, take into account what they want, and assess what they can financially pay for.  I feel that I have made strides in being able to professionally present myself to patients and offering the best care, but I feel there is room to grow and much more learn as I treat more patients.

My goal at NYU is to become a proficient dentist that will utilize the skills and knowledge learned here to provide the best patient care.  I want to be able to ensure the best patient care by being adept clinically and be able to teach patients the importance of oral care in a professional manner.  I aspire to able to participate in community outreach and be involved in educating and improving dental care in the community.   I expect NYU to challenge me to constantly improve myself not only as a dentist, but as a person.  I hope to uphold the high standards of NYU and demonstrate myself to be a motivated, intelligent, and caring dental professional.  As I continue to work within clinic, I am constantly learning what it means to be a professional and what it means to provide care.  The faculty have done a tremendous job in my growth and I hope to become competent in treating patients.  In the next year and half, I will strive to work hard and learn as much as I can.
It is important to have a knowledge of the principles of ethics and professionalism in order to be a successful dentist.

I believe becoming a professional requires being proficient and competent in many skills. It is important to have good manual dexterity, a knowledge of the basic sciences, health promotion, disease prevention and know how to treatment plan.

For the past two years, I learned a lot in dental school. From anatomy, physiology, biochemistry in D1 to microbiology and pathology in D2, its been a tough road the first two years. In bench and sim lab I learned how to drill teeth, including Class I-V preps, crown preps, and bridge preps. I learned the process of fabricating complete and removable partial dentures for both arches. Looking forward to 3rd year, I would like to utilize the knowledge and skills I learned from the first two years and apply them to patient care, which is important to be a competent dentist.

My goal throughout dental school is to develop the skills needed to become a successful dentist and gain competence in the field. I want to develop better skills in manual dexterity, how to interact with patients and great patient care. I want to interact with patients on a personal level and become the best dentist I can be.

After 4 months of clinic, I have learned and grew a lot. There were good times and down times in the clinic. Sometime patients can be really nice, and procedures can go really well. However, sometimes everything is just not going the way you wanted. When patients are experiencing pain and giving you attitude;when they are complaining about how slow this is;when X-ray machines were not working. These are all the things could go wrong. When all of these things come together, I will get really upset and depressed.

I'm going to try and use this as a kind of journal of my learning experiences in the clinic.
I didn't get a chance to write anything for the past few weeks, so I will try to sum it up.
-July and August:
I started getting used to the way the clinic works and how axium works. I saw/felt what caries is. I learned (and am still learning) how to correctly identify caries based on the ICDAS system.
I learned that a restoration needs to be redone if the explorer 'sticks' by the margins of the restoration. I also learned that, based on color, you can have a 'leaky' restoration even if the margins seem to be in-tact (I'm still not so clear on this). But if the margins have a tight seal and the radiograph shows a radiolucency under the restoration, we need to think about what this might be other than caries.
I also learned how to cut off a crown when it becomes locked on a tooth (Dr. Moghadam was kind enough to sit and do it with me).
-Week of 8/31
I learned that grinding/clenching can be a cause of widened PDL and not automatically an endo problem.
-Week of 9/7
In oral surgery rotation and learned how to use extraction tools and how to properly extract a tooth.
-Week of 9/14
-I need to brush up on the differences and indications for when to use a prefab crown and when to use a cast post-core crown.

This is my first "real" entry into my eportfolio.  I really like the idea of just being totally candid and honest in this private space and being able to look back on my journal of thoughts upon graduation. 

At this point in the year I am just glad to have my boards done and behind me.  I am a little nervous about the results but ultimately think that I passed..

I have seen a few tv shows lately (The Knick on HBOGO ((highly recommend it))) and seen a few inspirational quotes that have really had an impact on my approach to how I want to practice.  The fictional characters and real role models that inspire me most are the ones that most tenaciously uphold their responsibilities to their patients.  While we don't face the same grave consequences of surgeons, we do have the EXACT same obligation to demand perfection of ourselves in all aspects of patient treatment.

In dental school, dental career, and in life general, I will strive to progress to be the best person that I can be. Its been couple months since we had started clinic. I feel very comfortable getting to know the patient and making them at ease. I have grown more comfortable navigating and manipulating the axium. I have also come over my fear of injecting anesthesia and now can numb the area with no trouble. However, I still have difficulties making sure I have removed caries completely and some times have hard time distinguishing the remaining caries. I hope to work on correct diagnosis of the patient and coming up with a correct treatment plan. i also hope to work on working in a speedy manner.

Clinic update 9/25
We were taught that dental and medical school students, as well as practitioners, tend to become less empathetic to patients as time goes by. I didn't think it would happen to me, especially not this soon, but I am noticing a slight change in myself (particularly when there is a time constraint) in taking the time to empathize with a patient. I tend to think more and more that their dental or health problems are a result of their own neglect rather than unfortunate circumstances. I think this is called fundamental attribution error. The change isn't severe and isn't chronic, but I hope it does not progress much further or at least I am able to recognize when it does.

Clinic update 8/7/15

For whatever reason, the vast majority of my active patients are Spanish-speaking. This has forced me, in a good way, to *have* to improve my Spanish and prepare ahead of time. Minoring in Spanish turned out to be a crucial foundation for me as it has opened up a huge opportunity to communicate and connect with the Spanish speaking community, in clinic and in New York.

National Boards done. Passed, thank God. I really did not feel great after I took the exam, albeit I thought I probably did well enough to pass.  
Anyway, I'm not officially in third year, very exciting. Working in the clinic and learning actual, hands-on dentistry is the best thing ever; exactly what I signed up for. Enough with the extracurriculars. A bit harsh perhaps? Maybe, but personally, I am done with anything that does not involve learning to become a better care provider. I'll do whatever I need to do to graduate. I'll grab every opportunity to do and learn something new, see a new patient, accept any challenges that come my way.

The NYUCD clinic is great in that it gives me a great opportunity to work with a diverse patient population. I feel that I have become culturally aware. 
I believe that I have made great strides in becoming a better, and more professional communicator. Of course, there is always room for improvement. For instance, one faculty member pointed out that she felt my posture when speaking to patients exudes arrogance. Specifically, she said that I sometimes stand with my arms folded, or on my hips, and that may seem condescending to patients. Although my patient feedback has been excellent - I feel that I develop a great rapport with my patients - I still took her words into consideration and am much more conscious of my stance when speaking to patients.

In general, I strive to be a very positive person, both with myself and with others. I find that even when I'm not really feeling up to it, staying positive really makes any situation better, and makes it easier to deal with difficult people and situations. 
Some aspects of school life can be very frustrating at times, especially being a commuting parent and having to leave home at 5:15am to attend 7ams (more on that a different time). I've come a long way in dental school and in life, and the key is not to ever stress over a situation which is beyond my control. Stressing will only block me from thinking with a clear mind.

Through dental school I want to keep setting goals and accomplish them one by one. I hope to not get too overwhelmed but work hard on all these goals and desires so that I can become the best dentist possible. 
            1. Become a skilled and accredited dentist and confident in my work , develop my own style and technique 
            2. Don’t forget that patient needs are the most important and come out with the ability to provide compassionate care (patient-centered care) in any environment  
            3. Find my passion within dentistry, explore 
            4. Interpersonal skills, develop connections, network, join clubs, participate in activities
            5. Love what I am doing everyday and reflect on why it is important to me and who I have helped in that day and who has helped me 
            6. Keep setting goals in dentistry and running, combine my leadership skills into my time at dental school, inspire people through this leadership
            7. Don’t forget about the people who support you- husband, family, friends. Really give back and reach out to the surrounding community your love and knowledge of dentistry to make the world a better place.

I hope to be an ethical dentist. I think ethics is a good/important quality for dentists. It reflects on my integrity as a whole. I think it is important to keep your word as a dentist, by being honest with patients and having strong morals and core values. A good practice should be founded on those principles in order to best serve the needs of the patients.

I think while we have this ethical responsibility to the patient, they also have some sort of ethical responsibility to us to tell us the whole truth. Some patients clearly don't floss and come to clinic lying about flossing. However, I do believe as a good dentist, I should teach them the proper OHI and flossing so they can do it in case they want to change. It is for their own good and maybe it won't help now, but may help down the road.

I want to be a great clinician both within the dental sense and within the ethical sense. I want to be the dentist patients will think positively upon and want to come back to. I also know that being a professional takes time, and that I have a long way to go before I even fully understand what being a professional really means.

I think it's true that as professional as I want to be, some patients are uncooperative and I'm learning to distinguish when they are being unreasonable and when I could improve myself in some areas. I think it's definitely a learning process. Some patients will just trust me right away, sit down and open their mouths and let me do whatever to their teeth. Others are shopping around or have this initial impression of NYU which is hard to break. Still others come in thinking this school is there to give them just a cleaning and expect me to do it without a treatment plan. It's definitely a lot of managing people's expectations and being honest with myself and with the patient on how much to get done.

I think becoming a professional involves being good with your hands in the clinic, as well as maintaining a positive image for your patients. I want my future patients to reflect back positively on their experience in the clinic with me. I hope that they will want to return to me and tell their friends about their good experience. However, I do understand that it takes time to build trust amongst the patients and that maybe some patients are not as cooperative. I just want to be the most professional I can be, so that I know I did my best to treat patients both ethically and clinically.

I've learned a lot about professionalism through interacting with patients in the clinic in D3. For example, first impressions make a big difference and some patients are just more trusting than others. A lot of the times, it is how I come across, my body language and my tone of voice and whether I actually listen to their concerns. Overall showing that I am a caring and empathetic professional is key to success in my opinion.

I have made progress towards being a professional. For one, I am building my hand skills in GDS lab. I have worked on everything from class I-IV and V. I have learned so much from my mistakes, from the faculty who gave me constructive criticism and from the different techniques taught by the faculty.

In clinic, it is a long road to graduation and I'm beginning to see how long this journey truly is.  I have made progress so far since the start of the summer. I came in not knowing anything (couldn't even take a proper x ray or use Axium) and progressed to being faster with Xrays and spending less time making mistakes on Axium. Treatment planning became a bit easier and I am learning more and more from the faculty each day. I guess the most exciting part is actually doing the procedure and seeing how to make an access or prep. It was really a long way to go before I truly become proficient. For now, it is making sure each step is done right and learning how to diagnose and treat each patient.

What I have learned from this course
The past couple of weeks were relatively busy, which is pretty exciting. I now feel like I'm starting to actually get into a good groove with diagnosis and treatment and executing procedures in a timely fashion. I finally managed to finish a full restoration from start to finish ( unfortunately I have yet to hear from patients who have IRM restorations filled from the summer), but nonetheless I'm looking forward to the restorative cases that I have planned in the near future, as well as more advanced procedures in endo which are also going to be scheduled relatively soon.

I still feel that I am behind relative to my peers requirements wise, but I'm using that as motivation to work even harder to get more procedures under my belt. Challenges are present every single day, but I think at this point I'm no longer as hesitant to take them on.

This week was busy with treatment planning 2 extensive cases, which I'm excited to get started. This upcoming week should be fairly busy as well--my crown patient from the summer is coming back so that his final impression can be redone, and I should be doing my first root canal next Friday. This upcoming week will be challenging, but I'm hoping for the best as I'm preparing for the procedures at hand.

When we were in orientation we were advised to seek out old exams from students in the year above us. At various points during the first two years we are also told that old exams are often obtained by duplicitous means and that passing them around may be considered a violation. I will confess, there were several instances when having access to old exams made a big difference in my academic performance. Now that the bulk of the didactics are over with, I have formed a strong opinion about the issue of old material. All old exams should be released. Course directors should expect that their exams will be released, that students have all old exams. To do otherwise can not but strike me as lazy. The ultimate result of full exam distribution will no doubt be a library of a few hundred questions for each major exam in each subject. To which I say, if students can indeed remember every way of answering all those questions, they do indeed deserve to do well. And, if a lecturer is not re-writing several of their questions on a yearly basis, lazy.

10/11/15: The world teeters, as ever, along the indistinct edge of horror. Short of bravely protesting and resisting the powers of greed and corruption, what I ask myself, is the most I can hope to do for society, for people, especially the ones I care about? Becoming a doctor who accepts medicaid, does much to ease my conscience. 

9/28/13: I have been a "professional" for over 15 years. I was an adjunct professor at Pratt Institute, and ultimately an advertising creative director when I decided to change careers. I have chosen to become a "Health Professional" because, although lucrative, careers in media, even as a creative executive, do not nourish the soul. I am very fortunate to have this opportunity for development.

Fall of D3 update: 
      It felt great to pass the boards, hard to say if that celebration is cooled a bit knowing everyone passed, makes it seem less special somehow, even so, it was a very difficult exam. I'm far more enthusiastic about the 2nd two years of dental school than I was about the first. Aside from the thrill of being in clinic and treating people, even our lectures are more interesting by simple virtue of seeming more immediately relevant to our careers. One very interesting thing I've noticed: despite all the effort we make to be formal and follow protocols, there remains a wide margin of error in diagnosis and treatment. I know well which supervising doctors to ask for a treatment plan review if I don't want to do a restoration on a tooth, and which ones to approach if I do want to restore, even the smallest aberrations.  The old saying is very true: get two dentists to suggest diagnosis and treatment, and you'll get at least three opinions. 

End of D1 Update:
      It's more difficult than I thought it would be, or perhaps I'm worse at managing my time than I thought I was. Regardless, my original goals are largely unchanged. I'll also add that towards the end of the year we were given a presentation on lasers, those are techniques I'd like to learn. 

      Everyone thinks I want to be a dentist because of sculpture. I'm lucky to already have hand-skills, that's the reason I believed I could get through dental school. It has occurred to me, that another, huge reason I want to be a dentist is because  of how much I've always hated going to the dentist. People who are afraid of dentists (most people) will recognize my empathy, and take comfort. It's hubris, believing I can be a likable thing that nobody likes, nonetheless, I'm in good company. Speaking of, I had a not uncomplicated procedure performed by student doctors at NYUCD. It was as essential a part of the learning experience as any other thus far.

Here's a link (I hope it works) to some of my tooth sculptures -

As I go through each day of dental school, I learn more and more about what it means to be a professional. I believe that as much as anything, it means to continue learning and continue to want to learn more and more about your profession and how to master it. This is the approach I take when I come to clinic everyday. I try to prepare as much as I can before hand and learn as much as I can before I begin a new procedure. But most of the learning comes from actually doing that procedure. It is important to really pay attention to detail during our time in clinic, because every day and every appointment can be an opportunity to learn something new, and this is an opportunity that we must cherish and take advantage of.

From my first few weeks in school, I can tell that dental school is much more than just learning dental anatomy or knowing how to properly perform different procedures. It is about carrying yourself in a certain manner and knowing how to communicate with others. It is about approaching every task with the right preparation and knowing how to manage time properly. As I have just finished my undergraduate education in May, it is certainly a bit of a transition period from the casual lifestyle of a college student to a more professional atmosphere. Even though I am younger than most of my peers, I certainly believe I am mature enough to make the right adjustments and become a true professional.

EDIT 9/23/15
After looking at my public self reflection two years later, everything I wrote about core professional values still holds true, perhaps even moreso now that I am in clinic. Preparation is everything, and it has been very important for me to go to clinic everyday with an idea of what I hope to accomplish and a plan on how I will accomplish it. Just as important is being able to communicate with patients

In order to become a skilled dental practitioner, I will use these four years of school to gain professional competence and strive to perfect my craft. In the process, I will make many new friends and establish a network among my peers. I will develop teamwork skills and learn how to communicate effectively with both peers and patients. I will be active in both research and community outreach programs, whether local or international. Above all, I will always stick to my values and make ethical decisions.

I have officially began working in clinic and I love it! I am especially happy because I've been learning dentistry at a pace that is incomparable to what I gained from the classroom. I feel that I learn best with a hands on approach and its been working quite well for me. Of course, no one is perfect, and in the midst of my excitement, I may have gotten ahead of myself with a few instances, and underestimated the process of transitioning into clinic in other instances, but with each minor altercation, I have taken away invaluable lessons that will stay with me forever. One of the snags I've run into in clinic is timing. I have found myself running passed the allotted time for appointments. I've found that it's usually because I wait for the faculty too long or dont use my time as efficiently as I should. Since this realization, I've made an effort to set time markers for myself to make me more aware of what I have done, in what amount of time, and how much I have left to do in a certain time as well. This has really helped me get on track and work much more efficiently.

After four years of dental school I would like to leave with the proper technical training and education necessary to practice dentistry as well as being proficient with the science behind it. I would like to perfect my interpersonal skills and be able to properly educate and communicate with patients and colleagues. I want everyone that I interact with to feel absolutely comfortable with me working on them, or working with them. I would also like to make valuable and reliable friendships here at dental school. I want to gain the proper knowledge and leadership skills that are necessary for practice management. I hope to systematically practice self-evaluation techniques and promote feedback from patients as well as employees on the content of my work, so that I would be able to constantly improve the quality and integrity of my profession. I would also love to give back to the community, by participating or coordinating community service events, educating society in oral hygiene and preventative care.

I've learned the importance of trust and teamwork in the short time I've been in clinic. Although it may be a recent epiphany, I've found individuals I can depend upon because we all share a common goal and interests. People have their own goals and that may work on a personal basis but a solid team allows me get through the rigors of everyday work and allows the opportunity to focus on the overall goal and accomplishment of our dental careers.

I've learned the importance of trust and teamwork in the short time I've been in clinic. Although it may be a recent epiphany, I've found individuals I can depend upon because we all share a common goal and interests. People have their own goals and that may work on a personal basis but a solid team allows me get through the rigors of everyday work and allows the opportunity to focus on the overall goal and accomplishment of our dental careers.

10/11/15: This week I informed a patient of mine that the tooth I was going to be working on may need to be extracted if the decay is deeper than it appears. She was not happy about the news but reluctantly agreed. At the end of the treatment the tooth was able to be saved. Once we had finished our session she told me that I should not have informed her of the possibility of extraction because it only made her upset. I tried to explain to her that it's our policy to be upfront with the prognosis but she still disagreed. I suppose in the future I should let my patients know of any unfavorable prognosis in a more delicate way.

Last week I got a little bit of a tutorial on how to use the V3 system by Dr. Byrd and I think it's going to help improve the quality of my composite restorations dramatically. This experience taught to always see what's new as far as the materials in dentistry. I wouldn't want to miss out on something that could make work easier and better.

Entry 9/14/2015: I currently have a few prosth cases that I'm working on and I should make it a point to see my patients as often as possible so that I can deliver the dentures to them. I'm still having trouble taking quality impressions and need to improve my technique.
50% complete

Ethic Reflection
Ethical decisions are amongst the toughest choices to make. Many times I know that this is not best treatment for this situation but you have to provide that sometimes due to patients’ will or may be for greater benefit. There were situations where I felt implant could be best option but if we look at bigger picture where patient might need a sinus lift and insurance that might not cover for those treatment and I end up planning a removable denture. I feel that economic aspects try to modify mindsets of patients. I had hard time to accept that initially and I used to convince patient for the best option but now I realize that considering all principles of ethics when we come to a conclusion that is the best treatment.

In next two years I want to see myself rendering best possible dental care to my patients, make correct diagnosis and provide right treatment plan according to patient’s needs.  Not everyone has a chance to relearn so I want to make most of this opportunity by participating in new learning events and research experience. I am also exploring more options for public health dentistry where I can incorporate my public health knowledge with dentistry.

Being a health professional is slightly different in a sense that we have to deal with living human beings where they make decisions for their health and life. It is a more responsible job than any other profession. With my past and present experience, I realized that teamwork and communication skills are very important elements for a professional.  To provide efficient treatment it is crucial to be able to work with different people that includes clinical and non-clinical staff. The hardest part I faced in the beginning was to figure out about clinical protocols. After I learned about system and axium, I see myself improving as a professional.

Being a health professional is slightly different in a sense that we have to deal with living human beings where they make decisions for their health and life. It is a more responsible job than any other profession. With my past and present experience, I realized that teamwork and communication skills are very important elements for a professional.  To provide efficient treatment it is crucial to be able to work with different people that includes clinical and non-clinical staff. The hardest part I faced in the beginning was to figure out about clinical protocols. After I learned about system and axium, I see myself improving as a professional.

After starting clinic in July, when I look back when I look three months back I see a definite growth. It has been around two years since I left clinical practice back in India. I never used rubber dam this frequent in my practice before so it took me time to get used to that. Many instruments are different i.e. extraction forceps. I was not sure if I will be able to do successful extraction of a fractured tooth after all this time with instruments I never used before. I had observed other people using it but until you do it yourself it’s different. I had so many fear and doubts when I started clinic but I guess every day turns out to be a new experience and makes me more confident.

My objective from the Advanced Placement program is to improve clinical skills and enhance my knowledge. I also want to utilize my experience as a dental student to learn new techniques and learn a local language – like Spanish. With advanced communication skills I can understand my patients better and render best possible care. Along with that I want relive my moments as a student by making new friends and socializing with my colleagues and mentors.

Over the course of the next four years as a dental school student, I would like to plan my career path to include the aspects of a dental career that are most important to me, while maintaining my ethics, values, and commitment to service. As of now, I know that I would like to make public health dentistry a priority for at least a few years after I graduate. In order to do this, I should develop my professional confidence and competency as well as learn to be a leader among my coworkers.

9.16.15

These past couple of weeks have been quite a learning experience. I've been doing a few new treatment plans, several with dental complexities. In addition, I have made a few axium mistakes and learned (the hard way) a few new coding policies (continuation of comprehensive exam should always be treatment planned along with the initial comprehensive exam, the right way to treatment plan SRP and perio maintenance, the fact that you can leave notes for individual teeth in the axium odontogram, and that SRP may be indicated even if the probing depths are not over 5 mm). Here are some of the interesting cases I am currently working with:

David Ortiz- 44 y/o male, previous drug abuser, almost edentulous maxilla (4 non restorable teeth with gross decay)
 I started this case with Dr. Lee for a maxillary CD and mandibular RPD, and will now be working with Dr. Jyoshi. We will be making a couple of changes to the RPD, and will no longer need to do survey crowns. The patient is anxious to get the process moving, but can only come on Monday evenings 6-8 PM and couldn't make it the past two weeks.

Luis Mejia- 68 y/o male, high blood pressure controlled with medication
We are considering the ethical dilemma of doing what the patient wants- extract teeth that ARE restorable in favor of a partial denture instead of doing what would be ideally indicated dentally- crowns on all remaining teeth.

Linda Ziering-
Treatment plan in progress. The patient will have an edentulous space on the posterior upper right after treatment so it is interested to think of ways to help the patient maintain quality of life. She has an EXTREMELY strong gag reflex and it was my first time trying to take impressions on a patient with that strong of a gag reflex + a very high palate. She even gagged while taking bitewing xrays. 

Ateeb Hussein- 20 y/o male with high risk for caries
This patient has already had previous extractions and is congenitally missing one premolar from each quadrant. He has several (8) caries into the dentin and spots of demineralization. I strongly emphasized OHI to him and told him that if he changes his dental care habits, he can profoundly save his dental health, especially considering he is so young. I need to prescribe prevident to him at his next appointment as well. He now seems really committed, but probably needs continued encouragement and reinforcement. 

Marlene Browne- high blood pressure, female
Patient has an edentulous space on her mandibular ridge in the area of #30. She would like to consider getting an implant. She also needs a crown on one of her teeth with existing composite but very involved recurrent decay. It should be an interesting case because it will probably be the first crown I work on.

This week, I also worked on an emergency case where a patient came in with a fractured 6 unit temporary dental bridge (#6-11). It was a difficult treatment because fabricated a new temporary bridge doesn't yield any guaruntee that the new one would not crack as well. There just seemed to be too much flexion in the area of the anterior teeth , so the remaining abutment teeth, since the luxatemp matierial is so thin in these areas, cracked regardless. We reinforced the luxatemp material with bonding agent and composite to give it a little more strength and decrease the brittle factor. 

I also went to treatment planning this morning (on accident, because my actual session is apparently not until 9/30). It was a very interesting case though, and I think it reinforces my fascination with periodontistry. It's amazing to me how everything in our field really does depend on the soft tissue and bone surrounding teeth.

Becoming a professional encompasses several factors and takes place over the course of one's entire professional career. I would like to embark on this journey by practicing and learning ethical practices that allow me to contribute to the health and wellness of my patients. I would like to present myself at or above the expectations set forth by this career. I would also like to express me deep respect for my patients through cultural sensitivity, unbiased decision making, and putting the wellness of the patient at the forefront.

Over the course of the past few months, I've learned that MANY things encompass what makes one develop into a professional. I find that the greatest learning comes from the little things. For example, when you are running late completing a procedure, but the next patient has already arrived for an appointment, you need to be a professional and be able to notify the patient who has arrived but also stay calm and complete the task at hand. In addition, being a dental professional depends heavily on timeliness and preparedness. If you know exactly what to do in a procedure and have all of the supplies necessary in an organized set up, this can help one become much more efficient and be able to maintain professionalism through punctuality.

Over the course of the next four years as a dental school student, I would like to plan my career path to include the aspects of a dental career that are most important to me, while maintaining my ethics, values, and commitment to service. I continue to wish to pursue a career in public health dentistry. The courses we have taken so far have enriched my understanding of the needs of various patient populations, and helped me understand the basic sciences needed to make accurate dental diagnoses.

9.30.15
These past couple of months in clinic have been an exponential learning curve. I am learning how to adapt to a completely new environment and how to treat patients of my own. Between learning axium, learning the proper protocols for treatment planning, and learning about the various new dental materials available in clinic, I feel like I am learning a course's worth of information in each clinic session. I truly enjoy this part of my dental school experience the most, as I am fully engaged in speaking with patients and trying to tailor treatment plans to best suit each patient's needs. I've also had the opportunity to learn various techniques from watching faculty members mentoring other students. I hope these observations will help me perform procedures smoothly when I come across them in my own patient population.

My second year was very tough, handling both personal problems and academic and clinical/lab load at school as well. At one point, I even thought about quitting dental school all together, or at least taking a break. However, I pushed myself to continue and although I didn't perform as well as I hoped or could have in both academics and in lab, I am still glad that I finished everything. I know the road to dentistry and even beyond after school will not be an easy one but I have learned from this year and I hope to overcome any and more obstacles that may come my way.

During the next two years, I hope to gain extensive clinical experience so that I will feel comfortable and prepared no matter which patient or situation I come across. In addition, I hope to learn how to effectively manage my time so that I can lead a balanced lifestyle. I also hope to look at the patient as a whole and assess his or her different medical problems instead of just the dental issue at hand. Most importantly, I hope to work with the patient to provide the best service possible that the patient would be satisfied with so that I can become a trusted and competent dentist.

8/31 THRU 9/3:

A week of learning how to understand patient's expectations of treatment at the school, and managing patient's expectations with what is actually possible. I've found gaps in my ability to present the treatment plan to my patients in a way that they can understand and follow. Two of my patients this week have shown confusion and misunderstanding in their own treatment, and I believe in has come from me not taking the time to explain procedures and reasons for their need in a language that is relatable to the patient. I need to be better prepared and knowledgeable of the services I am providing to more effectively answer my patient's questions and concerns.

Clinic Update from 9/9: This week I was able to deliver a PFM crown of #7 to my patient. It was a very rewarding experience to be able to see this case through from start to finish. Throughout the entire crown fabrication process things moved relatively smoothly, and no major complications were faced. One aspect that I was nervous about was the crown preparation and fabrication of the acrylic provisional. While I had made the provisional many times in SimLab, I was still nervous of the acrylic setting on the tooth and me not being able to remove it when I wanted. Also, I had only used a vacuum-form matrix to fabricate the provisional once previously, and it was what Dr. Comut had recommended I used. Thankfully the provisional came out well first try, which I wish I could say always happened  on 11th floor. The final delivery of the crown too a lot of reduction from the crown's palatal surface, so much so that the crown was nearly left without a cingulum. Upon cementing the crown and having the patient state her satisfaction, I felt very proud with how the case had turned out. Some pictures were taken and they'll serve as a reminder of the first of many crowns that I will deliver in my career.

As we have begun in the clinic I have come to realize how time sensitivity is so integral in the work that we do. I mean this in every sense, but it most strikes me in the need to operate efficiency when seeing patients. This is so important and if tweaked right will make the patient experience optimal, patient (and dentist) stress levels minimal, and allow for the best possible work on my end as the dentist. This element of becoming a professional is one that sometimes goes unmentioned but I feel like has really struck me as critical and something I am personally working on improving.

I hope to grow into a dentist who is confident, passionate, and compassionate about their work. I think ethics goes hand in hand with professionalism, which is why we took a course on it together. Ethics to me, at this stage is important for growing as student and future clinician. If I do not study and learn the material now, odds are I will not be  learn it later (which is why I can't understand why so many people cheat). I consider myself a pretty honest person and student and cannot believe the hoops we jump through at NYU to take an exam, especially when I have friends in other medical schools who take their exams in a computer lab by themselves at a time of their choice. It just blows my mind that people at this school would risk so much money, time, and a career on such a stupid decision.

As clinic continues I feel more and more like a professional. Working with and treating patients is a professional skill that I have been looking forward to since I have been in school. Interacting with actual human beings (with non-ideal dentition) has helped me become more confident in becoming the way I act and speak with patients - and I am confident that my operative skill and confidence will improve as I gain more experience.

I believe being ethical means making decisions based on what is best and right for the patient even if that means it may not be what's best for you as the provider. For example, in clinic I had a patient who insisted on having an immediate denture made even though it was not covered by insurance and he had no visible front teeth to begin with, all crowns were extremely broken down due to decay. Faculty and I agreed that not only would this patient not benefit from an immediate denture as he had no teeth that required immediate replacement, he would also need a classic upper denture long term so to make an immediate would really be doing the patient a disservice. While this decision angered the patient at first it was important for us as providers to do what was right because we need to go to bed at night knowing we are providing patients with the best possible care.
Professionalism is an incredibly important part of being a health care provider. We are held to different standards as patients look to us for advise and council so we must uphold these standards.

I think I am on my way to becoming more of a professional individual. I am gaining confidence, skills, and abilities. Now that I have my own set of patients I am taking care of, I am understanding more and more about what it is like to become a professional. Each and every patient is different and I want to be able to treat them in a respectful and effective manner. As I gain more experience working with them, I am getting better at finding ways to relate to them and showing that I care. I think that I am growing towards being a more mature person and a better professional.

The ethical decision making is important while providing treatment and it makes an impact on the patients' experience. So I can see the difference now but as we graduate we may fall into the other side (bad) where we are not trusted. It may be because of poor ethics or merely lac of good judgement.
