Things are getting better, finally progressing towards my goal of attaining a D.D.S. degree.
I hope to become a competent and compassionate dental professional.  I know this will require a lot of hard work and dedication, I look forward to the challenge with great enthusiasm.
Passing all my classes, progressing slowly towards the DDS degree.  Enjoy working on patients in clinic.

I believe ethical principles (autonomy, nonmaleficence, beneficence and justice) are the true guideline of dentistry. It represents how dentistry is centered around the patient's needs, not the other way around. Ethical principles allow dentists to provide as an honest service.

I'm facing a dilemma. Even before dental school, I've always set my heart on pursuing Orthodontics. However, as the application cycle draws near, I am conflicted between my passion for general dentistry and orthodontics. I wish I had a clear cut answer. It's disappointing that I have to choose one or the other.
Many can become a professional, but only a few will be competent. in order to become a competent professional, one must excel in every aspect

I lack many qualities of a professional that I envision myself to be. I want to be a professional who can prevent patients from encountering harm. I want to lead them away from restorations. In order to achieve this, I must be able to accurately diagnose and educate the patient. Currently, I lack the ability to see the big picture when I review patient's medical history and X-rays.

Now that I am becoming familiar with the clinic, I am able to provide a much more efficient service to the patients. I have a general routine for each appointment and it is helping me to stay organized. I am also aware of where all the necessary instruments and tools are which saves me a lot of time during preparation.

I value the personal relationship I am able to develop with my patients. The trust they have for me is what drives my passion for dentistry. I want to return their trust by providing the best and honest service. The more I get to interact with patients, the more I realize how the last two years of studying in dental school were worth it.

Now that my class has entered our clinical years, I hear about different things that go on in different clinics. I find that I'm faced with ethical dilemmas more often than I would have anticipated. I am trying to figure out the boundaries and not enter into a sticky grey area. 

It seems that most people are concerned with "the best way to get CEE's". I would rather do what's most appropriate for the patient and not let the fear of getting enough CEEs guide my decisions.

Now that I have passed the National Board Dental Examination Part I,  I feel a weight has been lifted off of my shoulders. I am feeling fully immersed into the clinic at this point. Although I realize that there is still an immense amount of learning for me to do, I find myself really enjoying this time as my peers are coming together to help one another and support each other through this process. In addition, I find the faculty are aware of the fact that we are new and they take additional steps to ensure our full learning experience.

Now that we've had a summer in clinic, mostly full time, I feel like I've really been able to develop my professional rapport. I have been managing my patient roster, learning the intricacies of dealing with a diverse group of faculty, front desk associates, and supply desk workers. It has been an interesting balancing act, but I am quickly learning that it is well within reach given the knowledge that I've learned here at school, and my previous work ethic.
I act as my own office manager and practitioner. I have to manage my roster, appointments, and schedule, while also applying a patient, or more specifically person centered focus.

I plan to be compassionate and ethical in my practice, to foster and nurture relationships with my patients and the greater community that I am in. I intend to dedicate myself to communities that lack access to oral care. I will continue to improve my education and stay current with the new information and literature that is presented to the dental community. I will work on my skills to make sure that my hand skills continue to improve over time.

I feel fortunate enough to be at NYU College of Dentistry, an amazing institute where I will spend the next four years of my life learning all the foundation knowledge that I will need, and perfecting my skills in clinics. I understand this will not be an easy task, but I am ready. I will do everything in my power to become a great dentist that I always want to be.

I cannot wait to learn everything I possibly can to become a competent dentist. Right now, I don't feel so comfortable on some of the procedures, but under the guidance of the faculties, I believe that will soon change. Currently, I am working on complete denture with a patient with Dr. Shackman, and just by watching him demonstrate the border mold itself allows me to learn so much.

My goal is to provide my patients with the best dental care possible with integrity and empathy. I wish to establish strong bonds with my patients. I not only want to be a health professional, but also a reliable mentor and recognized community leader.
